Title: Comments on Broadbent's response bias model for stimulus recognition
Affiliations: Bell Telephone Lab., Murray Hill, N.J, United States
Authors with affiliations: Nakatani, L.H., Bell Telephone Lab., Murray Hill, N.J, United States
Abstract: A theoretical analysis of D. E. Broadbent's (see record 1967-04542-001) stimulus recognition models for the word-frequency effect reveals that his general response bias model (Model 4) is mathematically equivalent to the general pure guessing model (Model 1). It is also proven that Model 4 cannot predict the pattern of errors which results from recognition experiments. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved).
Author Keywords: Broadbent's response bias model for stimulus recognition, word frequency effect, comment
Correspondence Address: Nakatani, L.H.; Bell Telephone Lab., Murray Hill, N.J, United States

Title: Continuity theory revisited: Comments on Wolford and Bower
Authors with affiliations: Turner, C., U. Edinburgh, Scotland, United Kingdom; Mackintosh, N.J.
Abstract: Critically examines the suggestion made by G. Wolford and G. H. Bower (see record 1970-02077-001) that K. W. Spence's theory of discrimination learning can predict an overlearning reversal effect (ORE). The prediction depends on a choice of parameter values representing strong initial preferences for 1 or the other position, or for S-. Experimental evidence with 20 stat-rats shows that such preferences are not a necessary condition for the occurrence of an ORE. Even if the model could predict an ORE under other conditions, the basis for the prediction would be the existence of a strong correlation between position habits in acquisition and reversal, which does not exist. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved).
Author Keywords: Spence's theory of discrimination learning & prediction of overlearning reversal effect, comments on G. Wolford & G. Bower
Correspondence Address: Turner, C.; U. Edinburgh, Scotland, United Kingdom

Title: An extension of Hull-Spence discrimination learning theory
Affiliations: U. Iowa, Inst. of Child Behavior and Development
Authors with affiliations: Spiker, C.C., U. Iowa, Inst. of Child Behavior and Development
Abstract: Proposes 2 modifications in the basic axioms of Hull-Spence discrimination learning theory. The principle of primary stimulus generalization is changed from an exponential to a linear function for both habit and inhibition. The principle of stimulus interaction is substituted for the additive axiom used by Spence and for the principle of afferent neural interaction proposed by Hull. With these 2 modifications, and other principles in the theory, prediction equations are derived for several types of problems involving discrimination learning and transfer. The modified theory is shown to predict that successive, conditional reaction, and mixed simultaneous-successive problems can be learned. There is also an illustration of the way in which response-produced cues can be quantitatively incorporated into the theory. Finally, a method is described for obtaining maximum likelihood estimates of the parameters in the prediction equations. A generally favorable evaluation of the theory results from a comparison of its predictions with the outcomes of some 2 dozen experimental studies. (38 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: Hull-Spence discrimination learning theory, 2 modifications
Correspondence Address: Spiker, C.C.; U. Iowa,

Title: Manifest anxiety: Have we misread the data?
Abstract: An examination of the research literature suggests that the data on the relationship between manifest anxiety and learning has been misread. A more defensible theory appears to be that the persons who score as high anxious are those who show disrupted behavior under failure-induced stress, but not necessarily under pain-induced stress; persons who score as low anxious are those who show disruption under pain-induced stress, but not necessarily under failure. This position accounts for most of the conditioning and verbal learning data published to date. (25 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: pain- & failure-induced stress & learning, manifest anxiety, review of research
Correspondence Address: Saltz, E.

Title: Role of rules in behavior: Toward an operational definition of what (rule) is learned
Affiliations: U. Pennsylvania, Graduate School of Education
Authors with affiliations: Scandura, J.M., U. Pennsylvania, Graduate School of Education
Abstract: Proposes a precise formulation of the notion of a rule in terms of sets and functions. It is argued that this molar formulation cannot be captured by networks of associations unless one allows associations to act on (other) associations. This formulation is then used as a basis for showing how rules are involved in decoding and encoding, symbol and icon reference,and higher order relationships. Decoding and encoding are shown to involve insertion into and extraction from classes, respectively. Reference is viewed in terms of rules which map equivalence classes of signs into the classes of entities denoted by these signs. Symbols are shown to involve arbitrary reference, whereas icons retain properties in common with the entities they denote. Higher order relationships are then expressed as higher order rules on rules. This is a direct generalization of associations on associations. Finally, a partial solution is posed to the problem of what (rule) is learned. Given a rule-governed class of behaviors, what is learned is defined as the class of rules which provides an accurate account of test data. Empirical evidence is presented for a simple performance hypothesis based on this definition. (38 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: formulation of rules, use in decoding & encoding, symbol & icon reference & higher order relationships
Correspondence Address: Scandura, J.M.; U. Pennsylvania,

Title: An objective approach to subjective experience: Further explanation of a hypothesis
Affiliations: California Inst. of Technology, Div. of Biology, Pasadena, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sperry, R.W., California Inst. of Technology, Div. of Biology, Pasadena, United States
Abstract: Attempts to clarify a hypothesis of consciousness in which the phenomena of subjective experience are conceived to exert a direct causal influence on brain activity. Response is made to some questions posed by D. Bindra (see PA, Vol. 45:Issue 3) that arose from a recent statement by Sperry of the concept. The aim is to clarify where possible with material that supplements rather than repeats previous accounts, and the hypothesis is compared with other existing theories. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved).
Author Keywords: subjective experience, R. Sperry's concept of conscious awareness, reply to D. Bindra
Correspondence Address: Sperry, R.W.; California Inst. of Technology, , Pasadena, United States

Title: The problem of subjective experience: Puzzlement on reading R. W. Sperry's "A modified concept of consciousness"
Authors with affiliations: Bindra, D., McGill U., Montreal, Que., Canada
Abstract: The statement by R. W. Sperry (see record 1970-01839-001) on consciousness is confusing because it entangles the idea of conscious awareness (subjective experience) as an emergent phenomenon of brain function with the idea that such awareness plays a causal role in determining neural activity and behavior. Disentangled, Sperry's hypotheses appear to be circular and dualistic. Whether these difficulties are inherent in his basic position, or are misinterpretations arising from the vagueness of his present statement, would become clear if Sperry further explicates his hypotheses in more concrete terms. (19 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved).
Author Keywords: subjective experience, comments on R. Sperry's concept of conscious awareness
Correspondence Address: Bindra, D.; McGill U., Montreal, Que., Canada

Authors: Creel W., Boomsliter P.C., Powers S.R.
Title: Sensations of tone as perceptual forms
Authors with affiliations: Creel, W., Union U., Albany Medical Coll; Boomsliter, P.C.; Powers, S.R.
Abstract: The perception of sound is time-dependent. What is experienced is an imposed form. Its raw material is memory of the past portion of the stimulus and expectation of its future. The auditory input itself is, at any given instant, a single stimulus which, standing alone, has no pattern or meaning. Investigation of larger sound patterns in language and in music has led to evidence that the sensation of tone is itself an imposed form. That central neural factors are important to tonal sensation is shown by tone-noise tests given to 55 patients before and after surgery to improve blood supply to the brainstem. In other phenomena of tone, the brain exhibits the properties of an apparatus that works by neural mechanisms of temporal recurrence. (45 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: sensations of tone as perceptual forms
Index Keywords: animal; article; brain stem; hearing; vascularization; Animal; Auditory Perception; Brain Stem
Correspondence Address: Creel, W.; Union U.,

Title: Knowing and using concepts
Affiliations: U. Colorado, Inst. for the Study of Intellectual Behavior
Authors with affiliations: Bourne, L.E., U. Colorado, Inst. for the Study of Intellectual Behavior
Abstract: In 2 experiments, 78 and 48 undergraduates, respectively, solved several problems in which the object was to find the correct conceptual rule (out of 4 rules conjunctive, disjunctive, conditional, or biconditional) for sorting of geometrical designs. Sizable general positive intra- and interrule transfer effects were observed. The effects were traceable to the acquisition by Ss of a simple yet general problem-solving strategy based on the bidimensional logical truth table, and suggest a tentative hierarchical model of the sophisticated S's knowledge and skill (cognition and competence) based on the embeddedness and generative character of concepts. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: problem solving using correct conceptual rule, inter- & intrarule transfer
Correspondence Address: Bourne, L.E.; U. Colorado,

Title: Perceptual processes and forgetting in memory tasks
Abstract: Presents a quantitative model of the effects of perceptual processing on memory. It is assumed that memory for an item is directly related to the processing of that item and inversely related to the processing of other items, and that the amount of perceptual processing decreases during the temporal course of item presentation. Therefore, rate of forgetting is not constant with respect to the retroactive duration or the number of interpolated items. It is shown that increasing the rate of presentation of a list of items not only decreases the perception of the items, but also decreases the rate of forgetting when measured against the number of retroactive items. The theory provides an adequate description of several memory studies using both verbal and nonverbal items. (30 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: memory, perceptual processing & forgetting & presentation rate, quantitative model
Correspondence Address: Massaro, D.W.

Title: Theory of serial pattern learning: Structural trees
Abstract: When undergraduates learn patterned sequences, they divide them into subparts. Each subpart has the property that it can be generated unambiguously by simple rules. Such a rule system consists of E, the set of elements or events forthcoming, and I, the set of intervals leading from 1 event to the next. Parts or their generating rule systems can be the elements of higher order rule systems. This produces the recursive E-I theory. 1 part is generated from another by any of a class of transitions such as repeating, transposing, or inverting. By applying such transitions as compound functions, one generates structural trees, which give a particularly simple account of certain regular patterns. Experimental results show that the difficulty of learning a transition within such a pattern depends on how high it is in the tree. The theoretical results are applied to the theory of music. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: theory of serial pattern learning, structural trees
Correspondence Address: Restle, F.

Title: Sodium amobarbital, the hippocampal theta rhythm, and the partial reinforcement extinction effect
Affiliations: U. Oxford, Inst. of Experimental Psychology, England, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Gray, J.A., U. Oxford, Inst. of Experimental Psychology, England, United Kingdom
Abstract: The rat's hippocampal theta rhythm shows frequency-specific correlations with behavior and reinforcement contingencies. A frequency of approximately 7.7 Hz. is seen during exploration and in response to frustrative nonreward. Amobarbital, which attenuates the behavioral effects of nonreward, selectively raises the threshold for septal driving of the hippocampal theta rhythm at this frequency. Septal driving of hippocampal theta at 7.7 Hz. applied during extinction enhances extinction; applied during acquisition it creates a "pseudo partial reinforcement extinction effect." Blocking the theta rhythm by high-frequency septal stimulation or medial septal lesions blocks the partial reinforcement extinction effect. It is proposed that there is a septohippocampal system which mediates the behavioral effects of frustrative nonreward and punishment and that amobarbital acts on behavior by antagonizing this system. (63 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: sodium amobarbitol & hippocampal theta rhythm & partial reinforcement extinction effect, rat
Index Keywords: amobarbital; animal; article; drug effect; electroencephalography; exploratory behavior; frustration; hippocampus; rat; reinforcement; reward; Amobarbital; Animal; Electroencephalography; Exploratory Behavior; Extinction (Psychology); Frustration; Hippocampus; Rats; Reinforcement (Psychology); Reinforcement Schedule; Reward
Correspondence Address: Gray, J.A.; U. Oxford, , England, United Kingdom

Title: Habituation: A dual-process theory
Authors with affiliations: Groves, P.M., U. Colorado; Thompson, R.F.
Abstract: Presented a dual-process theory of response plasticity to repeated stimulation. 2 hypothetical processes, 1 decremental (habituation) and 1 incremental (sensitization), are assumed to develop independently in the CNS and interact to yield the final behavioral outcome. Behavioral experiments are presented, using both the hindlimb flexion reflex of acute spinal cat and the acoustic startle response of intact rat, which are consistent with this theory. Neurophysiological experiments indicate that the 2 processes have separate and distinct neuronal substrates. The dual-process theory and other current theories of response habituation are evaluated in terms of these and other recent findings. (6 p. ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: response plasticity to repeated stimulation, dual-process theory, hindlimb flexion reflex of acute spinal cat & acoustic startle reflex of rat
Index Keywords: neurotransmitter receptor; animal; animal behavior; article; cat; habituation; instrumental conditioning; interneuron; myotatic reflex; neurophysiology; physiology; rat; reflex; sensation; startle reflex; synapse; synaptic transmission; Animal; Behavior, Animal; Cats; Conditioning, Operant; Habituation (Psychophysiology); Interneurons; Neurophysiology; Rats; Receptors, Neurotransmitter; Reflex; Reflex, Stretch; Sensation; Startle Reaction; Synapses; Synaptic Transmission
Correspondence Address: Groves, P.M.

Title: Bilateral symmetry and behavior
Authors with affiliations: Corballis, M.C., McGill U., Montreal, Que., Canada; Beale, I.L.
Abstract: Defined 2 tests of the ability to distinguish left from right: mirror-image stimulus discrimination and left-right response differentiation. A perfectly bilaterally symmetrical machine could perform neither test. Evidence is reviewed that animals and men find both tests difficult, especially the lst. It is suggested that interhemispheric fiber systems, i.e., the corpus callosum, act to "symmetrize" memory traces and thus preserve structural symmetry. This may partly explain findings of mirror-image reversal accompanying interhemispheric transfer. Evidence is also described which suggests that animals may sometimes solve problems of mirror-image stimulus discrimination by adopting asymmetrical postures or by making asymmetrical responses in scanning the stimuli. (63 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: bilateral symmetry of nervous system & problem of left & right
Index Keywords: animal; article; behavior; corpus callosum; hemispheric dominance; memory; perceptive discrimination; physiology; pigeon; vision; Animal; Behavior; Corpus Callosum; Discrimination (Psychology); Laterality; Memory; Pigeons; Visual Perception
Correspondence Address: Corballis, M.C.; McGill U., Montreal, Que., Canada

Title: The problem of volition
Authors with affiliations: Kimble, G.A., U. Colorado; Perlmuter, L.C.
Abstract: The problem of volition is partly a verbal problem, as the extent to which it has been ignored by experimental psychologists seems to imply. However, the attributes of such behavior suggest a variety of empirical approaches, some of which are reviewed. 3 new experiments, designed to demonstrate certain of these properties, are presented. These experiments employ what is believed to be a simple example of the automatization of a voluntary act. Results suggest that this process involves a novel form of reinforcement and that automatic acts are relatively independent of their consequences and are inhibited by the process of paying attention to them. (68 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: volition, problems of definition & empirical approaches
Index Keywords: adult; article; association; cognition; conditioned reflex; conditioning; feedback system; female; Germany; history; history of medicine; human; kinesthesia; language; male; psychological theory; synaptic transmission; Adult; Association; Conditioning (Psychology); Conditioning, Classical; Feedback; Female; Germany; History of Medicine, 19th Cent.; Human; Kinesthesis; Language; Male; Psychological Theory; Synaptic Transmission; Volition
Correspondence Address: Kimble, G.A.

Title: A closed-loop theory of paired-associate verbal learning
Authors with affiliations: Adams, J.A., U. Illinois; Bray, N.W.
Abstract: Basic to the theory are 2 associative states, a dependency of recall on stimulus identification, mediation, and response feedback which is compared against an internal reference mechanism for judgment about correctness of the response. Data in support of the theory are presented. (3 p. ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: paired associate verbal learning, closed-loop theory
Index Keywords: adult; article; concept formation; cybernetics; feedback system; female; human; learning; male; memory; paired associate learning; psychological theory; reinforcement; thinking; Adult; Concept Formation; Cybernetics; Feedback; Female; Human; Male; Memory; Paired-Associate Learning; Psychological Theory; Reinforcement (Psychology); Thinking; Verbal Learning
Correspondence Address: Adams, J.A.

Title: On the generality of the laws of learning
Abstract: That all events are equally associable and obey common laws is a central assumption of general process learning theory. A continuum of preparedness is defined which holds that organisms are prepared to associate certain events, unprepared for some, and contraprepared for others. A review of data from the traditional learning paradigms shows that the assumption of equivalent associability is false. Examples from experiments in classical conditioning, instrumental training, discrimination training, and avoidance training support the assumption. Language acquisition and the functional autonomy of motives are also viewed using the preparedness continuum. It is speculated that the laws of learning themselves may vary with the preparedness of the organism for the association and that different physiological and cognitive mechanisms may covary with the dimension. (2 p. ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: generality of laws of learning
Correspondence Address: Seligman, M.E.

Title: A theory of the acquisition of conservation
Abstract: Contrasted equilibration and learning views of conservation acquisition, and analyzed the differences between them. In a learning task involving discriminations of quantity, responses may be based on quantity alone, or the constraint between quantity and the dimensions of the material (i.e., height and breadth) may be learned as well. It is argued that learning of the latter sort would include the major features of equilibration. Such learning would render perceptual and cognitive judgments consistent with one another, and remove the conflict between them. Thus, the impediment to the adoption of a quantity criterion is removed, not when cues such as height are found to be irrelevant, but when height and breadth jointly are found to be consistent with quantity. A further reason why quantity criteria are adopted is that any combination of 2 judgments based on quantity criteria always yields the same result, whereas judgments on a single dimensional criterion such as height do not. Implications for the conditions under which conservation may be acquired are outlined. (28 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: conservation acquisition, equilibration & learning views
Index Keywords: article; association; child; child development; conflict; decision making; human; learning; perception; thinking; Child; Child Development; Conflict (Psychology); Cues; Human; Judgment; Learning; Perception; Thinking
Correspondence Address: Halford, G.S.; U. NewcastleAustralia

Title: A cognitive-feature model of compound free associations
Abstract: Made predictions concerning the response distributions for single and compound stimuli from a cognitive-feature model of free association. The basic premise of the model was that the basic units of language behavior are not words, but instead consist of hypothesized elementary cognitive characteristics which are more fundamental than words. The predictions were that the response uncertainty and percentage of adjective responses would be: (a) greater for 3-noun stimuli than for single-noun stimuli, (b) less for 3-adjective stimuli than for single-adjective stimuli, and (c) greater for adjective-noun stimuli than single-noun stimuli. In an experiment with 400 female undergraduates, these predictions were confirmed, supporting the suggestion that the appropriate unit for analyzing free associations is something more elementary than the word. (22 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: compound free associations, cognitive-feature model
Index Keywords: adult; article; cognition; female; human; interpersonal communication; language; linguistics; model; personality test; psychoanalysis; Adult; Cognition; Communication; Female; Free Association; Human; Language; Models, Psychological; Psycholinguistics; Word Association Tests
Correspondence Address: Johnson, M.G.

Title: Language and thought: Aspects of a cognitive theory of semantics
Affiliations: Ontario Inst. for Studies in Education, Toronto, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Olson, D.R., Ontario Inst. for Studies in Education, Toronto, Canada
Abstract: Presents an argument in 3 parts. 1st, it is shown by reference to the role of semantics in a transformational grammar that semantic decisions are not determined by either syntactic or semantic selection restrictions but by the speaker's knowledge of the intended referent. 2nd, it is shown that current theories of word-referent relations are inadequate to specify the grounds for the above-mentioned semantic decisions. Finally, by the use of a paradigm case, a theory of reference in terms of a cognitive theory of semantics is advanced in which it is shown that a semantic decision, i.e., the choice of a word, is made so as to differentiate an intended referent from some perceived or inferred set of alternatives. The implications include an altered conception of meaning, a statement of the relative information in words and in pictures, a hypothesis about the redundancy of the postulation of deep structure, and revised conception of the relation between language and thought. (46 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: cognitive theory of semantics
Index Keywords: article; cognition; concept formation; decision making; human; language; language development; linguistics; perception; semantics; verbal behavior; Cognition; Concept Formation; Decision Making; Human; Language; Language Development; Perception; Psycholinguistics; Semantics; Verbal Behavior
Correspondence Address: Olson, D.R.; Ontario Inst. for Studies in Education, Toronto, Canada

Title: Perceptibility gradients for tachistoscopic patterns: Sensitivity or saliency?
Authors with affiliations: Harcum, E.R., Coll. of William and Mary
Abstract: Offers 3 lines of evidence against the proposition of M. Hershenson (see 43:6 and 43:7) that so-called "perceptual reports" of tachistoscopic patterns are determined by retinal sensitivity. 1st, perceptual reports are not determined by absolute (retinal) position of stimulus elements. 2nd, best performance for elements nearer fixation can be obtained from conventional tasks in which postperceptual factors are obviously effective. 3rd, results of a mock perceptual-report experiment, in which Ss merely guessed which stimulus elements would be seen, duplicated Hershenson's results. This evidence favors intrinsic organizational processes as a determinant of perceptibility for elements within tachistoscopic patterns. (28 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: "perceptual reports" of tachistoscopic patterns & retinal sensitivity, evaluation
Index Keywords: adult; article; eye fixation; human; learning; pattern recognition; physiology; retina; vision; Adult; Fixation, Ocular; Form Perception; Human; Retina; Set (Psychology); Vision
Correspondence Address: Harcum, E.R.; Coll. of William and Mary

Title: A model of decision times in difficult decision situations
Authors with affiliations: Pollay, R.W., U. British Columbia, Vancouver, Canada
Abstract: Using the notion that decision makers will terminate the decision process when the perceived effort of analysis exceeds the corresponding perceived utility, the model predicts that decision makers in difficult situations will take less time when all the alternatives are equally attractive than when some alternatives are inferior and easily rejected. By using concepts drawn from Bayesian decision theory, the model specifies the way in which decision makers revise their expectations with experience. The model is also extended to predict correlations of the degree of such behavior with personality factors. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: decision times in difficult decision situations, model
Index Keywords: article; conflict; decision making; human; perception; personality; theoretical model; time; Conflict (Psychology); Decision Making; Human; Models, Theoretical; Perception; Personality; Time Factors
Correspondence Address: Pollay, R.W.; U. British Columbia, Vancouver, Canada

Title: On the relation between interocular transfer of adaptation and Hering's law of equal innervation
Abstract: Generalized H. Helmholtz's explanation of adaptation to laterally shifting wedge prisms to other optical transformations such as tilt and aniseikonia on the assumption that the spatial attributes of perception are encoded in or associated with efferent signals to the eye muscles. In this context, the relation of E. Hering's law of equal innervation to the issue of interocular transfer of adaptation was discussed. (29 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: Hering's law of equal innervation & interocular transfer of adaptation
Index Keywords: aniseikonia; article; cognition; extraocular muscle; eye; eye movement; human; innervation; physiology; spectacles; vision; visual adaptation; Adaptation, Ocular; Aniseikonia; Eye; Eye Movements; Eyeglasses; Human; Oculomotor Muscles; Vision; Visual Perception; Volition
Correspondence Address: Ebenholtz, S.M.

Title: On the equivalence of detection probabilities and well-known statistical quantities
Affiliations: U. California, San Diego, United States
Authors with affiliations: Green, D.M., U. California, San Diego, United States; McGill, W.J.
Abstract: Shows psychophysical formulae occurring in auditory detection to be equivalent to central and noncentral chi-square and F. Exact psychometric functions are displayed for forced-choice detection of noise increments and for sinusoids superimposed on background noise. These concrete psychophysical applications offer an excellent intuitive foundation for understanding otherwise formidable statistical abstractions. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: equivalence of psychophysical formulae to central & noncentral chi-square & F in auditory detection research
Index Keywords: article; energy transfer; factorial analysis; hearing; human; noise; probability; psychometry; psychophysics; theoretical model; Auditory Perception; Energy Transfer; Factor Analysis, Statistical; Human; Models, Theoretical; Noise; Probability; Psychoacoustics; Psychometrics; Psychophysics; Statistics
Correspondence Address: Green, D.M.; U. California, San Diego, United States

Title: Subadditivity and superadditivity of heterochromatic lights
Authors with affiliations: Wasserman, G.S., U. Wisconsin; Gillman, C.B.
Abstract: Mixtures of spectral lights have been found to be nonadditive, in the sense that the effect of the mixture is either greater (superadditivity) or less (subadditivity) than the sum of the effects of the components. These effects can be simulated by a model which incorporates known facts of receptor function into opponent-color theory. The behavior of this model is the resultant of superadditive effects due to receptor nonlinearity and subadditive effects due to cancellation occurring in the opponent-colors systems. When the parameters of the model are set at values which are appropriate in terms of contemporary sensory physiology, the model simulates the behavior of human Os. (19 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: subadditivity & superaddivity of heterochromatic lights, model
Index Keywords: adaptation; article; color vision; light; theoretical model; vision; Adaptation, Physiological; Color Perception; Light; Models, Theoretical; Vision
Correspondence Address: Wasserman, G.S.

Title: A two-process theory of individual differences in motor learning
Affiliations: Pennsylvania State U., Milton S. Hershey Medical Center, Hershey
Authors with affiliations: Jones, M.B., Pennsylvania State U., Milton S. Hershey Medical Center, Hershey
Abstract: Analyzes individual differences in motor learning into 2 components, a terminal process that derives from the levels of performance different individuals reach after unlimited amounts of practice, and a rate process which reflects variations in the courses different individuals follow in arriving at their terminal positions. The terminal process generates a Spearman unit hierarchy among the intertrial correlations with loadings on the 1 common factor which increase sequentilly with practice. The rate process generates a superdiagonal pattern which wastes away with practice; the pattern is strong in the early trials but becomes progressively weaker as practice proceeds, until finally the correlations scatter irregularly near 0. Theory and evidence relevant to this analysis are discussed. (21 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: 2-process theory of individual differences in motor learning
Correspondence Address: Jones, M.B.; Pennsylvania State U., , Hershey

Title: On retrieving sequence from long-term memory
Authors with affiliations: Indow, T., Keio U., Tokyo, Japan; Togano, K.
Abstract: When an S listed all the items belonging to a specified category, cumulative totals of items produced exhibited a smooth curve as a function of time. The equation proposed by W. A. Bousfield and H. W. Sedgewick was fitted to single sequences of individual Ss, and it was suggested that either the S scans at a constant rate and scans exhaustively or that the density of relevant items under scanning decreases linearly. When the retrieval was repeated in immediate succession, the functional form of the sequences changed and 2 models were proposed: 1 assuming operation of 2 parallel scanning channels and the other assuming the change of retrieving rate to an exponential form. (24 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: retrieval sequence from long term memory, model
Correspondence Address: Indow, T.; Keio U., Tokyo, Japan

Title: Continuity theory revisited: A failure in a basic assumption
Affiliations: U. Toronto, Scarborough Coll., Ont., Canada
Authors with affiliations: Biederman, G.B., U. Toronto, Scarborough Coll., Ont., Canada
Abstract: Discusses recent evidence which suggests that habit strength does not increase monotonically with number of reinforcements in discrimination learning. Since K. W. Spence's theory assumes monotonicity in discrimination acquisition, it is suggested that G. Wolford and G. H. Bower's (see 44:2) simulation of Spence's theory necessarily incorporates an incorrect assumption. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved).
Author Keywords: habit strength increase as number of reinforcements in discrimination learning, critique of G. Wolford & G. Bower's simulation of Spence's theory
Correspondence Address: Biederman, G.B.; U. Toronto, , Ont., Canada

Title: "Sources of Experimental Amnesia": Erratum
Affiliations: U Southern California, Los Angeles, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lewis, D.J., U Southern California, Los Angeles, CA, United States
Abstract: Reports an error in the original article by D. J. Lewis (Psychological Review, 1969, Vol No. 76[5], 461-472). On page 468, column 2. paragraph 1, sentences 3 and 4 should read: "Schneider and Sherman (1968), using a situation which ordinarily does not produce RA at learning-EC S intervals greater than 2 or 3 minutes at the most, gave footshock followed 6 hours later by a second footshock and ECS 0.5 seconds thereafter, and they found RA. They also gave a first footshock, followed by another one 6 hours later with ECS following an interval of 30 seconds, but got no RA." In column 2, paragraph 3, sentence 1 should read: "In an experiment somewhat similar to that of Schneider and Sherman (1968), Misanin, Miller, and Lewis (1968) produced RA with an interval of 24 hours separating learning from ECS." (The following abstract of this article originally appeared in record 1970-01885-001.) Reviewed experiments showing the likelihood that some experimental amnesias are not due to a failure of fixation, e.g., when amnesia for an "old" memory is brought about by means of a single ECS it is not likely that consolidation "interruption" is the cause. Also when memory returns following amnesic treatment the source must be sought in a performance variable. Other conditions are discussed in which amnesia does not occur even though the learning-ECS interval is extremely short. Interpretation of these findings are suggested. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: consolidation interruption; ECS & neurochemical experimental amnesia; performance decrement
Correspondence Address: Lewis, D.J.; U Southern California, Los Angeles, CA, United States

Title: Functional measurement and psychophysical judgment
Affiliations: U. California, San Diego, United States
Authors with affiliations: Anderson, N.H., U. California, San Diego, United States
Abstract: Applies functional measurement theory to 4 experimental situations in psychophysical scaling. 2 judgment models: additive and multiplicative are 1st applied to a psychophysical averaging task and to a ratio estimation task in which the numerical response is assumed to be a valid and proper measure of subjective magnitude. It is shown that factorial designs and analysis of variance procedures not only provide tests of the models, but also scales of the independent, stimulus variables. Next multisection (including bisection) and ratio setting tasks are considered. For these, the response is on the physical stimulus scale, and this is not in general an adequate psychological scale. However, the monotone rescaling procedure of functional measurement provides a way to get a valid scale of the dependent, response variable. A robust method for distinguishing between the log and power versions of the psychophysical law is also obtained. Finally, it is argued that the experimental base of traditional psychophysical scaling with direct, numerical response methods is inherently too narrow to support a solution to its problems. Tasks based on psychophysical information integration provide a broader and potentially simpler approach to scaling. In this approach, the psychophysical law appears as a by-product of the substantive development. (2 p. ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: functional measurement theory & psychophysical scaling, judgment models
Index Keywords: analysis of variance; article; decision making; factorial analysis; human; mathematics; model; psychophysiology; Analysis of Variance; Factor Analysis, Statistical; Human; Judgment; Mathematics; Models, Psychological; Psychophysiology
Correspondence Address: Anderson, N.H.; U. California, San Diego, United States

Title: Orienting responses and GSR conditioning: A dilemma
Authors with affiliations: Badia, P., Bowling Green State U; Defran, R.H.
Abstract: Presents 2 experiments which applied an orienting response (OR) analysis to GSR conditioning phenomena of CR acquisition and UCR diminution in 62 female undergraduates. The analysis focused on the stimulus properties of CS and UCS omission. A hypothetical response to UCS omission was suggested to affect CR measurement with short but not long interstimulus intervals (ISIs) thus contributing to the shape of the conventional ISI function. Data were presented supporting the assertion that responses to UCS omission appear to be ORs, not CRs. The question was raised whether it is possible to determine an ISI function for GSR conditioning using current testing methods. In Exp. II, a theoretical account of UCR diminution based on conditioning is critically analyzed. Evidence is cited supporting an OR analysis of diminution and new data are presented which show that ORs occur to omission of the 1st of 2 paired stimuli. (28 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: orienting response & GSR conditioning of CR acquisition & UCR diminution
Index Keywords: adult; article; conditioned reflex; electrodermal response; female; habituation; human; orientation; Adult; Conditioning, Classical; Female; Galvanic Skin Response; Habituation (Psychophysiology); Human; Orientation
Correspondence Address: Badia, P.

Authors: Studdert-Kennedy M., Liberman A.M., Harris K.S., Cooper F.S.
Title: Motor theory of speech perception: A reply to Lane's critical review
Affiliations: Haskins Lab., 270 Crown St, New Haven, Conn, United States
Authors with affiliations: Studdert-Kennedy, M., Haskins Lab., 270 Crown St, New Haven, Conn, United States; Liberman, A.M.; Harris, K.S.; Cooper, F.S.
Abstract: Deals with certain misunderstandings on which H. L. Lane (see 39:5) based his criticism of data that bear on a motor theory of speech perception. Lane criticized experiments that had demonstrated contrasting tendencies toward "categorical" perception of stop consonants and "continuous" perception of vowels and nonspeech sounds. He also undertook to demonstrate that categorical perception of nonspeech sounds can be produced by the ordinary procedures of discrimination training, and so to refute the claim that such perception is an interesting characteristic of the speech mode. It is shown that contrary to Lane's claim, discrimination training is not sufficient to produce categorical perception. (34 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved).
Author Keywords: motor theory of speech perception, reply to H. Lane's criticism
Index Keywords: article; hearing; human; motor activity; perception; perceptive discrimination; speech; Auditory Perception; Discrimination (Psychology); Human; Motor Activity; Perception; Speech
Correspondence Address: Studdert-Kennedy, M.; Haskins Lab., 270 Crown St, New Haven, Conn, United States

Title: Dissimilarities between conditioned avoidance responses and phobias
Authors with affiliations: Costello, C.G., U. Calgary, Alta., Canada
Abstract: Behavior therapists have accepted O. H. Mowrer's 2-factor theory of avoidance as an experimental paradigm of phobia development. The inadequacy of this theory, reviewed in detail by R. J. Herrnstein (see 43:5), has been further emphasized. The adaptive nature of conditioned avoidance responses has been contrasted with the maladaptive nature of phobias. Alternative theories to the conditioning one have been briefly noted. (41 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: conditioned avoidance responses & phobias, contrasts, implications for behavioral therapy
Index Keywords: animal; anxiety; appetite; avoidance behavior; behavior therapy; human; instrumental conditioning; learning; phobia; review; Animal; Anxiety; Appetitive Behavior; Avoidance Learning; Behavior Therapy; Conditioning, Operant; Human; Learning; Phobic Disorders
Correspondence Address: Costello, C.G.; U. Calgary, Alta., Canada

Title: Motor control of serial ordering of speech
Abstract: Provides "an account of those aspects of the serial ordering process most directly responsible for the sequencing of the movements" and the sounds of language. "Current models of speech production which have implications for the motor control of the serial ordering process" are reviewed, and "some major shortcomings of these models" are discussed. An alternative model which attempts to avoid these shortcomings is presented. It is shown that motor equivalence may be achieved by an internalized space coordinate system which specifies invariant "targets" which control the generation of necessarily context-dependent movement patterns, with the aid of closed-loop control, at least in the initiation of utterances. (2 p. ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: motor control of serial ordering of speech, model
Index Keywords: article; biological model; human; language development; learning; motor performance; movement (physiology); speech; Human; Language Development; Models, Biological; Models, Neurological; Motor Skills; Movement; Serial Learning; Speech
Correspondence Address: MacNeilage, P.F.

Title: A two-process memory-strength theory for judgment of recency
Abstract: Postulated 2 processes, retention and decision, to account for the ability to judge the recency of occurrence of events. Categorical scaling procedures were used in conjunction with signal detection decision rules to characterize the decision process. 2 memory-strength functions were considered as possible retention functions. Quantitative analysis and the results of a deception experiment with 22 undergraduates supported the duo-process interpretation of judgment of recency with the retention and decision processes being clearly distinguishable. (32 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: judgment of recency, retention & decision processes in memory-strength theory
Correspondence Address: Hinrichs, J.V.

Title: Two-phase model for prompted recall
Abstract: Describes a model which deals with free recall failures of previously learned responses. Recovery of such responses with the aid of a prompter is conceived to involve an independent retrieval and recognition process. These subprocesses are measured independently and predictions of prompted recall success are generated for prompters of varying strength and for various retention intervals. The predictions are evaluated by observing prompted recall success and the data produce a good fit under a variety of experimental conditions. Residual errors are related to possible modifications of the model. The prompted recall situation is well suited for component analysis of memory because it permits isolated study of various aspects of retrieval. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: free recall failures of previously learned responses, recovery with prompter, 2-phase model
Correspondence Address: Bahrick, H.P., Ohio Wesleyan U, United States

Title: Developmental analysis of interpersonal behavior
Abstract: Presents an analysis of interpersonal behavior based on 2 interrelated conceptions which are central in Piaget's approach to cognition: (a) the individual knows or constructs his world in accordance with certain principles of organization, and (b) the individual's constructions are expressive of particular equilibrium relationships between subject and object. The stages of cognitive development in Piaget's system are essentially formalized characterizations of such different forms of equilibrium. In general, Piaget's characterizations of these equilibrium forms have stemmed from his studies of the development of conservation in such "impersonal" categories of experience as quantity and number. A critique of S. Asch's approach to social interaction suggests, however, that the processes involved in the organization of interpersonal events are isomorphic to those involved in the organization of impersonal events. This view can be expressed in terms of an extended version of the above 2 conceptions: (a) the individual constructs his world in the form of complementary polarities which at certain levels of development are experienced as physical dimensions of the impersonal event and as role dimensions of the interpersonal event, and (b) the equilibrium relationship between polarities is a determining factor with respect to the conservation of both impersonal and interpersonal events. The present formulation attempts to delineate some of these equilibrium forms in the individual's construction of interpersonal events. (25 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: developmental analysis of interpersonal behavior, cognitive aspects
Correspondence Address: Feffer, M.

Title: A probabilistic analysis of the relationships among belief and attitudes
Authors with affiliations: Wyer Jr., R.S., U. Illinois, Chicago Circle; Goldberg, L., U. Illinois, Chicago Circle
Abstract: Outlines an approach to the analysis of inference and classification processes, based on the assumption that subjective probabilities are related according to the laws of objective probability, and suggests certain of its implications for the study of relationships among attitudes and beliefs. Some preliminary empirical support for the formulation is reported. The consistency theories proposed by W. McGuire, by F. Heider, and by R. Abelson and M. Rosenberg (see33:3) are compared to the formulation proposed, and possible differences in their assumptions and implications are identified. Implications of the proposed formulation for impression-formation processes are discussed. (24 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: attitudes & beliefs, probabilistic analysis
Correspondence Address: Wyer Jr., R.S.; U. Illinois, Chicago Circle

Title: Relative reinforcement effects: S1/S2 and S1/S1 paradigms in instrumental conditioning
Abstract: Presents a series of simple descriptive equations which describe the effects of variation of reward in differential conditioning. Central to these equations is the assumption that contrasted reward inhibits performance. 142 male albino rats were used in 4 experiments. A variety of behavioral phenomena observed in the double-alley apparatus are interpreted as reflecting discrimination behavior and, therefore, the operation of an inhibitory effect of contrasted reinforcement. (39 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: instrumental conditioning & reward variation, rat
Correspondence Address: McHose, J.H.

Title: Sensory feedback mechanisms in performance control: With special reference to the ideo-motor mechanism
Abstract: Reviews 4 interpretations of the manner in which sensory feedback may be involved in regulation of skilled performance. For the serial chaining (SC) and closed-loop (CL) mechanisms, response selection is assumed to occur on the basis of peripheral feedback from preceding correct and incorrect responses, respectively; for the ideo-motor (IM) and fractional anticipatory goal response (rG-sG) mechanisms, it is assumed that a response's performance is directed by anticipatory representation of its own feedback or of feedback from the reaction to a goal to which the response leads, respectively. It is concluded that: (a) evidence for rG-sG as a mechanism for specific response selection, as opposed to generalized facilitation or inhibition of instrumental performance, is lacking; (b) the notion of a mechanism for comparison of actual feedback with images of desired feedback is not essential for explaining error-correction performance which is characteristic of CL; (c) limited available evidence is supportive of a contemporary version of IM; and (d) IM, SC, and CL can be regarded as serving complementary performance control functions. (3 p. ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: sensory feedback & motor performance
Index Keywords: adult; article; behavior; feedback system; human; learning; male; motivation; motor activity; perception; problem solving; theoretical model; vision; Adult; Behavior; Feedback; Human; Male; Models, Theoretical; Motivation; Motor Activity; Perception; Problem Solving; Verbal Learning; Visual Perception
Correspondence Address: Greenwald, A.G.

Title: Sex-linked, recessive inheritance of spatial and numerical abilities, and Turner's syndrome
Affiliations: Presbyterian-St. Luke's Hosp., Chicago, Ill, United States
Authors with affiliations: Garron, D.C., Presbyterian-St. Luke's Hosp., Chicago, Ill, United States
Abstract: Discusses the "implications of impaired spatial and numerical abilities in persons with Turner's syndrome for the hypothesis that superior spatial and numerical abilities are transmitted by sex-linked (X chromosome), recessive genes." From a review of experiential theories it is suggested that there is a comprehensive biological basis for sex differences in cognition which includes the sex chromosomes, the sex hormones, biochemical processes, and a neuroanatomical structure. (50 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: Turner's syndrome & spatial & numerical abilities & sex-linked recessive genes
Index Keywords: article; behavior; female; genetics; human; male; recessive gene; sex; sex chromosome; sex chromosome aberration; sex difference; Turner syndrome; verbal behavior; Female; Genes, Recessive; Human; Male; Sex; Sex Chromosome Aberrations; Sex Chromosomes; Sex Factors; Spatial Behavior; Turner Syndrome; Verbal Behavior
Correspondence Address: Garron, D.C.; Presbyterian-St. Luke's Hosp., Chicago, Ill, United States

Title: Model of the function of receptive fields in human vision
Affiliations: U. California, Los Angeles, United States
Authors with affiliations: Thomas, J.P., U. California, Los Angeles, United States
Abstract: Presents a formal model which expresses the facts that a given location in the visual field is serviced by many overlapping receptive fields, and that because these fields differ in size, shape, and layout, the neural units which they drive respond with differential selectivity to various patterns of illumination. Implications of this model are developed for experiments on areal summation, detection of compound stimuli, effects of manipulating the sharpness of contours, and effects of background size and location on increment thresholds. (40 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: model of receptive visual fields
Index Keywords: article; biological model; human; model; perceptive threshold; vision; visual field; Human; Models, Neurological; Models, Psychological; Subliminal Stimulation; Vision; Visual Fields; Visual Perception
Correspondence Address: Thomas, J.P.; U. California, Los Angeles, United States

Title: Species-specific defense reactions and avoidance learning
Abstract: Suggests that prevailing theories of avoidance learning and procedures used to study it are out of touch with what is known about how animals defend themselves in nature, and proposes an alternate assumption that animals have innate species-specific defense reactions (SSDRs) such as fleeing, freezing, and fighting. If a particular avoidance response is rapidly acquired, then that response must necessarily be an SSDR, hence, the learning mechanism appears to be suppression of nonavoidance behavior by the avoidance contingency. Traditional approaches to avoidance learning appear to be slightly more valid in the case of responses that are slowly acquired, although in this case, too, the SSDR concept is relevant, and reinforcement appears to be based on the production of a safety signal rather than the termination of an aversive CS. (53 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: avoidance learning, species-specific defense reactions, animals
Correspondence Address: Bolles, R.C.

Title: Encoding categories of words: An empirical approach to meaning
Abstract: Presents a series of studies investigating the dimension along which words are encoded, using the "release from proactive inhibition" in short-term memory technique. Results indicate that semantic dimensions (taxonomic categories or semantic differential) are highly effective, whereas physical characteristics, i.e., word length or figure-ground colors of the slide presentation are relatively ineffective in releasing proactive inhibition. Results of this technique of measuring encoding are related to other types of experiments on verbal material as well as to the topic of subception and imageless thought. (36 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: short term memory, encoding of words & release from proactive inhibition
Correspondence Address: Wickens, D.D.

Title: General shape function model of learning with applications in psychobiology
Authors with affiliations: Warburton, D.M., Queen's U., Belfast, Ireland, Ireland; Greeno, J.G.
Abstract: Neurobiological studies of learning have encountered problems in the analysis and interpretation of acquisition performance. Some of the common methods of analysis can result in the false detections of treatment effects and failures to detect real effects. A general shape function model is described and its application to several problems outlined. Use of this method of analysis gave a more precise description of the acquisition performance and prevented erroneous conclusions about treatment effects. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: neurobiological aspects of acquisition performance, general shape function model
Index Keywords: atropine; pargyline; physostigmine; analysis of variance; animal; article; drug effect; factorial analysis; learning; theoretical model; Analysis of Variance; Animal; Atropine; Factor Analysis, Statistical; Learning; Models, Theoretical; Pargyline; Physostigmine
Chemicals/CAS: atropine, 51-55-8, 55-48-1; pargyline, 306-07-0, 555-57-7; physostigmine, 57-47-6, 64-47-1; Atropine, 51-55-8; Pargyline, 555-57-7; Physostigmine, 57-47-6
Correspondence Address: Warburton, D.M.

Authors: Valenstein E.S., Cox V.C., Kakolewski J.W.
Title: Reexamination of the role of the hypothalamus in motivation
Affiliations: Fels Research Inst., Yellow Springs, O, United States
Authors with affiliations: Valenstein, E.S., Fels Research Inst., Yellow Springs, O, United States; Cox, V.C.; Kakolewski, J.W.
Abstract: Presents data to support the view that there is much less anatomical specificity within the hypothalamus than is commonly assumed. Significant differences in animals between natural states of hunger and thirst, and those associated with the elicitation of eating and drinking are described. Additional information related to species differences, the role of prior experience, and an analysis of the environmental conditions essential to the elicitation of well-established response patterns suggests an alternative interpretation of hypothalamic function in the regulation of behavior. (39 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: hypothalamus, role in regulation of behavior, natural hunger & thirst vs. elicitation of eating & drinking, animals
Index Keywords: animal; animal behavior; drinking behavior; drive; eating; environment; histology; hunger; hypothalamus; motivation; physiology; rat; review; thirst; Animal; Behavior, Animal; Drinking Behavior; Drive; Eating; Environment; Hunger; Hypothalamus; Motivation; Rats; Thirst
Correspondence Address: Valenstein, E.S.

Title: Probability matching as a basis for detection and recognition decisions
Affiliations: University Coll. London, England, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Thomas, E.A., University Coll. London, England, United Kingdom; Legge, D.
Abstract: Assumes that in detection tasks, Ss respond so that the probability of their reporting a signal, Prob(Y), is equal to kq, where q is the probability of a signal and k is a constant reflecting the bias of the payoff matrix. This assumption provides a more plausible scheme than signal detection theory for the poorly informed S. When data are obtained from conditions having the same values of q and k, these conditions can be ordered with respect to receiver sensitivity. If the added assumption is made that the S has a fixed decision criterion, the model accounts for "conservative" behavior directly. However, signal detection theory still provides a valuable basis for assessing receiver sensitivity independent of response bias. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: detection & recognition decisions, signal detection vs. probability matching theories
Correspondence Address: Thomas, E.A.; University Coll. London, England, United Kingdom

Title: The age variable in psychological research
Abstract: Examines the treatment of the age variable in the conception, design, and interpretation of developmental research. It is suggested that age be incorporated into the dependent variable in developmental studies, by defining the latter in terms of specified aspects or parameters of the function describing the changes which occur over age for a given behavioral variable. Implications of this view for developmental research are brought out, with particular reference to problems of description and quantitative analysis of developmental change, to the application of the experimental method in developmental research, and to the study of individual differences in the context of developmental change. (57 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: age as dependent variable in developmental research
Correspondence Address: Wohlwill, J.F.

Title: A theory of visual movement perception
Authors with affiliations: Kinchla, R.A., Princeton U; Allan, L.G.
Abstract: Develops a mathematical model for visual movement perception and applies it to data from several experiments. Movement perception is treated as a problem of position memory: an O compares the position of an object at 1 point in time with his memory of its position earlier in time. The accuracy of this comparison appears to be limited by noise in his eye positioning system which is cumulative with time. Although involuntary eye movements are suggested as a major component of this noise, other covert components are also considered. A measure of visual movement sensitivity is defined which is independent of the O's response bias. Invariant estimates of this sensitivity parameter are shown to be recovered from a wide variety of perceptual tasks. (27 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1969 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: visual movement perception, mathematical model, position memory
Index Keywords: article; eye movement; human; memory; model; movement perception; Eye Movements; Human; Memory; Models, Psychological; Motion Perception
Correspondence Address: Kinchla, R.A.

Title: A modified concept of consciousness
Affiliations: California Inst. of Technology, Div. of Biology
Authors with affiliations: Sperry, R.W., California Inst. of Technology, Div. of Biology
Abstract: Challenges the assumption that the subjective phenomena of conscious experiences do not exert any causal influence on the sequence of events in the physical brain process. A theory of mind is suggested in which consciousness, interpreted to be a direct emergent property of cerebral activity, is conceived to be an integral component of the brain process that functions as an essential constituent of the action and exerts a directive holistic form of control over the flow pattern of cerebral excitation. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1969 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: subjective conscious experience & cerebral excitation control, mind-brain causality theory
Index Keywords: article; brain cortex; consciousness; human; physiology; psychological theory; Cerebral Cortex; Consciousness; Human; Psychological Theory
Correspondence Address: Sperry, R.W.; California Inst. of Technology,

Title: Fantasy need achievement and performance: A role analysis
Authors with affiliations: Klinger, E., U. Minnesota; McNelly Jr., F.W.
Abstract: Social status affects fantasy n Ach and performance, and may underlie their joint relationship, shaped and maintained by social control mechanisms, role conflict, and resultant anxiety. Ss high in n Ach perceive themselves as normally and appropriately overcoming challenging odds in achievement situations, and Ss low in n Ach undertaking unchallenging work. Each prefers and strives hardest in task situations consonant with his self-perceptions, and actively avoids role-inappropriate situations and behavior. Evidence supports the generalization that fantasy content reflects most prominently Ss' characteristic, contemporaneous nonfantasy activities, concerns, and social milieu. The role analysis provides a new theoretical framework at its own level of analysis, and suggests modifications of the motivational theory of achievement behavior. (87 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1969 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: fantasy n Ach, social status & self-perception & achievement situation role behavior
Index Keywords: achievement; anxiety; article; fantasy; human; motivation; role playing; self concept; social behavior; social class; social control; Achievement; Anxiety; Fantasy; Human; Motivation; Role; Self Concept; Social Behavior; Social Class; Social Control, Informal
Correspondence Address: Klinger, E.

Title: Future orientation and motivation of immediate activity: An elaboration of the theory of achievement motivation
Affiliations: State U. New York, Buffalo, United States
Authors with affiliations: Raynor, J.O., State U. New York, Buffalo, United States
Abstract: Finds the current theory of achievement motivation limited in that it does not distinguish between effects attributable to anticipation of future goals and the immediate consequences of an activity. An elaboration based on a more general expectancy-value theory of motivation is proposed to overcome this limitation. Implications of the new proposals are derived for situations in which achievement-oriented activity is conceived by an individual as the immediate next step in a path to some distant future goal. Supportive empirical evidence and an experimental paradigm for future research are described. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1969 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: achievement motivation, future goal anticipation vs. immediate activity motivation, expectancy value theory
Correspondence Address: Raynor, J.O.; State U. New York, Buffalo, United States

Title: The Ranschburg effect
Abstract: Summarizes recent research on the Ranschburg effect, an inhibitory effect on short-term recall observed when a stimulus string contains a repeated element, and attempts to identify the conditions associated with the effect. The theoretical bases for the Ranschburg effect, including a new analysis of the effect are considered and the results of 2 experiments designed as a 1st test of this notion are presented. (31 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1969 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: short term recall inhibition, element repetition, Ranschburg effect
Correspondence Address: Jahnke, J.C.

Title: Attributes of memory
Abstract: Conceptualizes a memory as a collection of attributes which serve to discriminate 1 memory from another and to act as retrieval mechanisms for a target memory. The attributes identified are temporal, spatial, frequency, modality, orthographic and associative nonverbal and verbal. (50 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1969 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: memory discrimination & retrieval, temporal & spatial & frequency & modality & orthographic & associative verbal & nonverbal attributes
Correspondence Address: Underwood, B.J.

Title: Redintegrative memory
Authors with affiliations: Horowitz, L.M., Stanford U; Prytulak, L.S.
Abstract: Proposes the following criterion for calling a memory task redintegrative: In free recall the probability should be high that an S who recalls part of a unit recall the whole unit. 4 tasks that met the criterion and 2 tasks that did not were examined. The redintegrative tasks showed that whatever part of a unit was best remembered in free recall was also the best cue for eliciting the whole unit; it had the greatest redintegrative power. This consistency appeared in memory for single words, phrases, sentences, and 2-digit numbers. Results are related to the issue of associative symmetry and to other matters of verbal behavior. (26 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1969 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: redintegrative memory, stimulus-response relation, part vs. whole unit free recall
Correspondence Address: Horowitz, L.M.

Title: Memory limitations of stimulus-response models
Abstract: P. Suppes (see 41:10) has proved that for every finite automation there exists a stimulus-response scheme which converges to the automation. A short proof is given making explicit assumptions left implicit in the original treatment. These limitations lead to the claim that the memory of stimulus-response models is limited, and that planning and motivation require hierarchical models. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1969 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: stimulus-response model memory limitations, hierarchical models for planning & motivation, criticism of P. Suppes' automata theory
Correspondence Address: Arbib, M.A.

Title: Continuity theory revisited: Rejected for the wrong reasons?
Authors with affiliations: Wolford, G., Dartmouth Coll; Bower, G.H.
Abstract: Presents a simulation of the original K. W. Spence discrimination model using 400 rats. Both the overlearning reversal effect and reversals being faster than nonreversals are shown to be within the scope of the model without modification. Both findings had previously been considered as evidence against any continuous, nonselective theory of discrimination learning. (26 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1969 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: continuity theory of discrimination learning, overlearning reversal effect, reevaluation of Spence's model, research with rat
Correspondence Address: Wolford, G.; Dartmouth Coll

Title: Stimulus-response theory of automata and TOTE hierarchies: A reply to Arbib
Affiliations: Stanford U., Inst. for Mathematical Studies in the Social Sciences
Authors with affiliations: Suppes, Patrick., Stanford U., Inst. for Mathematical Studies in the Social Sciences
Abstract: A reply to M. Arbib's (see 44:2) comments and criticisms is presented in 5 sections: (1) matters of proof; (2) stimulus traces and mediating responses; (3) number of states; (4) real vs. metaphorical learning; and (5) problem of hierarchies. It is contended that a viable alternative to stimulus-response theory has not been defined, and that explicit negative proofs of the systematic inadequacies of stimulus-response theory to account for complex behavior have not yet been given. The important constructive issue of determining how complex learning does take place is emphasized. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1969 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: stimulus-response theory of finite automata & TOTE hierarchies, application to complex learning, reply to M. A. Arbib
Correspondence Address: Suppes, Patrick.; Stanford U.,

Title: Control group and conditioning: A comment on operationism
Abstract: Suggests that not only operational considerations, but also the effects that a control manipulation has, as well as theoretical considerations, are relevant to determining appropriate control groups. A control group in which the CS and the UCS occur independently of each other has been suggested on operational grounds as the only adequate control for Pavlovian conditioning. This suggestion is criticized on the basis of findings which show that this "control" procedure has powerful effects of its own which impair its usefulness as a control. An analogous example dealing with the risky-shift phenomenon also is examined. The implications of these examples for the logic of control group inferences are discussed. (15 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1969 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: control group methodology, operationism & theory, Pavlovian conditioning
Correspondence Address: Seligman, M.E.

Title: Meanings, impressions, and attitudes: A model of the evaluation process
Affiliations: U. California, School of Social Science, Irvine
Authors with affiliations: Chalmers, D.K., U. California, School of Social Science, Irvine
Abstract: Incorporated into a "change of meaning" hypothesis assumptions about the process by which complex information sequences are evaluated. Cast into the form of a weighted average model, the hypothesis proved capable of accounting for impression-formation data within a generalized order effect paradigm. When coordinated with assumptions from interference theory in verbal learning, the hypothesis was capable of providing a groundwork for an explicit theory of attitude development and change. (18 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1969 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: "change of meaning" hypothesis & information sequence evaluation model, impression & attitude formation & change
Correspondence Address: Chalmers, D.K.; U. California, , Irvine

Title: A temporal interpretation of some recall phenomena
Affiliations: State U. New York, Buffalo, United States
Authors with affiliations: Slamecka, N.J., State U. New York, Buffalo, United States
Abstract: Hypothesized that, other things equal, amount recalled is a joint positive function of absolute and proportional time. A number of retroactive inhibition experiments were analyzed and explained within the framework of the hypothesis. An original experiment with 45 undergraduates demonstrated that the usual retroactive inhibition effects were obtainable even when the 2 lists were not presented separately, so long as their temporal features were maintained. With the provision that response biases can also play a role, proactive inhibition phenomena were similarly accomodated. A mechanism compatible with the hypothesis is suggested. (42 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1969 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: temporal recall hypothesis, absolute & proportional time, retroactive vs. proactive inhibition
Correspondence Address: Slamecka, N.J.; State U. New York, Buffalo, United States

Title: A coded element model of the perceptual processing of sequential stimuli
Authors with affiliations: Vitz, P.C., New York U; Todd, T.C.
Abstract: Developed a parameter-free model of how 35 undergraduates perceptually processed sequential patterns of binary and trinary events. Emphasis is on repeating and short, nonrepeating patterns. The model's major characteristics are: (1) coding of the pattern into a hierarchy of larger and fewer elements until the pattern itself is the final coded element; and (2) evaluation of the information associated with the coded elements using W. R. Garner's multivariate uncertainty analysis. The total uncertainty of the coded elements of a pattern, called Hcode, is defined as the pattern's complexity. Hcode values of a large variety of binary and trinary patterns are used to predict such response indexes as: accuracy of pattern recall, mean number of words to describe a pattern, and judged pattern complexity. Typical correlations ranged from .90-.95. Some deviations from the predictions that imply changes or additions to the model are discussed. (17 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1969 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: sequential pattern perceptual processing, binary vs. trinary events & repeating vs. nonrepeating patterns, coded element model
Correspondence Address: Vitz, P.C.

Title: Information-processing analysis of perceptual processes in problem solving
Affiliations: Carnegie-Mellon U., Graduate School of Industrial Administration
Authors with affiliations: Simon, H.A., Carnegie-Mellon U., Graduate School of Industrial Administration; Barenfeld, M.
Abstract: Proposed a theory to explain, in information-processing terms, some common phenomena in the initial perceptual phases of problem solving, to show that some existing computer programs for heuristic search and learning already contain basic processes that will produce these phenomena, and to show how simple organizations of the processes enable the programs to parallel human behavior. The theory is particularized in a computer program to simulate the eye movements, during the 1st 5 sec., of Ss choosing a move in chess. The application of the theory is illustrated and its consistency is shown with data on memory of chess positions and with existing knowledge of short-term memory parameters. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1969 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: problem solving, visual information processing analysis, computer program
Index Keywords: article; computer; eye movement; human; memory; model; perception; problem solving; Computers; Eye Movements; Human; Memory; Models, Psychological; Perception; Problem Solving
Correspondence Address: Simon, H.A.; Carnegie-Mellon U.,

Title: Sources of experimental amnesia
Abstract: Reviewed experiments showing the likelihood that some experimental amnesias are not due to a failure of fixation, e.g., when amnesia for an "old" memory is brought about by means of a single ECS it is not likely that consolidation "interruption" is the cause. Also when memory returns following amnesic treatment the source must be sought in a performance variable. Other conditions are discussed in which amnesia does not occur even though the learning-ECS interval is extremely short. Interpretation of these findings are suggested. (51 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1969 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: ECS & neurochemical experimental amnesia, consolidation interruption vs. performance decrement, review
