Index Keywords: amnesia; electric shock; human; learning; memory; psychological theory; review; short term memory; time; Amnesia; Electroshock; Human; Learning; Memory; Memory, Short-Term; Psychological Theory; Time Factors
Correspondence Address: Lewis, D.J.

Title: On the word-frequency effect
Affiliations: 4800 Baltimore Ave, Philadelphia, Pa, United States
Authors with affiliations: Catlin, J., 4800 Baltimore Ave, Philadelphia, Pa, United States
Abstract: The sophisticated-guessing theory of the word-frequency effect, rejected by D. E. Broadbent (See 41:4), in proposing his own new theory, accounts for the data of word-frequency-effect experiments better than does Broadbent's new theory. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved).
Author Keywords: "sophisticated guessing" theory of word frequency effect, criticism of D. E. Broadbent's theory
Correspondence Address: Catlin, J.4800 Baltimore Ave, Philadelphia, Pa, United States

Title: Scala naturae: Why there is no theory in comparative psychology
Affiliations: Walter Reed Army Inst. of Research, Washington, D.C, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hodos, W., Walter Reed Army Inst. of Research, Washington, D.C, United States; Campbell, C.B.
Abstract: The concept that all living animals can be arranged along a continuous "phylogenetic scale" with man at the top is inconsistent with contemporary views of animal evolution. Nevertheless, this arbitrary hierarchy continues to influence researchers in the field of animal behavior who seek to make inferences about the evolutionary development of a particular type of behavior. Comparative psychologists have failed to distinguish between data obtained from living representatives of a common evolutionary lineage and data from animals which represent divergent lineages. Only the former can provide a foundation for inferences about the phylogenetic development of behavior patterns. The latter can provide information only about general mechanisms of adaptation and survival, which are not necessarily relevant to any specific evolutionary lineage. The widespread failure of comparative psychologists to take into account the zoological model of animal evolution when selecting animals for study and when interpreting behavioral similarities and differences has greatly hampered the development of generalizations with any predictive value. (42 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1969 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: theory of evolutionary development of behavior, data from living vs. divergent lineages
Correspondence Address: Hodos, W.; Walter Reed Army Inst. of Research, Washington, D.C, United States

Title: Note on "optimal policies for the Prisoner's Dilemma"
Abstract: Amnon Rapoport's solution to the iterated Prisoner's Dilemma (PD) is shown to be applicable only when (1) each player's response on Trial n depends only on the outcome on Trial -1 (and on the length of the present "run" of the outcome), and (2) this dependence is deterministic only for the player offered the solution. General algebraic expressions for the favored player's long-run payoffs under these conditions are provided as an alternative to Rapoport's numerical methods. When both players are assumed to behave rationally, standard game-theoretic methods single out mutual cooperation on the 1st trial, followed by defection on Trial n unless a mutually cooperative outcome occurred on Trial n-1, as a rational solution to PD games in which alternation strategies are unprofitable. Any other PD games reduces to a coordination game. Some suggestions are advanced for analyzing the situation when the players are allowed to change strategies at any point, and when the players are not restricted to 1st-order conditional strategies. (18 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved).
Author Keywords: Rapoport's solution to Prisoner's Dilemma game, criticism
Correspondence Address: Harris, R.J.

Title: Temporal variables in paired-associate learning: The law of contiguity revisited
Abstract: Tests the law of contiguity by examining the relationship between associative strength and temporary contiguity of stimulus-response (S-R) events in a paired-associate situation using 150 undergraduates. The law was reformulated to assess effects of temporal separation of S-R events in the presence or absence of actual or potential mediating activities. The results for both acquisition and retention suggest the union of 2 components, a contiguity component and a rehearsal component. The contiguity component decreases rapidly from 0-1 sec. and more slowly thereafter. Beyond 1 sec., the rehearsal component increases in a negatively accelerated fashion, compensating for the lack of S-R contiguity. A model of the interaction of these components is presented. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1969 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: paired associate learning, associative strength & temporary contiguity of stimulous-response events, rehearsal component
Correspondence Address: Nodine, C.F.

Authors: Capehart J., Tempone V.J., Herbert J.
Title: A theory of stimulus equivalence
Authors with affiliations: Capehart, J., U. Arizona; Tempone, V.J.; Herbert, J.
Abstract: Reconsiders the problem of stimulus equivalence (SE). Primary emphasis is placed on the related areas of stimulus generalization, transposition, and discrimination learning as examples of SE. Recent evidence has indicated that the only comprehensive approach to SE, the Hull-Spence system, is inadequate to account for many phenomena in these areas. A theory of SE based on a combination of information and adaptation-level concepts is proposed as an alternative to the Hull-Spence theory. A number of investigations were conducted in order to test certain assumptions of the proposed theory. The results of these studies provide support for the approach presented in this paper. A main advantage of the proposed theory is that the use of adaptation-level concepts permits quantitative predictions when an appropriate mathematical model for the calculation of adaptation level is available. It is felt, however, that both in lieu of and in addition to quantitative predictions, that the present system has considerable heuristic value that may stimulate further research. (32 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1969 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: theory of stimulus equivalence
Correspondence Address: Capehart, J.

Title: Unnoticed verbal conditioning of an aware experimenter by a more aware subject: The double-agent effect
Authors with affiliations: Rosenfeld, H.M., U. Kansas; Baer, D.M.
Abstract: Apparent evidence that awareness regularly mediates verbal conditioning actually may by attributable to a self-fulfilling experimental methodology. A more appropriate procedure was devised in which a subtle reversal of the roles of S and E distracted the actual S from acquiring the problem-solving set characteristic of previous methods. This "double-agent" approach was established in the context of an interview. The interviewer considered himself the E, and was told that his assignment was to reinforce a particular motor response in the interviewee. The interviewee was in fact the E; he used that motor response to reinforce a particular choice of verbal prompt (to continue the interview) in the interviewer. Thereby, the double-agent interviewee (ostensibly the S, actually the E) was able to accomplish seven reversals in the relative rates of 2 of the interviewer's prompts. Frequent probing of the interviewer indicated that he was not aware of these changes in his own behavior, and that he had other irrelevant hypotheses to explain his variable apparent success in reinforcing the interviewee's motor response. Variable success in obtaining the effect across Ss may eventually be accounted for by parameters of the setting and by the S's other characteristic uses of the verbal responses chosen for study. Thus, the results indicate that verbal operant conditioning can occur without awareness in some persons, and that a person may unknowingly let his verbal behavior be controlled by another person in order to himself gain control over certain aspects of the other's behavior. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1969 American Psychological Association.
Correspondence Address: Rosenfeld, H.M.

Title: Concurrent verbal activity
Abstract: The capacity of the human to engage in 2 independent verbal activities at the same time is assumed to be related to the degree of attention required by the tasks. A hierarchical classification of tasks is investigated from simple emissive activities, through reproduction of an input, to problem solving. 44 Ss were tested. A relationship is found between type of task and concurrent performance. Similarity of elements in the 2 activities is not found to be important in the concurrent tasks studied. Instruction to rehearse is found to improve retention even though the vocal mechanism is at the same time reading aloud rapidly. Methodological and theoretical implications are discussed. (24 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1969 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: concurrent verbal activity, attention required & similarity, instructions to rehearse
Correspondence Address: Peterson, L.R.

Title: Sincerity and dogmatism: A reassessment and new data
Abstract: 2 hypotheses alternative to the acquiescence explanation commonly invoked to account for the double agreement phenomenon have been proposed by Rokeach. A study purportedly examining 1 of these (Hypothesis B1), that dogmatic Ss may tell the truth in response to the original scales and lie in response to reversed scales, was interpreted by the original investigators as negative evidence for the hypothesis. This paper examines the predictions and analyses of that study and concludes that they do not properly test the hypothesis. Appropriate analyses are presented with new data that support Rokeach's hypothesis with the Marlowe-Crowne Social Desirability scale but fall short of statistical significance with the Lie scale of the MPI. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1969 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: double agreement on original & reversed dogmatism scales, Social Desirability scale & Lie scale scores
Index Keywords: article; authority; human; personality test; recumbency; social desirability; Authoritarianism; Deception; Human; Personality Inventory; Social Desirability
Correspondence Address: Dillehay, R.C.

Title: Frustration theory and partial reinforcement effects: The acquisition-extinction paradox
Authors with affiliations: Hug, J.J., U. Toronto, Ont., Canada; Amsel, A.
Abstract: Experimental results indicating slower acquisition speeds but greater resistance to extinction under partial reinforcement (PRF) than under continuous reinforcement have been said to constitute a paradox for frustration theory, which attributes the increased persistence after PRF training to counterconditioning of anticipatory-frustration stimuli to the instrumental response. An argument is presented for resolving this apparent paradox within the framework of existing frustration theory. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1969 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: frustration theory, partial reinforcement effects on acquisition & extinction
Index Keywords: article; frustration; reinforcement; Extinction (Psychology); Frustration; Reinforcement Schedule
Correspondence Address: Hug, J.J.; U. Toronto, Ont., Canada

Title: Linguistic processes in deductive reasoning
Abstract: Develops a theory to specify in part how a person stores and searches through information retained from sentences. The theory states that (1) functional relations, like the abstract subject-predicate relation which underlies sentences, are more available from memory than other, less basic kinds of information; (2) certain "positive" adjectives, like long, are stored in memory in a less complex and more accessible form than their opposites, like short; and (3) listeners can only retrieve, from memory, information which is congruent at a deep level to the information they are searching for. The present theory, unlike previous ones, correctly predicts the principal differences in the solution times of 8 types of 2-term series problems and 32 types of 3-term series problems (e.g., If John isn't as bad as Pete, and Dick isn't as good as Pete, then who is worst?). It also accounts for previous observations on children solving these problems and explains other phenomena in deductive reasoning. (46 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1969 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: linguistic processes in deductive reasoning
Correspondence Address: Clark, H.H.

Title: Elaboration of Guilford's SI model
Authors with affiliations: Varela, J.A., 2926 Bvd. Espana, Montevideo, Uruguay
Abstract: Presents a modification of J. P. Guilford's structure-of-intellect (SI) model. The original 3-dimensional cartesian coordinate representation is modified into a polar coordinate system. Related abilities originally at extreme ends of a dimension are brought together thus achieving unity and closure on at least 2 of the 3 principal dimensions. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1969 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: Guilford's structure-of-intellect model, modification
Correspondence Address: Varela, J.A.

Title: Comment on roles of activation and inhibition in sex differences in cognitive abilities
Authors with affiliations: Singer, G., Macquarie U., North Ryde, Australia; Montgomery, R.B.
Abstract: The hypothesis of a relationship between sex-based differences in physiology and sex differences in cognitive abilities proposed by D. M. Broverman, E. L. Klaiber, Y. Kobayashi, and W. Vogel (see 43:4) is critized on the grounds of either a lack of supporting evidence, or supporting evidence which is contrary to the presently known facts. (21 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved).
Author Keywords: sex differences in cognitive abilities, activation & inhibition, comment
Index Keywords: article; cognition; female; human; male; nervous system function; psychophysiology; sex; sex difference; Cognition; Female; Human; Male; Nervous System Physiology; Psychophysiology; Sex; Sex Factors
Correspondence Address: Singer, G.; Macquarie U., North Ryde, Australia

Authors: Trowill J.A., Panksepp J., Gandelman R.
Title: An incentive model of rewarding brain stimulation
Authors with affiliations: Trowill, J.A., U. Massachusetts; Panksepp, J.; Gandelman, R.
Abstract: Early data and theories suggested that the properties of rewarding electrical stimulation of the brain (ESB) differ from those of natural rewards, e.g., food or water. It is contended here that such differences are solely due to differences in deprivation and training conditions, rather than to inherent differences in the rewards. Therefore, it is proposed that ESB has the same properties as other rewards and that its motivational properties are inherent in its reinforcement properties in the form of incentive motivation, rather than in the induction of drive energization. Data testing the model are reviewed and are found to support the incentive position. It is further suggested that to the extent that brain stimulation can maintain behavior in the absence of deprivation the laws for incentive independent of deprivation conditions can be found using brain stimulation. (4 p. ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1969 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: electrical brain stimulation, incentive model
Index Keywords: chlordiazepoxide; animal; brain; drive; drug effect; electrostimulation; food deprivation; model; motivation; physiology; psychological theory; rat; reaction time; reinforcement; review; reward; water deprivation; Animal; Brain; Chlordiazepoxide; Drive; Electric Stimulation; Extinction (Psychology); Food Deprivation; Models, Psychological; Motivation; Psychological Theory; Rats; Reaction Time; Reinforcement (Psychology); Reward; Water Deprivation
Correspondence Address: Trowill, J.A.

Title: Threshold theories of signal detection
Abstract: 2-state low-threshold theory (2-LT), combined with a probabilistic response model, gives a plausible account of those features of confidence-rating detection data that have been cited as evidence against it. Nevertheless, there are data that conclusively reject 2-LT. A successful threshold theory must have both a low and a high threshold (and in consequence, must postulate at least 3 sensory states involved in detection). 3-state low- and high-threshold theory (3-LHT) is compatible with available detection data and is quantitatively quite similar to normal distribution signal detection theory with signal-plus-noise variance exceeding noise variance. The most promising way to reject 3-LHT, and all other threshold theories as well, would be to show that the posterior probability of the signal, given the response, can approach zero for moderate signal strengths. (26 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1969 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: signal detection, threshold theories
Index Keywords: article; auditory threshold; hearing; human; mathematics; model; perception; probability; vision; Auditory Perception; Auditory Threshold; Human; Mathematics; Models, Psychological; Perception; Probability; Visual Perception
Correspondence Address: Krantz, D.H.

Authors: Broverman D.M., Klaiber E.L., Kobayashi Y., Vogel W.
Title: Reply to the "Comment" by Singer and Montgomery on "Roles of activation and inhibition in sex differences in cognitive abilities"
Affiliations: Worcester State Hosp., Mass, United States
Authors with affiliations: Broverman, D.M., Worcester State Hosp., Mass, United States; Klaiber, E.L.; Kobayashi, Y.; Vogel, W.
Abstract: G. Singer and R. B. Montgomery (see 43:8) state that the hypothesis that certain sex differences in cognitive abilities may reflect sex-differences in physiology lacks supporting evidence. This statement lacks substance since they do not consider the evidence reported in support of the hypothesis. The issues with which Singer and Montgomery are concerned are either problems of definition or are peripheral to the hypothesis. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved).
Author Keywords: sex differences in cognitive abilities, roles of activation & inhibition, comment
Index Keywords: article; cognition; female; human; male; nervous system function; psychophysiology; sex; Cognition; Female; Human; Male; Nervous System Physiology; Psychophysiology; Sex
Correspondence Address: Broverman, D.M.; Worcester State Hosp., Mass, United States

Title: Strategies and models of selective attention
Affiliations: Oxford U., Inst. of Experimental Psychology, England, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Treisman, A.M., Oxford U., Inst. of Experimental Psychology, England, United Kingdom
Abstract: Reviews experiments on selective attention, mainly to competing speech messages, and relates them to D. E. Broadbents filter theory. 4 types of attention strategy are distinguished; (1) restriction of the number of inputs analyzed, (2) restriction of the dimensions analyzed, (3) the items (defined by sets of critical features) for which S looks or listens, and (4) selections of which results of perceptual analysis will control behavior and be stored in memory. The role played by these different mechanisms in various experimental tasks is explored and their relative importance and efficiency assessed. (2 p. ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1969 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: selective attention, strategies & models
Index Keywords: attention; hearing; human; information science; memory; model; perception; psychologic test; review; vision; Attention; Auditory Perception; Human; Information Theory; Memory; Models, Psychological; Perception; Psychological Tests; Visual Perception
Correspondence Address: Treisman, A.M.; Oxford U., , England, United Kingdom

Title: Music recognition
Affiliations: U. California, San Diego, United States
Authors with affiliations: Deutsch, D., U. California, San Diego, United States
Abstract: Argues that music recognition involves certain specific processes of abstraction. A network is proposed which can perform these abstractions. (30 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1969 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: recognition of musical tone combinations, abstraction processes
Index Keywords: aptitude; article; cognition; hearing; human; memory; music; Aptitude; Auditory Perception; Cognition; Human; Memory; Music
Correspondence Address: Deutsch, D.; U. California, San Diego, United States

Title: Multidimensional information transmission as a function of unidimensional channel capacity
Abstract: The channel capacity of human Os in dimensional absolute judgments increases with the number of dimensions, though at a decreasing rate. A simple model has been developed for precise prediction of multidimensional channel capacity from known channel capacities for undimensional judgment. The model is based on the assumption that the n-dimensional channel capacity equals the distance of a point in n-dimensional Euclidean space from the origin when the point is defined by unidimensional channel capacities as coordinates. Predictions of the model are compared with available data on multidimensional absolute judgment. Errors of prediction are mostly in the range of .0-.3 bits. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1969 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: prediction of multidimensional channel capacity from capacities for unidimensional judgment, model
Correspondence Address: Slak, S.

Title: Interaction of information in word recognition
Affiliations: Applied Psychology Research Unit, Cambridge, England, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Morton, J., Applied Psychology Research Unit, Cambridge, England, United Kingdom
Abstract: Quantitative predictions are made from a model for word recognition. The model has as its central feature a set of "logogens," devices which accept information relevant to a particular word response irrespective of the source of this information. When more than a threshold amount of information has accumulated in any logogen, that particular response becomes available for responding. The model is tested against data available on (1) the effect of word frequency on recognition, (2) the effect of limiting the number of response alternatives, (3) the interaction of stimulus and context, and (4) the interaction of successive presentations of stimuli. Implications of the underlying model are largely upheld. Other possible models for word recognition are discussed as are the implications of the logogen model for theories of memory. (30 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1969 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: word recognition model, information threshold, word frequency & response alternatives & context
Correspondence Address: Morton, J.; Applied Psychology Research Unit, Cambridge, England, United Kingdom

Title: Nonstationary performance before all-or-none learning
Authors with affiliations: Polson, P.G., U. Texas; Greeno, J.G.
Abstract: Considers the relationship between all-or-none learning and stationarity of the conditional probability of an error on Trial n given that the last error is on Trial n or later. It is shown that by relaxing the restriction that the sequence of successes and errors before learning must be a series of Bernoulli trials, a class of all-or-none learning theories that do not have the stationarity property is obtained. (18 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1969 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: all-or-none learning & conditional probability or error, last error on Trial n or later
Correspondence Address: Polson, P.G.

Authors: Henley N.M., Horsfall R.B., De Soto C.B.
Title: Goodness of figure and social structure
Affiliations: U. Maryland, Div. of Social Sciences
Authors with affiliations: Henley, N.M., U. Maryland, Div. of Social Sciences; Horsfall, R.B.; De Soto, C.B.
Abstract: Discusses the relative "goodness of figure" of structures having some resemblance to the linear ordering. Completely connected structures made of asymmetric relations tend toward the linear ordering and produce strain to the extent that they depart from it. The M. G. Kendall and B. B. Smith coefficient of consistency is proposed as an index of departure from the linear ordering, and predicts ease of learning very well in an experiment in which 102 undergraduates learned social structures based on the relation "influences." The coefficient is modified to deal with incomplete structures and structures composed of both symmetric and asymmetric relations. Reanalysis of previously published data demonstrates that the modified coefficient powerfully predicts ease of learning of various such structures. (27 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1969 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: Kendall & Smith coefficient of consistency as index of departure from linear ordering of social structures
Correspondence Address: Henley, N.M.; U. Maryland,

Title: Sequential determinants of information processing in serial and discrete choice reaction time
Affiliations: U. Michigan, Mental Health Research Inst
Authors with affiliations: Kornblum, S., U. Michigan, Mental Health Research Inst
Abstract: Reveals that the measure of average stimulus information (H) is confounded with the probability of nonrepetition of the stimuli in most of the experimental conditions whose results have been taken as evidence in support of the linear relationship between choice RT and H. Results of a serial and a discrete experiment, designed to unconfound these 2 variables, lead to a rejection of the information hypothesis. The RT for repetition was faster than for nonrepetitions, and both were decreasing linear functions of their respective conditional probabilities. The manner in which the slope and the intercepts of these linear functions are affected by changes in the number of alternatives, stimulus-response compatibility, and response-to-stimulus interval is discussed. It is also shown that the present approach not only accounts for data which had previously been described by the information hypothesis, but for results which departed from the hypothesis as well. Errors are discussed in a manner which supplements the main argument. It is shown that the molar results of RT experiments can be systematically accounted for in terms of the characteristics of easily distinguishable differentially sensitive partitions in these data. (25 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1969 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: serial & discrete choice reaction time, stimulus information load vs. repetition
Correspondence Address: Kornblum, S.; U. Michigan,

Title: Optimal behavior in free-operant experiments
Abstract: Expected utility theory successfully predicts the steady-state relative frequencies of the 2 alternatives in 2-key, discrete-trial probability-learning experiments, in concurrent variable interval (VI) schedules, and in concurrent VI schedules modified to study magnitude and delay of reinforcement and conditioned reinforcement. It also successfully predicts the relative frequencies of interresponse times in 1-key VI schedules. Different interresponse times between pecks on a single key and pecks on different keys are treated as different instances of concurrent operants that have basically the same functional relationships with reinforcement variables. The theory states that an S chooses whichever alternative momentarily has the greatest weighted probability of reinforcement. (2 p. ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1969 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: utility theory prediction of steady state relative frequencies of alternatives in 2-key probability learning, interresponse time, pigeon
Correspondence Address: Shimp, C.P.

Title: Effects of "right" and "wrong" on subsequent behavior: A new interpretation
Abstract: In Thorndikian experiments, 48 undergraduates responded each time a stimulus was presented. Outcomes, e.g., right or wrong, provided Ss with information about correct responses. Classical results, such as the acquisition of correct responses, and asymmetry in the effects on right and wrong can be explained without using the principle of reinforcement by assuming that (1) S may recall his response without recalling its outcome, and conversely, (2) a response that is not recalled can only be repeated by chance, and (3) the probability of repeating a response that is recalled is independent of the outcome of that response unless it is also recalled. Several experiments testing this thory are reported. In general the results were confirmed. (15 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1969 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: conditioning S's verbal responses, E's verbal approval
Correspondence Address: Buchwald, A.M.

Title: Correlation-and-regression model for category judgments
Authors with affiliations: Johnson, D.M., Michigan State U; Mullally, C.R.
Abstract: Correlation-and-regression analysis, though seldom used, is appropriate for judgments of ordered stimuli on ordered scales. A reduction in exposure time, by reducing accuracy, systematically reduces the correlation between judgments and stimuli and consequently the slope of the regression line. The regression equations reproduce the mean scale values of the stimuli and explain the central tendency of judgment. Effects of external anchoring stimuli on judgments of all stimuli are clarified by computation of conventional regression equations. The equation for estimating the correlation in a wide range from the correlation in a narrow range can be applied to judgment data. This model is compared with others and some limitations are noted. (21 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1969 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: correlation & regression model, category judgments of visual stimuli
Correspondence Address: Johnson, D.M.

Title: Oculomotor control: A possible function of REM sleep
Affiliations: U. California, Crown Coll., Santa Cruz
Authors with affiliations: Berger, R.J., U. California, Crown Coll., Santa Cruz
Abstract: Hypothesized that REM sleep provides a mechanism for establishment of the neuromuscular pathways serving binocularly coordinated eye movements in both phylogenesis and ontogenesis; and that throughout mammalian life REM sleep periodically innervates the oculomotor system during extended sleep to maintain facilitation of binocularly coordinated eye movement into subsequent wakefulness. Positive correlations between amounts of REM sleep and of conjugate eye mobility in phylogenesis are described. The possibilities of rapid plastic changes with lack of innervation of the oculomotor system during NREM sleep are suggested. Consistent with the hypothesis are the high degree of organization of the REMs and their reciprocal relationships with prior waking eye movements, the effects of sleep deprivation, and the neurophysiological mechanisms of REM sleep. (5 p. ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1969 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: REM sleep & innervation of oculomotor system for coordinated eye movements

Title: Heterochromatic additivity failure
Abstract: Mixtures of spectral lights have been found to be nonadditive, in the sense that the effect of the mixture is not equal to the sum of the effects of the components. A model is described which simulates the results of such mixture experiments. The model incorporates conventional ideas about the mechanism of color vision; the novel feature is a postulated collateral from the chromaticity to the luminosity system. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1969 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: model of nonadditivity of spectral lights
Index Keywords: article; biological model; color vision; human; vision; Color Perception; Human; Models, Biological; Vision
Correspondence Address: Wasserman, G.S.

Title: Quantitative specification of information in sequential patterns
Abstract: Presents a theory dealing with the specification of the units of information that are independently processed in the human perception of sequential patterns. It implies that sequential patterns, i.e., visual patterns and Letter Series Completion Test items, can be encoded in a formal language. The amount of information that can subsequently be reduced from these formal representations predicts rather successfully the degree of complexity of patterns such as measured in various tasks recording complexity judgments, the number of tachistoscopic presentations required for correct reproduction, fixation times, duration of appearance, stabilized retinal images, and errors in the extrapolation of letter series. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1969 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: quantitative specification of information in sequential visual & letter patterns

Title: Auditory or articulatory coding in verbal short-term memory
Authors with affiliations: Wickelgren, W.A., Massuchusetts Inst. of Technology
Abstract: Attempts to determine whether the verbal short-term memory (STM) trace is in an auditory or an articulatory system by comparison of the confusion matrices for auditory recognition and STM are shown to be based on assumptions that are very likely invalid. Attempts to decide this question by means of the effects of noise on STM are also shown to be inconclusive. It must be considered that the trace is in an abstract verbal system that is neither purely auditory nor purely articulatory. (19 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1969 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: verbal short term memory, auditory vs. articulatory coding
Index Keywords: article; hearing; human; linguistics; short term memory; speech; Auditory Perception; Human; Memory, Short-Term; Psycholinguistics; Speech

Title: Curvilinear relation between cognitive functioning and distance of child from parent of the same sex
Authors with affiliations: Lynn, D.B., U. California, Davis, United States
Abstract: Hypothesized that the child's cognitive functioning is related curvilinearly to the distance of the child from the parent of the same sex. Such cognitive functioning is best exemplified by field independence and problem-solving skills. The hypotheses presented follow the basic hypothesis: (1) Males are better problem solvers and more field independent than females. (2) Boys with distant fathers tend to be poor problem solvers and to be field dependent. (3) Girls with moderately distant mothers are better problem solvers and more field independent than girls with closer mothers. (4) With the father unusually close to the boy and the mother relatively distant from the girl, the superiority of males in problem solving and field independence is lost. (5) With the father extremely close to the boy and the mother relatively distant from the girl, boys are inferior to girls in problem solving and are more field dependent. (17 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1969 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: field independence & problem solving, parent-child relationship & sex differences, children
Index Keywords: article; child; child parent relation; cognition; group psychology; human; identity; sex; Child; Cognition; Human; Identification (Psychology); Parent-Child Relations; Sex; Social Distance
Correspondence Address: Lynn, D.B.; U. California, Davis, United States

Title: Storage and retrieval processes in long-term memory
Authors with affiliations: Shiffrin, R.M., Indiana U; Atkinson, R.C.
Abstract: Describes a theory of human memory in which a distinction is made between 3 memory stores: the sensory register, and the short- and long-term stores. Primary emphasis is given to the processes by which information is stored in and retrieved from the long-term store, a store which is considered to be a permanent repository for information. Forgetting and related phenomena are attributed to a failure of the retrieval process, in which the search through some memory area becomes less efficient as new information is placed in it. Storage and retrieval in the long-term store are conceived of as parallel processes, one mirroring the other, and each is divided into 3 stages for conceptual clarity. The memory trace is viewed as an ensemble of information stored in some memory location, the location of storage determined largely by the components of the ensemble itself. The ability of the system to cope with diverse phenomena is demonstrated by a number of selected experimental paradigms. (2 p. ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1969 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: memory theory, storage & retrieval processes
Correspondence Address: Shiffrin, R.M.

Title: Mental imagery in associative learning and memory
Affiliations: Middlesex Coll., U. Western Ontario, London, Canada, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Paivio, A., Middlesex Coll., U. Western Ontario, London, Canada, Canada
Abstract: Considers nonverbal imagery and verbal symbolic processes in relation to associative learning and memory. These 2 hypothesized processes are operationally distinguished in terms of stimulus attributes and experimental procedures designed to make them differentially available as associative mediators or memory codes. The availability of imagery is assumed to vary directly with item concreteness or image-evoking value, whereas verbal processes are presumably independent of concreteness but functionally linked to meaningfulness (m) and codability. Stimulus characteristics are hypothesized to interact with mediation instructions, presentation rates, and type of memory task. Performance and subjective-report data resulting from experimental tests of the model indicated that imagery-concreteness is the most potent stimulus attribute yet identified among meaningful items, while m and other relevant attributes are relatively ineffective; that both processes can be effectively manipulated by mediation instructions, but imagery is a "preferred" mediator when at least 1 member of the pair is relatively concrete; and that the 2 mechanisms are differentially effective in sequential and nonsequential memory tasks. Findings substantiate the explanatory and heuristic value of the imagery concept. (4 p. ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1969 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: associative learning & memory, mental imagery & verbal symbolic processes
Correspondence Address: Paivio, A.

Title: Intransitivity of preferences
Authors with affiliations: Tversky, A., Hewbrew U., Jerusalem, Israel
Abstract: Reveals that, under specified experimental conditions, consistent and predictable intransitivities can be demonstrated. The conditions under which intransitivities occur and their relationships to the structure of the alternatives and to processing strategies are investigated within the framework of a general theory of choice. Implications to the study of preference and the psychology of choice are discussed. (33 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1969 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: transitivity in preference & choice behavior
Correspondence Address: Tversky, A.; Hewbrew U., Jerusalem, Israel

Title: Method and theory in the study of avoidance
Abstract: Devised 2-factor theories of avoidance to explain responding in avoidance procedures that closely resemble the Pavlovian paradigm in superficial features, although differing in the fundamental contingency of reinforcement. Both typically involve an arbitrary CS and a trial-by-trial sequence of pairings between the CS and UCS. According to 2-factor theory, the instrumental reinforcement of avoidance is based on the Pavlovian reinforcement of a drive state in the presence of the CS. It has been shown that the presence of the CS is not necessary for the occurrence of avoidance responding. A procedure in which the sole effect of the avoidance response was a reduction in the average frequency of occurrence of an aversive electric shock proved to fully adequate to maintain lever pressing in rats, thereby suggesting that not all avoidance requires 2 factors. Further experiments with various new procedures suggested that the CS may function as a discriminative stimulus for the avoidance response, rather than as a stimulus whose removal is inherently reinforcing, as 2-factor theory requires. (56 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1969 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: avoidance conditioning research, method & theory
Index Keywords: animal; article; avoidance behavior; conditioned reflex; conditioning; electric shock; emotion; psychological theory; technique; Animal; Avoidance Learning; Conditioning (Psychology); Conditioning, Classical; Electroshock; Emotions; Methods; Psychological Theory

Title: Reinforcement as consolidation
Abstract: Presents a theory of the nature of reinforcement. It assumes that learning is essentially by contiguity, but that a hyperexcitable state exists in the nervous system following an experience, such that an ordinarily insufficient stimulus can reexcite all or part of the cells involved in a just prior learning experience. This reexcitation in turn generates additional consolidation and thus strengthens learning. The theory thus explains the retroactive effect of operant reinforcement. Coupled with an assumption of nonadditivity of 2 temporally overlapping consolidation processes, the theory predicts certain phenomena of temporal gradients of reinforcement. The predictions compare favorably with data. (33 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1969 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: reinforcement as neural consolidation, theory
Index Keywords: article; human; instrumental conditioning; nervous system function; paired associate learning; reinforcement; time; Conditioning, Operant; Human; Nervous System Physiology; Paired-Associate Learning; Reinforcement (Psychology); Time Factors
Correspondence Address: Landauer, T.K.

Title: Visual intensity judgments: An empirical rule and a theory
Abstract: Judgments of visual intensity are shown to be proportional to the square root of the stimulus intensity, when known biasing factors are eliminated, for 5 classes of judgments: (1) lightness of gray papers, (2) brightness of luminous fields, (3) brightness of brief light flashes, (4) brightness of star points, and (5) quantitative judgments of color. The rule is explained in terms of the physical correlate theory of sensory intensity. (67 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1969 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: visual intensity judgments, formula & theory
Index Keywords: color vision; decision making; electrophysiology; human; mathematics; psychological theory; review; visual acuity; visual adaptation; Adaptation, Ocular; Color Perception; Electrophysiology; Human; Judgment; Mathematics; Psychological Theory; Visual Acuity
Correspondence Address: Warren, R.M.

Title: Parsimonious biological models of memory and reinforcement
Abstract: The synaptic and RNA theories of memory assume more than is necessary to show how neuronal changes could store information. Neurons acting as units could store information through modulations of the ordinary metabolic events which maintain electrical excitability. This type of memory model is parsimonious because (1) its assumptions are few, and widely accepted, and (2) the postulated biochemical changes could occur in well described, commonplace metabolic reactions. This memory model does not depend on any particular reinforcement theory, but it is consistent with plausible electrophysiological and humoral mechanisms of reinforcement. (3 p. ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1969 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: biological model of memory & reinforcement
Index Keywords: hormone; animal; article; biological model; electrophysiology; human; memory; model; nerve cell; physiology; reinforcement; Animal; Electrophysiology; Hormones; Human; Memory; Models, Neurological; Models, Psychological; Neurons; Reinforcement (Psychology)
Correspondence Address: Pfaff, D.

Title: Context-sensitive coding, associative memory, and serial order in (speech) behavior
Authors with affiliations: Wickelgran, W.A., Massachusetts Inst. of Technology
Abstract: Defines the problem of serial order in noncreative behavior in much the same manner as K. S. Lashley, and examines several theories of serial order. Lashley's rejection of associative-chain theories of serial order is shown to apply to 1 particular theory, and to be invalid as applied to other associative theories. The most plausible theory is the context-sensitive associative theory, which assumes that serial order is encoded by means of associations between context-sensitive elementary motor responses. In speech, this means that a word, e.g., sleep, is assumed to be coded allophonically rather than phonemically. This theory handles the pronunciation of single words and even phrases in a certain sense. (19 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1969 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: serial order in speech behavior & context-sensitive coding & associative memory
Correspondence Address: Wickelgran, W.A.; Massachusetts Inst. of Technology

Title: Transfer-activited response sets in verbal learning and transfer
Authors with affiliations: Paul, C., Adelphi U; Paul, H.
Abstract: Presents the notion that in verbal rote-learning tasks preexperimentally acquired conceptual and classificatory responses are activated by attributes of the materials to be learned, and that the implicit representational stimuli associated with these responses serve to constrain the class of responses emitted. Thus, the emission of a particular response is under the control of both an implicit stimulus that is discriminative with respect to response class and an exteroceptive stimulus which is discriminative with respect to a specific member of the class. The above notion seems useful in accounting for experimental differences obtained between mixed and unmixed treatment (list) conditions, and has implications regarding the role of specific associations in single-list and transfer performance. (32 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: transfer-activated response sets in verbal rote learning tasks
Correspondence Address: Paul, C.

Title: The stimulus barrier and the autonomy of the ego
Authors with affiliations: Martin, R.M., U. Colorado Medical Center
Abstract: Examined the metaphoric form in which the stimulus barrier is expressed, the manner in which the concept is used, and its parallel to the concept of threshold to aid in understanding its significance. Observations of development relating to early forms of the stimulus barrier lead to a proposal of their functional similarity with later ego processes. The stimulus barrier functions of attention and concentration are examined in some detail and related to clinical phenomena. The implications of the stimulus barrier concept for the autonomy of the ego are developed and related to experimental work on perception and personality. (21 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: stimulus barrier concept & ego autonomy
Correspondence Address: Martin, R.M.; U. Colorado Medical Center

Title: Toward a theory of memory and attention
Affiliations: U. California, San Diego, United States
Authors with affiliations: Norman, D.A., U. California, San Diego, United States
Abstract: Describes a theoretical structure to account for a variety of phenomena encountered in the study of perception, attention, and memory. A storage system is proposed which has 2 different modes of activation: a temporary excitation (short-term or primary storage), and a permanent excitation (long-term or secondary storage). The storage is assumed to be organized so that access to stored information can be made directly from a sensory code. Thus, the initial interpretation of sensory events can be performed automatically, allowing attention to be directed to events on the basis of their meaning and momentary psychological pertinence. A retrieval process is described to handle the problem of deciding when an item that is recovered from storage is that which was sought. The output from storage is accepted as valid only if it can lead back naturally to the original query of memory. If it cannot, the retrieval process continues, using the initial query together with each intermediate output to guide the direction of search. (35 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: memory & perception & attention, theoretical model
Correspondence Address: Norman, D.A.; U. California, San Diego, United States

Title: A Rashevsky-Landahl neural net: Simulation of metacontrast
Authors with affiliations: Wiesstein, N., Loyola U., Chicago, United States
Abstract: Metacontrast, a type of visual masking which exhibits some special properties, has been difficult to explain by general theories of visual masking. A brief review of these theories and of types of masking shows that lateral inhibition may explain metacontrast, if it is assumed that inhibitory and excitatory processes develop at different rates. The specific lateral inhibition model used to make quantitative predictions is a neural network consisting of 5 2-factor neurons as developed by N. Rashevsky and H. D. Landahl. The idealization of neural response represented by these neurons is discussed. This model successfully predicts when monotonic and U shaped functions will be obtained in metacontrast interactions, and it predicts the reappearance of a masked target under conditions in which both target and mask are presented a number of times in succession. An extension of the model may account for paracontrast and other types of forward masking. Such a model promises to be quite generally applicable to temporal processing of visual stimuli. (55 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: metacontrast as lateral inhibition, neural network model

Title: Concerning imagery
Authors with affiliations: Hebb, D.O., McGill U., Montreal, Que., Canada
Abstract: Attempts to analyze imagery in physiological terms. It is proposed (1) that eye movement has an organizing function, (2) that 1st-order cell assemblies are the basis of vivid specific imagery, and (3) that higher-order assemblies are the basis of less specific imagery and nonrepresentational conceptual processes. Eidetic images, hallucinations, and hypnagogic imagery are compared with the memory image, and certain peculiarities of the memory image are discussed. (24 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.

Title: Stimulus coding in topographic and nontopographic afferent modalities: On the significance of the activity of individual sensory neurons
Abstract: Discusses 2 related problems in the neural handling of sensory information. The 1st is the meaning of the varieties of breadth of responsiveness, or differing levels of specificity, of individual afferent neurons; reasons are discussed why, for example, visual receptors and neurons are responsive to nearly the total visual spectrum, whereas tactile neurons respond to very limited proportions of the skin surface. The broadly tuned neurons constitute 1 class of afferent modality labeled nontopographic, the narrowly tuned neurons constituting the topographic modalities. 2nd, some common principles of encoding sensory stimuli in both classes of modalities are developed. (45 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: stimulus coding of afferent modalities & specificity of sensory neuron
Index Keywords: color vision; hearing; nerve cell; nerve conduction; peripheral nerve; physiology; review; sensation; sensory receptor; touch; vision; Color Perception; Hearing; Neural Conduction; Neurons; Peripheral Nerves; Receptors, Sensory; Sensation; Touch; Vision
Correspondence Address: Erickson, R.P.

Title: Constructing spatial images: A strategy in reasoning
Authors with affiliations: Huttenlocher, J., Teachers Coll., Columbia U
Abstract: Proposes an explanation of how undergraduates solve 3-term series problems (ordering syllogisms). Earlier work suggests that Ss invoke spatial images to represent the order of items. S's strategy for achieving such a representation of order is examined. S imagines items to be material objects which he must move about in space to correspond to the verbal descriptions given in the 2 premises. The mental operations involved in obtaining answers to these reasoning problems correspond to those involved in making actual spatial arrangements of real objects according to analogous types of verbal descriptions. The suggested strategy explains observed variations in difficulty of alternative forms of the problem. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: spatial images & resaoning strategy in 3-term series problems
Correspondence Address: Huttenlocher, J.

Title: Learning of generalized imitation as the basis for identification
Affiliations: National Inst. of Mental Health, Bethesda, Md, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gewirtz, J.L., National Inst. of Mental Health, Bethesda, Md, United States; Stingle, K.G.
Abstract: Deals 1st with generalized imitation, which is assumed to represent a functional response class containing a potentially unlimited number of instrumental responses, varied in content and matched to response-provided cues from 1 or more models, which is acquired through extrinsic reinforcement (by reinforcing agents) of some members of that response class and is subsequently maintained by intermittent extrinsic reinforcement. The matching-to-sample conditional discrimination-learning paradigm is presented as an analogy. In life settings, this discriminated-operant conception can account for cases of observational learning, and for the pervasiveness of generalized imitation, the focusing of it on 1 model, and its occurrence in situations where the model is absent or which there is no extrinsic reinforcement for imitation. This mechanism can also apply to imitation of more general attitudes or values, which may result in behaviors that are topographically quite different from the model's. The paper next examines the identification process by which a child is said to acquire the motives, values, and ideals of another (or others), and proposes the generalized-imitation paradigm, cued and reinforced by social stimuli, as a parsimonious basis for the phenomena usually grouped under identification. Fear or anxiety are not critical for identification under the model advanced. Dependence-attachment to the model is conceived to be relevant to imitation-identification only insofar as it is an abstraction that indexes the discriminative and reinforcing value for the child of stimuli d 216 233 250 250 250 296 362 382 40322052223imited theoretical relevance when both abstractions are reduced to issues of stimulus control over responses, as in the functional analysis presented. (54 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: learning of generalized imitation in identification, children

Title: Stimulus meaningfulness and paired-associate transfer: An encoding variability hypothesis
Abstract: The role of stimulus meaningfulness (M) in single-list and transfer situations and in proaction and retroaction paradigms is explicated with the help of an encoding-variability hypothesis, which states that analyzable nominal stimuli are variably encodable and hence may be perceived differently on different occasions. This means that in a single-list situation, paired-associate learning will appear to progress more slowly under the more variable functional stimulation of low M nominal stimuli. It also means that in a negative-transfer situation, the 2nd task involves recoding when stimuli are low M, but unlearning when stimuli are high M. New transfer data are presented as verification, and implications for proaction and retroaction are discussed. Throughout, a major role is assigned to stimulus recognition. (43 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: stimulus meaningfulness, paired associate transfer
Index Keywords: association; discrimination learning; human; information science; learning; memory; paired associate learning; review; technique; Association; Discrimination Learning; Human; Information Theory; Memory; Methods; Paired-Associate Learning; Probability Learning; Transfer (Psychology); Verbal Learning
Correspondence Address: Martin, E.

Title: Stimulus intensity and response evocation
Abstract: A decision model based on that of W. J. McGill relating stimulus intensity to response latency is applied to conditioning and RT data. Points of similarity and identity between this model, the Hull-Spence behavior theory, and the theory of signal detection are indicated. It is suggested that the concept of a variable, experimentally manipulable detection criterion or reaction threshold is a principle of considerable potential power in behavior theory. The difference between within- and between-S stimulus-intensity effects is deduced from the model. The effects of motivational, reinforcement, adaptation, and practice variables and their relations to stimulus intensity are analyzed. (18 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: reaction time, stimulus intensity
Index Keywords: adaptive behavior; human; instrumental conditioning; model; reaction time; review; technique; time; Adaptation, Psychological; Conditioning, Operant; Human; Methods; Models, Psychological; Reaction Time; Time Factors

Title: Shape of the conditioned eyelid response
Affiliations: Graylingwell Hosp., Clinical Psychiatry Research Unit, Chichester, Sussex England, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Levey, A.B., Graylingwell Hosp., Clinical Psychiatry Research Unit, Chichester, Sussex England, United Kingdom; Martin, I.
Abstract: The conventional frequency measure used in eyelid conditioning disregards the development of the CR over trials, its shape, and what it accomplishes in relation to the UCS and UCR. The paper considers how shaping of the response is achieved through the interaction of single response elements (latency, amplitude, etc.) and how their appropriate coordination places the CR in relation to specified end points such as successful avoidance. A model compatible with neurophysiological evidence is offered to account for the response-shaping process. (22 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.

Title: A small error in Thurstone's length-difficulty function
Authors with affiliations: Bogartz, W., U. Illinois, Chicago Circle
Abstract: Reveals Thurstone's square-root function relating length of a paired-associate list with trials to criterion as the result of a minor oversight. Length-difficulty relationships actually implied by Thurstone's learning theory are derived. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.

Title: An information-theoretic model for the serial position effect
Affiliations: Illinois State Psychiatric Inst., Chicago, United States
Authors with affiliations: Thomas, H.B., Illinois State Psychiatric Inst., Chicago, United States
Abstract: Develops a formal model for the serial position effect of rote learning. A function U'(pi,h) is derived by an information-theoretic argument from assumptions which are conveniently stated with reference to a geometric diagram. Estimating a parameter (h) from the data, a substantially linear relation is found between U'(pi,h) and the number, n(i), of recall failures at the position which lies a proportion pi of the way down the list. Good fit is obtained to typical serial position curves which vary considerably in skewness. Some work is reviewed which suggests that serial position effects are generated in the course of executing some cognitive operation, interposed between input and output and oriented with respect to a linear psychophysical dimension appropriate to the nature of the task. A "process" model is then proposed to account for the observed linear relation. It is assumed that 1 process (X) handles a quantity U'(pi,h) of information whenever it operates on the item or position at pi and in so doing, injects a proportionate amount of "noise" into a 2nd process (Y) responsible for retrieving the name of that item, so causing a proportionate number of recall failures. The possible nature of Process X is discussed. (21 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: information-theoretic model for serial position effect

Title: Interaction of behavioral and physiological stress reactions
Affiliations: Northeastern U, Boston, MA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Teichner, W.H., Northeastern U, Boston, MA, United States
Abstract: The study of stress is seen as an investigation of the interaction between physiological and behavioral compensatory reactions to physical and symbolic stressors. A conceptual approach is developed and an attempt made to integrate the effects of informational overloads, emotion-provoking stimuli, and the effects of the physical environment into one psychophysiological context. This is done by postulating interregulatory controls among activating mechanisms and data-processing mechanisms with corresponding changes in the strength and direction of physiological and behavioral reactions. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.

Title: THE ORIENTING REFLEX AND ATTENTION IN COGNITIVE DEVELOPMENT
Authors with affiliations: JEFFREY, W.E., U. CALIFORNIA, LOS ANGELES
Abstract: CERTAIN CHANGES IN STIMULATION PRODUCE A PATTERN OF PHYSIOLOGICAL RESPONSES (ORIENTING REFLEX) THAT IS PRESUMED TO SHARPEN PERCEPTION THROUGH FOCUSING ATTENTION ON SALIENT CUES. WHEN THE ORIENTING REFLEX HABITUATES TO A PARTICULAR CUE OF A COMPLEX STIMULUS, A 2ND AND PREVIOUSLY LESS SALIENT CUE MAY NOW ELICIT AN ORIENTING REFLEX AND ATTENTION WILL THEN BECOME SELECTIVE FOR THAT CUE. GIVEN CERTAIN CONDITIONS, SERIAL HABITUATION OF THE ORIENTING REFLEX TO SEVERAL CUES OF A STIMULUS COMPLEX WILL PRODUCE A CHAIN OF ATTENDING RESPONSES. WITH REPEATED PRESENTATION OF THE STIMULUS COMPLEX, THIS CHAIN WILL BECOME A SINGLE WELL-INTEGRATED MEDIATING EVENT (SCHEMA) THAT MAY BE USED TO EXPLAIN HIGHER-LEVEL PROBLEM-SOLVING BEHAVIORS. Title: VIGILANCE, AROUSAL, AND HABITUATION
Authors with affiliations: MACKWORTH, J.F., RADCLIFFE INST., CAMBRIDGE, MASS
Abstract: DISCUSSES DECREMENTS IN PERFORMANCE IN VIGILANCE TASKS IN TERMS OF HABITUATION OF THE NEURAL RESPONSES TO THE BACKGROUND EVENTS OF THE TASKS. HABITUATION OF THE AROUSAL RESPONSE LEADS TO AN INCREASE IN VARIANCE AND AMPLITUDE OF THE SPONTANEOUS NEURAL RHYTHMS; THIS INCREASE IN NEURAL NOISE MAY RESULT IN A DECREASE IN SENSITIVITY TO THE SIGNAL EVENTS. HABITUATION OF THE EVOKED RESPONSES TO BOTH SIGNAL AND NONSIGNAL EVENTS OF THE TASK PRODUCES A DECREASE IN AMPLITUDE AND INCREASE IN LATENCY OF THE EVOKED RESPONSE, WHICH MAY CAUSE THE DECREASES IN CORRECT AND FALSE DETECTIONS FOUND IN MANY VIGILANCE TASKS. SENSITIVITY MAY INCREASE AS THE NEURAL EVOKED RESPONSE TO THE NONSIGNAL EVENTS DECREASES, THUS COUNTERACTING THE EFFECT OF THE DECREASE IN THE AROUSAL RESPONSE. (3 P. REF.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: VIGILANCE & HABITUATION & AROUSAL, NEURAL RESPONSES

Title: STIMULUS CONTROL AND SPREADING CORTICAL DEPRESSION: SOME PROBLEMS RECONSIDERED
Abstract: L. R. SQUIRE AND P. H. LISS (SEE 42:9) RAISE 4 CRITICISMS OF THE STIMULUS-CONTROL INTERPRETATION OF THE SPREADING DEPRESSION PHENOMENON. 3 OF THE POINTS THAT THEY CHALLENGE ARE DEFENDED ON THE BASIS OF DATA AND STATEMENTS PRESENTED BY SCHNEIDER. THE 4TH CRITICISM, THAT THE STIMULUS-CONTROL THEORY FAILS TO ACCOUNT FOR THE AMNESIC EFFECTS OF POSTTRANSFER DEPRESSION, WHEN ANALYZED ON BOTH EMPIRICAL AND LOGICAL GROUNDS, IS NOT JUSTIFIED. HOWEVER, SOME QUESTIONS REMAIN AND SUGGESTIONS ARE OFFERED FOR FUTURE RESEARCH THAT WOULD FURTHER RESOLVE THE COMPLEXITIES OF THIS LATTER ISSUE. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: STIMULUS CONTROL THEORY OF SPREADING CORTICAL DEPRESSION

Title: FINITE INTEGER MODELS FOR LEARNING IN INDIVIDUAL SUBJECTS
Abstract: PROPOSES A CLASS OF INHOMOGENEOUS MARKOV MODELS AS A DESCRIPTION OF THE LEARNING PROCESS. THE MODELS ARE MATHEMATICALLY TRACTABLE AS IT IS EASY TO OBTAIN LIKELIHOOD FUNCTIONS AND MAXIMUM LIKELIHOOD PARAMETER ESTIMATES. THE MODELS PERMIT THE ANALYSIS OF THE SEQUENCE OF RESPONSES MADE BY AN INDIVIDUAL S IN ANY SITUATION IN WHICH S EMITS A RELATIVELY LONG SEQUENCE OF RESPONSES WHICH CAN BE CATEGORIZED INTO 2 MUTUALLY EXCLUSIVE CLASSES. FOR AN M-STATE MODEL, EACH RESPONSE SEQUENCE IS DIVIDED INTO M SEGMENTS CORRESPONDING TO UNDERLYING STATES OF RESPONSIVENESS. INTEGERS CORRESPONDING TO THE TRIALS ON WHICH TRANSITIONS WERE MADE FROM 1 STATE TO ANOTHER ARE SELECTED SUCH THAT THE LIKELIHOOD OF OBTAINING S'S EXACT SEQUENCE OF RESPONSES IS MAXIMIZED. LIKELIHOOD RATIO TESTS BETWEEN SOME PSYCHOLOGICALLY INTERESTING GENERAL AND RESTRICTED MODELS ARE DISCUSSED. SOME IMPLICATIONS OF FINITE INTEGER MODELS ARE OUTLINED FOR A NUMBER OF STANDARD LEARNING SITUATIONS. THE RELATIONSHIP OF FINITE INTEGER MODELS TO THE CONTINUITY-NONCONTINUITY QUESTION IN LEARNING IS DISCUSSED. (22 REF.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: FINITE INTEGER MODEL FOR INDIVIDUAL SS

Title: WHAT GIVES RISE TO THE PERCEPTION OF MOTION?
Abstract: REJECTS THE ASSUMPTION THAT DISPLACEMENT OF THE RETINAL IMAGE OVER THE RETINA IS THE BASIS FOR ALL PERCEPTION OF MOTION AS IT IS BASED ON A MISCONCEPTION ABOUT THE WAY EYES WORK. ANOTHER THEORY OF THE INFORMATION FOR PERCEIVING MOTION IS PROPOSED IN TERMS OF THE AMBIENT ARRAY OF LIGHT. THE REGISTERING OF SUBJECTIVE BODILY MOVEMENTS BY VISION IS CONTRASTED WITH THE DETECTING OF OBJECTIVE ENVIRONMENTAL MOTIONS. A NUMBER OF CENTURY-OLD PUZZLES ARE RESOLVED BY THIS APPROACH AND A SET OF NOVEL EXPERIMENTS IS SUGGESTED. (20 REF.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: BASIS/SUBJECTIVE & OBJECTIVE

Title: CONTROL OF MEMORY BY SPREADING CORTICAL DEPRESSION: A CRITIQUE OF STIMULUS CONTROL
Authors with affiliations: SQUIRE, L.R., MASSACHUSETTS INST. OF TECHNOLOGY; LISS, P.H.
Abstract: MANY INVESTIGATORS HAVE FOUND THAT MEMORY FOR A TASK TRAINED DURING UNILATERAL SPREADING DEPRESSION (USD) IS UNAVAILABLE TO THE ANIMAL IF IT IS LATER TESTED WITH SPREADING DEPRESSION OF THE OPPOSITE SIDE. HOWEVER, IF BETWEEN TRAINING AND TEST SESSION AN ANIMAL IS GIVEN 1 TRIAL WITH NEITHER HEMISPHERE DEPRESSED, GOOD RETENTION IS OBSERVED. A. M. SCHNEIDER (SEE 41:7) HAS INTERPRETED THIS IN TERMS OF A STIMULUS CONTROL AND STIMULUS GENERALIZATION HYPOTHESIS. THIS EXPLANATION OF THE 1-TRIAL TRANSFER PHENOMENON IS EXAMINED AND FOUND UNSATISFACTORY BECAUSE: (1) THE STIMULUS CONTROL THEORY REQUIRES THE NONDEPRESSED STATE TO BE MORE SIMILAR TO THE USD AND CONTRALATERAL USD STATES THAN TO EACH OTHER. THE EVIDENCE FOR THIS SIMILARITY CONTINUUM IS UNCONVINCING. (2) SCHNEIDER INVOKES A DIFFERENT SIMILARITY CONTINUUM TO ACCOUNT FOR THE RESULTS OF SCHNEIDER AND KAY, AND FAILS TO SUPPLY RULES SPECIFYING WHICH CONTINUUM SHOULD APPLY IN ANY GIVEN CASE. (3) THE STIMULUS CONTROL THEORY INCORRECTLY PREDICTS THAT MAXIMUM TRANSFER SHOULD OCCUR WITHOUT A NONDEPRESSED TRANSFER TRIAL. (4) THE STIMULUS CONTROL THEORY CANNOT EXPLAIN THE EFFECTS OF POSTTRANSFER TRIAL USD ON RETENTION. (17 REF.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved).

Authors: Broverman D.M., Klaiber E.L., Kobayahi Y.
Title: "Roles of activation and inhibition in sex differences in cognitive abilities": Erratum
Authors with affiliations: Broverman, D.M.; Klaiber, E.L.; Kobayahi, Y.
Abstract: Reports an error in the original article by Broverman, Klaiber, Kobayashi, and Vogel (Psychological Review, 1968[75], Vol 1, 23-50). On page 37, the first sentence of the second paragraph in the second column should read: "Convulsability varies in female rats with the estrous cycle, reaching a peak at time of estrus (Woolley & Timiras, 1962a)." (The following abstract of this article originally appeared in record 1968-05055-001.) Hypothesizes that known sex differences in cognitive abilities reflect sex related differences in physiology. Females surpass males on simple, overlearned, perceptual-motor tasks. Males excel on more complex tasks requiring an inhibition of immediate responses to obvious stimulus attributes in favor of responses to less obvious stimulus attributes. It is hypothesized that these sex differences reflect differences in relationships between adrenergic activating and cholinergic inhibitory neural processes, which, in turn, are sensitive to the sex hormones, androgens and estrogens. Studies of the effects of drug and hormone administrations on these behaviors, and of sex hormones on adrenergic and cholinergic neurotransmitters are examined. Implications for crosssectional correlative analyses of cognitive organization are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: andrenergic & cholinergic neural processes; androgens; cognition; estrogens

Title: AN OBSERVING RESPONSE ANALYSIS OF VISUAL SEARCH
Abstract: AN ASSUMPTION IS MADE THAT THE PERCEPTUAL PROCESS INVOLVED IN SCANNING OR SEARCH ARE SIMILAR TO THOSE POSTULATED IN OBSERVING RESPONSE (OR) MODELS OF DISCRIMINATION LEARNING. A MODEL OF VISUAL SEARCH IS PRESENTED WHICH TREATS SCANNING BEHAVIOR AS A SEQUENCE OF DISCRETE ORS. THE BASIC MODEL IS STOCHASTIC, AND THE SEQUENCE OF ORS IS REPRESETNED BY AN ABSORBING MARKOV CHAIN WHERE THE ABSORBING STATE IS TARGET LOCATION. THE MODEL IS CAPABLE OF DESCRIBING SEARCH TIMES FOR: (1) DISPLAYS OF VARYING DENSITIES, (2) SEARCH DISPLAYS WITH MULTIPLE CUES IN A NONTARGET DIMENSION, AND (3) SEARCH TASKS WITH COMPOUND CUES. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: MODEL OF VISUAL SEARCH, SCANNING BEHAVIOR AS OBSERVING RESPONSE IN DISCRIMINATION

Title: A NOTE ON VISUAL LATENCY
Abstract: THE CHANGES IN THE TIME CONSTANT OF A MODEL OF RETINAL ADAPTATION AS THE PREVAILING LIGHT LEVEL IS CHANGED ARE USED TO DEVELOP A THEORY OF THE DIFFERENCES IN VISUAL LATENCY WITH DIFFERENCES IN INTENSITY MEASURED WITH THE PULFRICH STEREOPHENOMENON. IT IS ASSUMED THAT THE TIME CONSTANT AT ANY LEVEL OF RETINAL ILLUMINANCE IS IDENTICAL FOR THE 2 EYES. THE THEORY IS A SATISFACTORY DESCRIPTION OF THE RESULTS, PROVIDED THE NUMBER OF STAGES IN THE AUTOMATIC VOLUME CONTROL MODEL IS LIMITED TO ABOUT 4. THE TREATMENT THEN YIELDS A RELATION BETWEEN VISUAL LATENCY AND INTENSITY RATHER THAN MERELY BETWEEN THEIR RESPECTIVE DIFFERENCES. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.

Title: ELECTROPHYSIOLOGICAL STUDIES OF DREAMING AS THE PROTOTYPE OF A NEW STRATEGY IN THE STUDY OF CONSCIOUSNESS
Authors with affiliations: STOYVA, J., U. COLORADO MEDICAL CENTER, DENVER; KAMIYA, J.
Abstract: ARGUES THAT THE COMBINED USE OF PHYSIOLOGICAL MEASURES AND VERBAL REPORT, AS IN THE REM STUDIES OF DREAMING, REPRESENTS A NEW STRATEGY IN THE STUDY OF PRIVATE EVENTS. ELECTROPHYSIOLOGICAL STUDIES OF DREAMING AS AN INSTANCE OF CONVERGING OPERATIONS SERVE TO VALIDATE A HYPOTHETICAL MENTAL STATE. A REDEFINITION OF DREAMING AS A HYPOTHETICAL CONSTRUCT IS SUGGESTED. THE POSSIBLE WAYS OF RELATING VERBAL REPORTS OF DREAMING, THE REM MEASURE, AND THE HYPOTHETICAL DREAM EXPERIENCE ARE VIEWED WITHIN A SYSTEMATIC FRAMEWORK. THAT THE NEW STRATEGY-COMBINED USE OF VERBAL REPORT AND PHYSIOLOGICAL MEASURES-NEED NOT BE CONFINED TO DREAMING IS SUGGESTED BY THE EXPERIMENTS ON LEARNED CONTROL OF THE EEG ALPHA RHYTHM. HERE, THE USE OF INFORMATION FEEDBACK PROCEDURES TEACHES S TO CONTROL THE PHYSIOLOGICAL RESPONSE AND, APPARENTLY, THE ASSOCIATED MENTAL STATE AS WELL. (43 REF.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.

Authors: DUNHAM J.L., GUILFORD J.P., HOEPFNER R.
Title: MULTIVARIATE APPROACHES TO DISCOVERING THE INTELLECTUAL COMPONENTS OF CONCEPT LEARNING
Authors with affiliations: DUNHAM, J.L., U. TEXAS; GUILFORD, J.P.; HOEPFNER, R.
Abstract: EXAMINES PROBLEMS IN CONNECTION WITH CONCEPT LEARNING, PROPOSING AND ILLUSTRATING STEPS REPRESENTING IMPROVEMENTS OVER PREVIOUS ATTEMPTS. IT ADVOCATES THAT A FACTORIAL REFERENCE FRAME BE INDEPENDENTLY ESTABLISHED, WITH LEARNING SCORES REPRESENTED BY VECTORS LOCATED WITHIN THE FRAME BY EXTENSION PROCEDURES. IT IS PROPOSED THAT CONCEPT-LEARNING IS A PROBLEM SOLVING AFFAIR WITH COMPLEX FACTOR COMPOSITION THAT SHIFTS AS LEARNING PROCEEDS, AND THAT A COMPREHENSIVE THEORY REGARDING CONCEPT LEARNING CAN BE CONSTRUCTED ON THE BASIS OF RESULTS BY THIS APPROACH. (22 REF.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: CONCEPT LEARNING, FACTOR ANALYSIS AS BASIS OF COMPREHENSIVE THEORY

Title: CONTRIBUTIONS OF LEARNING TO HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
Abstract: CRITICALLY CONSIDERS MODELS OF HUMAN INTELLECTUAL DEVELOPMENT. 2 COMMONLY CONTRASTED MODELS ARE GROWTH READINESS, ASSOCIATED WITH THE WRITINGS OF HALL AND GESELL, AND COGNITIVE ADAPTATION, DEVELOPED BY PIAGET. A 3RD MODEL, CUMULATIVE LEARNING, IS DISCUSSED. APPLICATIONS OF THIS MODEL INCLUDING AN ANALYSIS OF THE CONSERVATION OF LIQUID VOLUME AS A LEARNED CAPABILITY OF YOUNG CHILDREN ARE NOTED. IMPLICATIONS OF THE CUMULATIVE LEARNING MODEL FOR TRANSFER OF LEARNING ARE DESCRIBED. (26 REF.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.

Title: ORGANIZATION OF ABILITIES AND THE DEVELOPMENT OF INTELLIGENCE
Abstract: PERFORMANCES WHICH INDICATE INTELLIGENCE ARE INTERRELATED TO PRODUCE 2 BROAD FACTORS, EACH REPRESENTING A KIND OF INTELLIGENCE. THE 1ST, CRYSTALLIZED INTELLIGENCE, INDICATES THE EXTENT OF ACCULTURATION AS IT DETERMINES HUMAN ABILITIES. THE OTHER, FLUID INTELLIGENCE, INDICATES A PATTERN OF NEURALPHYSIOLOGICAL AND INCIDENTAL LEARNING INFLUENCES. THE 2 BECOME INDEPENDENT AS DEVELOPMENT PROCEEDS FROM INFANCY TO ADULTHOOD. MEASURES OF FLUID INTELLIGENCE ARE MORE SENSITIVE INDICATORS OF BRAIN MALFUNCTION; FLUID INTELLIGENCE DECLINES WITH BRAIN DAMAGE AND AGING IN ADULTHOOD. PERFORMANCES ON ABILITY TESTS INVOLVE PROCESSES OTHER THAN INTELLIGENCE. THESE ARE ASSOCIATED WITH SENSORY MODALITY FUNCTIONS, PERHAPS INDICATE ENDOCRINE FUNCTIONS (IN SPEEDINESS), REPRESENT STRATEGIES OR STYLES OF PERFORMANCE, AND RELATE TO MOTIVATION. RESULTS IN SUPPORT OF THE THEORY ARE PRESENTED AND EVALUATED. (74 REF.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: ORGANIZATION OF ABILITIES & DEVELOPMENT OF INTELLIGENCE

Title: EVALUATION AND PREFERENCE IN BEHAVIORAL DEVELOPMENT
Abstract: CONCERNED WITH THE ROLE OF AFFECTIVE AROUSALS IN THE DEVELOPMENT OF EVALUATIVE DISPOSITIONS. CURRENT AND PREVIOUS EXPERIMENTS ARE REVIEWED TO EXPLAIN INCOMPATIBLE RESULTS OBTAINED WITH DIFFERENT METHODS OF TESTING FOOD PREFERENCES. THE PSYCHOPHYSICAL AND PHYSIOLOGICAL METHODS IMPLY THAT AFFECTIVE AROUSALS ARE CONTEMPORARY DYNAMIC EVENTS BUT ARE ALSO REINFORCERS AND DETERMINANTS OF BEHAVIORAL DEVELOPMENT. EVIDENCE SHOWS THAT REINFORCEMENTS FROM THE ORAL CAVITY AND FROM INTRAORGANIC REGIONS CAN PRODUCE INCOMPATIBLE SELECTIONS OF FOODSTUFF. HEDONIC THEORY IS EXTENDED TO INCLUDE INTRAORGANIC REINFORCEMENTS. IT IS ASSUMED THAT EVALUATIVE DISPOSITIONS ARE ORGANIZED, REGISTERED, AND RETAINED IN THE CEREBRUM AND THAT ACQUIRED DISPOSITIONS CAN BECOME INDEPENDENT DETERMINANTS OF BEHAVIOR AND CHOICE. (57 REF.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.

Title: TRAIT-VIEW THEORY OF PERTURBATIONS IN RATINGS AND SELF RATINGS (L(BR)- AND Q-DATA): ITS APPLICATION TO OBTAINING PURE TRAIT SCORE ESTIMATES IN QUESTIONNAIRES
Abstract: TRAIT-VIEW THEORY, A SECTION OF PERTURBATION THEORY CONCERNED WITH VIEWER AND VIEWED IN RATINGS AND QUESTIONNAIRES, AIMS TO COMPREHEND WHAT IS NOW HANDLED UNDER AD HOC CONCEPTS OF RESPONSE SET, SOCIAL DESIRABILITY, MULTIMETHOD SCORING, ETC. THE MODEL MAKES THE DISTORTION IN ANY TRAIT ASSESSMENT, BY RATING OR QUESTIONNAIRE, A FUNCTION OF THE SITUATION, THE BACKGROUND OF TRAITS IN S, AND THE TRAITS OF THE O. IT IS SHOWN THAT BY SUITABLE FACTOR ANALYTIC TREATMENT A TRUE TRAIT ESTIMATE CAN BE MADE IN EACH CASE. (2 P. REF.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
