Title: AN ANALYSIS OF THE CONCEPT OF REINFORCEMENT
Abstract: IT IS NOTED THAT THE TERM REINFORCER IS APPLIED TO 2 QUITE DIFFERENT CONCEPTS. THE 1ST IS ANY STIMULUS SITUATION WHICH STRENGTHENS THE TENDENCY FOR THOSE RESPONSES WHICH IT FOLLOWS TO RECUR; THE 2ND, WHICH IS DESIGNATED ATTRACTIVENESS, DETERMINES ASYMPTOTIC CHOICE. THE HYPOTHESIS THAT ALL BEHAVIOR CHANGE IS BEST DESCRIBED AS TRANSMISSION OF DIFFERENTIAL ATTRACTIVENESS TO ANTECEDENT STIMULUS SITUATIONS IS FORMULATED. SECONDARY HYPOTHESES ARE SUGGESTED AND THE VIEWPOINT IS APPLIED TO EXTINCTION OF AVOIDANCE RESPONSES, DEVELOPING A SCALE OF RESPONSE STRENGTH, DELAY OF REWARD AND PUNISHMENT, AND RATE OF ACQUISTION. (2P.REF.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.

Title: SHIFTS IN MAGNITUDE OF REWARD AND CONTRAST EFFECTS IN INSTRUMENTAL AND SELECTIVE LEARNING: A REINTERPRETATION
Abstract: STUDIES INVOLVING SHIFTS IN MAGNITUDE OF REWARD IN APPETITIVE LEARNING ARE REVIEWED WITH RESPECT TO THE OCCURRENCE OR NONOCCURRENCE OF SO-CALLED CONTRAST EFFECTS (CE). SUCH STUDIES HAVE TYPICALLY INVESTIGATED SUCCESSIVE CE IN INSTRUMENTAL CONDITIONING OR SIMULTANEOUS CE IN DIFFERENTIAL CONDITIONING AND SELECTIVE LEARNING. IN BOTH CASES, THE USUAL RESULT HAS BEEN THE OCCURRENCE OF NEGATIVE CE IN THE ABSENCE OF POSITIVE CE. CURRENT INTERPRETATIONS OF SHIFTS IN REWARD MAGNITUDE ARE EXAMINED AND APPEAR TO BE INADEQUATE TO ACCOUNT FOR THESE DATA. AN ALTERNATIVE INTERPRETATION IS SUGGESTED. ORIGINAL DATA SUPPORTING THE IMPLICATIONS OF THIS INTERPRETATION WITH RESPECT TO SHIFTS OF DELAY OF REWARD AND PERCENTAGE OF REINFORCEMENT ARE ALSO REPORTED. (2 P. REF.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.

Title: AN ATTEMPTED CLARIFICATION OF FRUSTRATION THEORY
Abstract: CURRENT FRUSTRATION THEORY APPEARS TO INVOLVE AMBIGUITIES ON 3 ISSUES: THE FRUSTRATING EFFECTS OF A NEGATIVE DISCRIMINATIVE STIMULUS, THE GENERALIZATION OF APPROACH TENDENCIES CONDITIONED TO RESPONSE FRUSTRATION, AND THE EXPLANATION OF THE ACQUISITION PARTIAL REINFORCEMENT EFFECT. SUGGESTIONS ARE MADE FOR RESTATING CERTAIN ASSUMPTIONS OF FRUSTRATION THEORY IN ORDER TO DEAL MORE CLEARLY WITH THESE TOPICS. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: THEORY, CLARIFICATION

Authors: BEALS R., KRANTZ D.H., TVERSKY A.
Title: FOUNDATIONS OF MULTIDIMENSIONAL SCALING
Authors with affiliations: BEALS, R., U. CHICAGO; KRANTZ, D.H.; TVERSKY, A.
Abstract: ANALYZES MULTIDIMENSIONAL SCALING FROM THE STANDPOINT OF MEASUREMENT THEORY. THE QUALITATIVE PROPERTIES THAT MUST BE SATISFIED IF AN ORDERING OF DISSIMILARITIES IS TO BE REPRESENTABLE BY AN ORDERING OF DISTANCES IN ANY 1 OF A WIDE VARIETY (EUCLIDEAN, ETC.) OF DISTANCE GEOMETRIES ARE EXHIBITED AND DISCUSSED. IN THE CURRENT PRACTICE OF MULTIDIMENSIONAL SCALING, THE REPRESENTABILITY OF STIMULI BY SPECIFIC TYPES OF DISTANCE GEOMETRY IS RARELY QUESTIONED. THE COMPUTATIONAL METHODS IN USE GIVE A "BEST" ANSWER, REGARDLESS OF WHETHER THE UNDERLYING MODEL IS APPROPRIATE. IN CONTRAST, GEOMETRIC REPRESENTATIONS ARE HERE REGARDED AS A FORM OF QUANTITATIVE THEORY. THOSE PROPERTIES OF ORDINAL DATA THAT MAKE A GIVEN MODEL APPROPRIATE, THE PSYCHOLOGICAL MEANING OF THOSE PROPERTIES, AND THE STRUCTURE OF CRITICAL EXPERIMENTS THAT TEST THEM ARE STUDIED. (24 REF.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: MULTIDIMENSIONAL SCALING, MEASUREMENT THEORY ANALYSIS

Title: PIAGET'S THEORY OF KNOWLEDGE: THE NATURE OF REPRESENTATION AND INTERIORIZATION
Authors with affiliations: FURTH, H.G., CATHOLIC U. OF AMERICA
Abstract: PRESENTS A SHORT HISTORICAL SURVEY OF THE NOTION OF REPRESENTATION IN PHILOSOPHICAL THEORIES OF KNOWLEDGE. IT IS POINTED OUT THAT THE MANNER IN WHICH CONTEMPORARY SCIENTIFIC THEORIZING TYPICALLY USES THE CONCEPT OF MEDIATING REPRESENTATION HAS DEEP AND OFTEN UNANALYZED PHILOSOPHICAL ROOTS. FOR PIAGET THE OPERATIVE PROCESS BY WHICH WE CONSTRUCT REALITY-AS-KNOWN AND THE SYMBOLIC PROCESS BY WHICH WE RE-PRESENT KNOWN REALITY ARE FUNCTIONALLY DIFFERENT AND POSSESS A DIFFERENT REALITY STATUS. A CORRESPONDING DISTINCTION IS PROPOSED FOR PIAGET'S TERM "INTERIORISER": WHILE SYMBOLS DERIVE FROM A REAL INTERNALIZATION OF ACCOMMODATED EXTERNAL ACTIONS, THE FUNCTIONAL INTERIORIZATION OF OPERATIONS REFERS TO THE INCREASING DISSOCIATION BETWEEN GENERAL FORM AND PARTICULAR CONTENT, NOT TO SOMETHING THAT WAS 1ST OVERT AND THEN BECOMES COVERT. IN CONTRAST TO CURRENT REPRESENTATIONAL THEORIES OF KNOWLEDGE, PIAGET'S MODEL IS UNIQUE IN INCORPORATING THE 3 COMPETING AND OFTEN CONFUSED MEANINGS ATTACHED TO THE WORD REPRESENTATION. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.

Title: A REINTERPRETATION OF THE DIRECTION OF EFFECTS IN STUDIES OF SOCIALIZATION
Affiliations: NATIONAL INST., MENTAL HEALTH, CHILD RESEARCH BRANCH, BETHESDA, MD, United States
Authors with affiliations: BELL, R.Q., NATIONAL INST., MENTAL HEALTH, CHILD RESEARCH BRANCH, BETHESDA, MD, United States
Abstract: STUDIES ARE SUMMARIZED INDICATING THAT THE BASIC MODEL OF SOCIALIZATION, THE ACTION OF A PARENT ON A CHILD, IS TOO LIMITED TO ACCOMODATE DATA EMERGING FROM RECENT STUDIES OF HUMAN AND ANIMAL SS. A SET OF PROPOSITIONS IS PRESENTED CONCERNING THE EFFECTS OF CONGENITAL FACTORS IN CHILDREN ON PARENT BEHAVIOR. THIS SYSTEM IS APPLIED TO CURRENT FINDINGS IN SEVERAL MAJOR AREAS. CURRENT LITERATURE ON SOCIALIZATION, BASED LARGELY ON CORRELATIONS BETWEEN PARENT AND CHILD BEHAVIOR, CAN BE REINTERPRETED PLAUSIBLY AS INDICATING EFFECTS OF CHILDREN ON PARENTS. A CORRELATION DOES NOT INDICATE DIRECTION OF EFFECT. IT IS FELT THAT THE EFFECT OF CHILDREN ON PARENTS CAN NO LONGER BE DISMISSED AS ONLY A LOGICAL BUT IMPLAUSIBLE ALTERNATIVE EXPLANATION OF A CORRELATION. (2 P. REF.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.

Title: THE TWO-AROUSAL HYPOTHESIS: RETICULAR FORMATION AND LIMBIC SYSTEM
Abstract: POSTULATES THAT THERE ARE 2 MAJOR SYSTEMS IN THE BRAIN THAT MAINTAIN THE ONGOING BEHAVIOR OF THE VERTEBRATE ORGANISM. AROUSAL SYSTEM I IS RELATED TO THE RETICULAR ACTIVATING SYSTEM. IT MAINTAINS THE AROUSAL OF THE ORGANISM, AND PROVIDES THE ORGANIZATION FOR RESPONSES. AROUSAL SYSTEM II IS RELATED TO THE LIMBIC SYSTEM, AND PROVIDES CONTROL OF RESPONSES THROUGH INCENTIVE RELATED STIMULI. THE ORGANIZATION OF THESE 2 MECHANISMS IS POSTULATED TO BE MUTUALLY INHIBITORY. IT IS SHOWN HOW SUCH AN ORGANIZATION IS OF VALUE IN UNDERSTANDING REINFORCEMENT AS PART OF A RECIPROCAL RELATION BETWEEN DRIVE (I) AND INCENTIVE (II). MEMORY IS VIEWED AS A CONSEQUENCE OF THIS RECIPROCITY. (6 P. REF.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: RETICULAR FORMATION & LIMBIC SYSTEM, DRIVE & INCENTIVE, AROUSAL

Title: NEUROPSYCHOLOGICAL INTERPRETATION OF THE EFFECTS OF DRIVE AND INCENTIVE-MOTIVATION ON GENERAL ACTIVITY AND INSTRUMENTAL BEHAVIOR
Affiliations: MCGILL U., MONTREAL, QUEBEC, CANADA, Canada
Authors with affiliations: BINDRA, D., MCGILL U., MONTREAL, QUEBEC, CANADA, Canada
Abstract: EXPERIMENTS THAT SEPARATE THE EFFECTS OF DRIVE FROM THOSE OF INCENTIVE-MOTIVATIONAL (REINFORCEMENT LINKED) STIMULI INDICATE THAT, WHILE CERTAIN DRIVES CAN RAISE THE LEVEL OF GENERAL ACTIVITY AND FACILITATE THE OCCURRENCE OF PARTICULAR CONSUMMATORY RESPONSES, DRIVE FACILITATION OF INSTRUMENTAL BEHAVIOR RESULTS NOT FROM DRIVE PER SE, BUT FROM AN INCREASE IN THE EFFICACY OF INCENTIVE-MOTIVATIONAL STIMULI. OTHER STUDIES SUGGEST THAT THE MECHANISM BY WHICH INCENTIVE-MOTIVATIONAL STIMULI INFLUENCE BEHAVIOR IS NOT THE INSTRUMENTAL CONDITIONING OF SPECIFIC RESPONSES OR OF ANTICIPATORY GOAL REACTIONS, BUT THE CLASSICAL CONDITIONING OF A CENTRAL STATE TO THE STIMULI. THESE CONCLUSIONS ARE INTERPRETED IN TERMS OF A MODEL OF MOTIVATIONAL EFFECTS CONSISTING OF 4 HYPOTHETICAL FUNCTIONS WHICH ARE ASSUMED TO (1) ACTIVATE CONSUMATORY ACTION SITES (DRIVE-REINFORCEMENT), (2) FACILITATE RELEVANT SENSORY INPUT (ATTENTION), (3) CREATE A CENTRAL STATE OF SOME GENERALITY (INCENTIVE-MOTIVATION), AND (4) ENHANCE MOTOR READINESS (AROUSAL). SOME IMPLICATIONS OF THE MODEL ARE DISCUSSED. (4 P. REF.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: & INCENTIVE-MOTIVATION, ACTIVITY & INSTRUMENTAL BEHAVIOR
Correspondence Address: BINDRA, D.

Authors: BROVERMAN D.M., KLAIBER E.L., KOBAYASHI Y.
Title: ROLES OF ACTIVATION AND INHIBITION IN SEX DIFFERENCES IN COGNITIVE ABILITIES
Authors with affiliations: BROVERMAN, D.M., CLARK U; KLAIBER, E.L.; KOBAYASHI, Y.
Abstract: HYPOTHESIZES THAT KNOWN SEX DIFFERENCES IN COGNITIVE ABILITIES REFLECT SEX RELATED DIFFERENCES IN PHYSIOLOGY. FEMALES SURPASS MALES ON SIMPLE, OVERLEARNED, PERCEPTUAL-MOTOR TASKS. MALES EXCEL ON MORE COMPLEX TASKS REQUIRING AN INHIBITION OF IMMEDIATE RESPONSES TO OBVIOUS STIMULUS ATTRIBUTES IN FAVOR OF RESPONSES TO LESS OBVIOUS STIMULUS ATTRIBUTES. IT IS HYPOTHESIZED THAT THESE SEX DIFFERENCES REFLECT DIFFERENCES IN RELATIONSHIPS BETWEEN ADRENERGIC ACTIVATING AND CHOLINERGIC INHIBITORY NEURAL PROCESSES, WHICH, IN TURN, ARE SENSITIVE TO THE SEX HORMONES, ANDROGENS AND ESTROGENS. STUDIES OF THE EFFECTS OF DRUG AND HORMONE ADMINISTRATIONS ON THESE BEHAVIORS, AND OF SEX HORMONES ON ADRENERGIC AND CHOLINERGIC NEUROTRANSMITTERS ARE EXAMINED. IMPLICATIONS FOR CROSSSECTIONAL CORRELATIVE ANALYSES OF COGNITIVE ORGANIZATION ARE DISCUSSED. (6 P. REF.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: COGNITION, ANDROGENS & ESTROGENS, ADRENERGIC & CHOLINERGIC NEURAL PROCESSES
Correspondence Address: BROVERMAN, D.M.

Title: REPLY TO JUDSON MILLS
Abstract: IF THE INTERPERSONAL REPLICATIONS REPORTED BY BEM (SEE 41:7) AND CRITICIZED BY MILLS (SEE 42:1) ARE TO BE FAITHFUL TO THEIR THEORETICAL GOAL OF TESTING THE HYPOTHESIZED FUNCTIONAL SIMILARITY BETWEEN INTERPERSONAL AND SELF-PERCEPTION, THEN THOSE REPLICATIONS MUST REPRODUCE THE ORIGINAL EXPERIMENTAL SITUATION AS SEEN BY THE ORIGINAL SS, NOT AS SEEN BY THE E. INTERPERSONAL OS REPRODUCE THE FUNCTIONAL RELATIONS FOUND IN COGNITIVE DISSONANCE STUDIES; THEIR TASK IS NOT TO PREDICT ATTITUDE CHANGES WHICH ARE A PSYCHOLOGICAL REALITY ONLY FOR THE E WHO CAN COMPARE SS' RATINGS WITH THOSE OF CONTROLS. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved).
Author Keywords: FESTINGER-CARLSMITH COGNITIVE DISSONANCE, INTERPRETATION BY BEM, REPLY

Title: COMMENTS ON BEM'S "SELF-PERCEPTION: AN ALTERNATIVE INTERPRETATION OF COGNITIVE DISSONANCE PHENOMENA"
Abstract: SINCE SS IN BEM'S (SEE 41:7) "INTERPERSONAL REPLICATION OF THE FESTINGER-CARLSMITH EXPERIMENT" WERE NOT INFORMED THAT THE AMOUNT THE PERSON THEY OBSERVED WAS PAID WAS INDEPENDENT OF HIS INITIAL ATTITUDE, BEM'S RESULTS ARE OPEN TO THE ALTERNATIVE INTERPRETATION THAT SS ASSUMED THE PERSON'S ATTITUDE DETERMINED THE AMOUNT HE WAS PAID. Title: CONCEPTS OF SET AND AVAILABILTIY AND THEIR RELATION TO THE REORGANIZATION OF AMBIGUOUS PICTORIAL STIMULI
Authors with affiliations: STEINFELD, G.J., FAIRFIELD HILLS HOSP., NEWTOWN, CONN
Abstract: CRITICIZES EXPERIMENTS ON THE EFFECTS OF SET ON PERCEPTION FOR NOT HAVING ADEQUATELY DIFFERENTIATED PERCEPTION FROM RECOGNITION, IDENTIFIABILITY, INTERPRETATION, AND RESPONSE PROCESSES. AFTER MAKING THESE DISTINCTIONS WITHIN THE CONTEXT OF A COGNITIVE THEORY, THE ROLE OF PAST EXPERIENCE IN RELATION TO THESE PROCESSES AND TO THE PROCESS OF RECOGNITION-PERCEPTION (RP) IS DISCUSSED. 2 HYPOTHESES ARE OFFERED AS EXPLANATIONS OF RP. THE MEANING OF THE CONCEPT OF AVAILABILITY IS REVIEWED AND IT IS ARGUED THAT SETS, NO MATTER HOW CONCEIVED, REFER TO DYNAMIC-MOTIVATIONAL FACTORS WHICH INCREASE THE AVAILABILITY OF MEMORY TRACES. IT IS POSTULATED AND SUPPORTED THAT HIGHLY AVAILABLE MEMORY TRACES CAN AFFECT THE REORGANIZATION OF AMBIGUOUS PICTORIAL STIMULI (RP). THE AVAILABILITY CONCEPT IS VIEWED AS BEING BROAD ENOUGH TO ENCOMPASS THE 2 BASIC HYPOTHESES, PERCEPTUAL AND NONPERCEPTUAL, USED TO INTERPRET SET EFFECTS. (54 REF.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1967 American Psychological Association.

Title: ON THE ALLEGED CIRCULARITY OF SKINNER'S CONCEPT OF STIMULUS
Abstract: IT HAS BEEN SAID IN CRITICISM OF SKINNER THAT TO DEFINE A STIMULUS IN TERMS OF ITS ELICITATION OF A RESPONSE IS TO DEFINE IT CIRCULARLY, AND THAT A STIMULUS OUGHT TO BE DEFINED SOLELY IN TERMS OF ITS PHYSICAL PROPERTIES. THERE ARE 2 FALLACIES IN THIS CRITICISM. 1ST, ONE DOES NOT DEFINE A THING. ONE DEFINES SOME PROPERTY OF A THING, OR ONE DEFINES A THING WITH RESPECT TO SOME CLASSIFICATION. 2ND, ONE CANNOT DEFINE RELATIONAL, AS DISTINGUISHED FROM INTRINSIC, PROPERTIES OF THINGS INDEPENDENTLY OF THE RELATIONS THOSE THINGS BEAR TO OTHER THINGS. THE PROPERTY OF BEING A STIMULUS IS A RELATIONAL PROPERTY. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1967 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: CIRCULARITY OF SKINNER'S CONCEPT OF STIMULUS

Authors: Liberman A.M., Cooper F.S., Shankweiler D.P., Studdert-Kennedy M.
Title: Perception of the speech code
Affiliations: Haskins Laboratories, New York, NY, United States; Haskins Laboratories, New York, NY, United States; Haskins Laboratories, New York, NY, United States; Haskins Laboratories, New York, NY, United States
Authors with affiliations: Liberman, A.M., Haskins Laboratories, New York, NY, United States; Cooper, F.S., Haskins Laboratories, New York, NY, United States; Shankweiler, D.P., Haskins Laboratories, New York, NY, United States; Studdert-Kennedy, M., Haskins Laboratories, New York, NY, United States
Abstract: Man could not perceive speech well if each phoneme were cued by a unit sound. In fact, many phonemes are encoded so that a single acoustic cue carries information in parallel about successive phonemic segments. This reduces the rate at which discrete sounds must be perceived, but at the price of a complex relation between cue and phoneme: cues vary greatly with context, and there are, in these cases, no commutable acoustic segments of phonemic size. Phoneme perception therefore requires a special decoder. A possible model supposes that the encoding occurs below the level of the (invariant) neuromotor commands to the articulatory muscles. The decoder may then identify phonemes by referring the incoming speech sounds to those commands. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1967 American Psychological Association.

Title: DECISION PROCESSES IN MEMORY
Abstract: SEVERAL CURRENT THEORIES OF THE RESPONSE PROCESS IN RECOGNITION MEMORY, OR IN CONFIDENCE RATING IN RECALL, HAVE POSTULATED A CONTINUOUS DECISION PROCESS AS IN THE THEORY OF SIGNAL DETECTABILITY. THIS ASSUMPTION, HOWEVER, DOES NOT RULE OUT ASSUMING THAT THE PROCESS BY WHICH INFORMATION IS STORED AND RETAINED IN MEMORY IS A DISCRETE ONE. IN THE FINITE-STATE DECISION THEORY PRESENTED HERE, THE CONTINUOUS DECISION PROCESS IS COMBINED WITH A REPRESENTATION OF THE MEMORY TRACE AS A TAG THAT IS EITHER AVAILABLE OR NOT AVAILABLE AT THE TIME OF TEST. IN ITS PREDICTIONS FOR RECOGNITION MEMORY EXPERIMENTS, THIS THEORY IS AT LEAST THE EQUAL OF THEORIES BASED ON TRADITIONAL HABIT STRENGTH ASSUMPTIONS. FURTHERMORE- DATA <&FROM STUDIES OF CONFIDENCE RATINGS IN RECALL <&PROVIDE CONSIDERABLE SUPPORT FOR THE <&FINITE-STATE ASSUMPTION. (25 REF.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1967 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: DECISION MAKING, RECOGNITION
Index Keywords: decision making; human; memory; probability; psychological model; review; Decision Making; Humans; Memory; Models, Psychological; Probability
Correspondence Address: BERNBACH, H.A.

Title: ON THE PROPER MEANING OF THE TERM "STIMULUS"
Abstract: IN REPLY TO HOCUTT (SEE 42:1), IT IS NOTED THAT PSYCHOLOGISTS CAN INDEED AVOID CIRCULAR REASONING IN THE WAY HE RECOMMENDS, BUT ONLY AT THE COST OF REDUCING PSYCHOLOGY TO A TRIVIAL SCIENCE. THE REAL CIRCULARITY TO BE FACED LIES IN THE PREVALENT CUSTOM OF CALLING ENVIRONMENTAL OBJECTS AND EVENTS STIMULI. SINCE PSYCHOLOGISTS ARE FORCED TO SPEAK OF OBJECTS AND EVENTS IN SOME TERMINOLOGY, THEY ARE FACED WITH A DILEMMA. AN ALTERNATIVE IS SUGGESTED. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved).

Title: A MODEL FOR COGNITIVE BALANCE
Abstract: THE CONSTRUCT "COGNITIVE BALANCE" AS PRESENTED BY HEIDER HAS GIVEN RISE TO A NUMBER OF MODELS OF THE BALANCING PROCESS. IN THIS PAPER, A BALANCE MODEL WAS DEVELOPED IN AN ATTEMPT TO PREDICT THE RELATIVE MAGNITUDE AND DIRECTION OF AN S'S EVALUATIONS FROM A KNOWLEDGE OF PERCEIVED RELATIONSHIPS. AN EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURE TO TEST THIS MODEL WAS PRESENTED AND 2 VARIATIONS ARE CARRIED OUT. ANALYSIS OF THE DATA OF THESE 2 EXPERIMENTAL CONDITIONS SUPPORTS THE PREDICTIONS OF THE MODEL. (23 REF.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1967 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: COGNITIVE BALANCE

Title: MEMORY AND DECISION ASPECTS OF RECOGNITION LEARNING
Abstract: RECOGNITION LEARNING MAY BE DESCRIBED AS A DISCRETE STATE PROCESS INVOLVING TRANSITIONS BETWEEN AN INITIAL, A TEMPORARY, AND A LEARNING STATE. IT IS ASSUMED THAT SS JUDGE THE FAMILIARITY OF LEARNING ITEMS ON AN ESSENTIALLY CONTINUOUS SCALE, BUT THAT DECISION CRITERIA ARE ESTABLISHED WHICH DIVIDE THIS SCALE INTO SEPARATE REGIONS CORRESPONDING TO THE STATES OF THE MODEL. WITH THE ASSUMPTION OF AN UNDERLYING CONTINUOUS FAMILIARITY SCALE THE LEARNING MODEL CAN ACCOUNT FOR CONFIDENCE JUDGEMENTS DURING RECOGNITION LEARNING. MEMORY-OPERATING CHARACTERISTICS DERIVED FROM THE MODEL WERE IN GENERAL AGREEMENT WITH EXPERIMENTAL DATA. THE LEARNING, FORGETTING, AND DECISION ASSUMPTIONS OF THE MODEL ARE DISCUSSED WITH RESPOECT TO RELEVANT EMPIRICAL EVIDENCE. (15 REF.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1967 American Psychological Association.

Title: ASYMPTOTIC BEHAVIOR: THE CONCEPT OF THE OPERANT
Abstract: THE CONCEPT OF THE OPERANT IS DISCUSSED IN TERMS OF ITS ROLE IN THE EVOLUTION OF SCIENTIFIC DESCRIPTIONS OF LEARNED ASYMPTOTIC BEHAVIOR. SOME DIFFERENCES BETWEEN THE HISTORICAL DEVELOPMENT OF THE EXPERIMENTAL ANALYSIS OF BEHAVIOR AND THE DEVELOPMENT OF OTHER EXPERIMENTAL SCIENCES ARE DISCUSSED AND FOUND TO BE UNJUSTIFIED. THE UTILITY OF A SEARCH FOR STRUCTURE, BROADLY DEFINED, IN BEHAVIOR IS SUGGESTED AND ARGUMENTS PRESENTED TO ESTABLISH THE COMPATIBILITY OF SUCH A SEARCH BOTH WITH THE CONCEPT OF THE OPERANT AS ORIGINALLY DEFINED AND WITH THE EVOLUTION OF ANALOGOUS CONCEPTS IN RELATED SCIENCES. (29 REF.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1967 American Psychological Association.

Title: Triadic Consistency: A statement of affective-cognitive-conative consistency
Affiliations: U North Carolina, NC, United States; U North Carolina, NC, United States
Authors with affiliations: Insko, C.A., U North Carolina, NC, United States; Schopler, J., U North Carolina, NC, United States
Abstract: This paper attempts to state the conditions under which consistency between attitude, cognitions, and behavior is to be expected. Attitudes are classified as positive or negative depending upon whether the individual feels favorable or unfavorable toward the attitude object or object of affective significance. Cognitions (beliefs about or perceptions of relationships) are classified as positive, negative, or null depending upon whether they are perceived as working toward the formation of a unit, working against the formation of a unit, or negating positive (or negative) relations. Behavior is classified as positive or negative depending upon how the individual evaluates it. 2 objects of affective significance associated with a cognition are referred to as a cognitive band. Such cognitive bands are consistent if the product of the signs is positive and inconsistent if the product of the signs is negative. Following the same multiplicative rule the triad of behavior, cognition, and object of affective significance is consistent if the product of the signs is positive and inconsistent if the product of the signs is negative. The movement toward triadic consistency and away from triadic inconsistency can occur in 2 basic situations, attitude-belief change following behavior change and behavior change following attitude-belief change. For numerous reasons the former sequence is much more likely to produce triadic consistency than is the latter. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1967 American Psychological Association.

Title: CHRONOMETRIC ANALYSIS OF CLASSIFICATION
Authors with affiliations: POSNER, M.I., U. OREGON; MITCHELL, R.F.
Abstract: REPRESENTS AN EFFORT TO EXTEND THE SUBTRACTIVE METHOD OF DONDERS TO THE ANALYSIS OF DEPTH OF PROCESSING IN SIMPLE CLASSIFICATION TASKS. THE STIMULI ARE ALWAYS PAIRS OF ITEMS (LETTERS, NONSENSE FORMS, DIGITS) TO WHICH S MUST RESPOND "SAME" OR "DIFFERENT" AS QUICKLY AS POSSIBLE. LEVELS OF INSTRUCTION ARE PHYSICAL (E.G., AA), NAME (E.G., AA), AND RULE IDENTITY (E.G., BOTH VOWELS). BY USE OF THE SUBTRACTIVE METHOD, TIMES FOR MATCHES AT EACH LEVEL ARE ANALYZED. THE EMPHASIS IS NOT PLACED UPON THE TIMES THEMSELVES BUT UPON THEIR RELEVANCE FOR UNDERSTANDING THE OPERATIONS AND MECHANISMS INVOLVED IN PERCEPTUAL MATCHING, NAMING, AND CLASSIFYING. (23 REF.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1967 American Psychological Association.

Title: ROLE OF EVENT RUNS IN PROBABILITY LEARNING
Authors with affiliations: GAMBINO, B., U. MASSACHUSETTS; MYERS, J.L.
Abstract: SEVERAL STUDIES IN 2-CHOICE PROBABILITY LEARNING HAVE DEMONSTRATED THAT SS MAKE ERRORS WHEN PREDICTING EVENT PATTERNS WHICH CAN BE PERFECTLY LEARNED. PREVIOUS MODELS HAVE BEEN UNABLE TO ACCOUNT FOR THIS RESULT. THIS PAPER PRESENTS A MODEL WHICH PROVIDES A BETTER DESCRIPTION OF THE DATA BY ASSUMING THAT REINFORCEMENT OF THE PREDICTION OF AN EVENT PATTERN MAY GENERALIZE AND SERVE AS REINFORCEMENT FOR THE PREDICTION OF OTHER EVENT PATTERNS. SEVERAL POSSIBLE EXTENSIONS OF THE MODEL ARE SUGGESTED. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1967 American Psychological Association.

Title: S-R CONTIGUITY AND DELAY OF REINFORCEMENT AS CRITICAL PARAMETERS IN CLASSICAL AVERSIVE CONDITIONING
Abstract: A 2-FACTOR EXPLANATION OF CLASSICAL AVERSIVE CONDITIONING PROPOSED BY JONES IS ANALYZED, EXTENDED, AND DEVELOPED FURTHER IN THE LIGHT OF MORE RECENT EVIDENCE. 5 POSTULATES ARE PRESENTED IN WHICH THE 2 FACTORS, STIMULUS-RESPONSE CONTIGUITY AND DELAY OF REINFORCEMENT, ARE RELATED TO CRITICAL PARAMETERS OF CONDITIONING DURING EARLY AND LATE STAGES OF PRACTICE. THE CRITICAL PARAMETERS IN EARLY PRACTICE ARE ASSUMED TO BE THE TEMPORAL INTERVALS BETWEEN THE CS AND UCR AND BETWEEN UCR AND UCS-OFFSET. THE CRITICAL PARAMETERS IN LATE PRACTICE TRIALS ARE ASSUMED TO BE THE CS-CR INTERVAL AND THE CR-UCS-OFFSET INTERVAL. EMPIRICAL EVIDENCE IS CITED APPROPRIATELY AND SOME NOVEL DEDUCTIONS ARE INCLUDED. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1967 American Psychological Association.

Title: Psychological Review: Erratum
Abstract: Reports an error in the May 1967 issue of the Psychological Review. A typographical error appeared on the cover of this issue. Norman E. Spear's name was incorrectly shown as Norman E. Sear. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1967 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: journal cover; Psychological Review

Title: ASSETS AND LIABILITIES IN GROUP PROBLEM SOLVING: THE NEED FOR AN INTEGRATIVE FUNCTION
Abstract: RESEARCH REVEALS THAT THE GROUP HAS ADVANTAGES AND DISADVANTAGES OVER INDIVIDUAL PROBLEM SOLVING. IF THE POTENTIALS FOR GROUP PROBLEM SOLVING CAN BE EXPLOITED AND ITS DEFICIENCIES AVOIDED, GROUP PROBLEM SOLVING CAN ATTAIN A LEVEL OF PROFICIENCY NOT ORDINARILY ACHIEVED. THE REQUIREMENT FOR ACHIEVING THIS LEVEL OF GROUP PERFORMANCE HINGES ON DEVELOPING A STYLE OF DISCUSSION LEADERSHIP WHICH MAXIMIZES THE GROUP'S ASSETS AND MINIMIZES ITS LIABILITIES. SINCE MEMBERS POSSESS THE ESSENTIAL INGREDIENTS FOR THE SOLUTIONS, THE DEFICIENCIES THAT APPEAR IN GROUP SOLUTIONS RESIDE IN THE PROCESSES BY WHICH GROUP SOLUTIONS DEVELOP. THESE PROCESSES CAN DETERMINE WHETHER OR NOT THE GROUP FUNCTIONS EFFECTIVELY. THE CRITICAL FACTORS IN A GROUP'S POTENTIAL ARE ORGANIZATION AND INTEGRATION. WITH TRAINING, A LEADER CAN SUPPLY THESE FUNCTIONS AND SERVE AS THE GROUP'S CNS, THUS PERMITTING THE GROUP TO EMERGE AS A HIGHLY EFFICIENT ENTITY. (39 REF.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1967 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: PROBLEM SOLVING

Title: METHODOLOGICAL DIFFERENCES BETWEEN BEHAVIORISM AND PHENOMENOLOGY IN PSYCHOLOGY
Authors with affiliations: BRODY, N., NEW SCHOOL FOR SOCIAL RESEARCH; OPPENHEIM, P.
Abstract: A REPLY TO CRITICISMS BY M. HENLE AND G. BALTIMORE AND BY R. M. ZANER (SEE 41:9) OF A PREVIOUSLY PUBLISHED PAPER ABOUT METHODOLOGICAL DIFFERENCES BETWEEN BEHAVIORISM AND PHENOMENOLOGY IN PSYCHOLOGY. THESE DIFFERENCES ARE DISCUSSED PRINCIPALLY IN TERMS OF THE DISTINCTION BETWEEN EXPERIENCES THEMSELVES AND VERBAL COMMUNICATIONS ABOUT EXPERIENCES. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved).
Author Keywords: & PHENOMENOLOGY, METHODOLOGY, DEFENSE
Index Keywords: article; behavior; behaviorism; human; psychology; Behavior; Behaviorism; Human; Psychology
Correspondence Address: BRODY, N.

Title: BEHAVIOR THERAPY AND PSYCHOTHERAPY
Authors with affiliations: WEITZMAN, B., NEW SCHOOL FOR SOCIAL RESEARCH
Abstract: CLAIMS OF THE GROUNDING OF THE METHOD OF SYSTEMATIC DESENSITIZATION IN ANIMAL EXPERIMENTATION, AND CLAIMS OF THE ADEQUACY OF CONTEMPORARY LEARNING THEORY TO CONCEPTUALIZING AND EXPLAINING THE EFFECTS OF SYSTEMATIC DESENSITIZATION, ARE MISCONCEIVED. CLAIMS OF BEHAVIOR THERAPISTS THAT THEIR SUCCESSES INVALIDATE PSYCHOANALYTIC THEORY ARE BASED UPON INADEQUATE ANALYSES. SPECIAL ATTENTION IS GIVEN TO THE PROBLEM OF SYMPTOM SUBSTITUTION. SOME EMPIRICAL EXPLORATIONS OF SYSTEMATIC DESENSITIZATION ARE DESCRIBED WHICH TEND TO THE CONCLUSION THAT THE THERAPEUTIC PROCESS HAS NOT BEEN ADEQUATELY CHARACTERIZED BY BEHAVIOR THERAPISTS. THESE EXPLORATIONS LEAD TO TENTATIVE REVISIONS OF THE THEORY AND TECHNIQUE OF SYSTEMATIC DESENSITIZATION AND TO CERTAIN INCREASES IN THEIR EFFECTIVENESS. AN ARGUMENT IS UNDERTAKEN TO JUSTIFY THE ENGAGEMENT OF THE TECHNIQUE AND DATA OF SYSTEMATIC DESENSITIZATION WITH ANALYTIC THEORIES. ILLUSTRATIVE THEORETICAL ANALYSES ARE PRESENTED IN WHICH THE TECHNIQUE AND EFFECTS OF SYSTEMATIC DESENSITIZATION ARE SHOWN TO BE COMPATIBLE WITH ASPECTS OF FREUDIAN, JUNGIAN, SULLIVANIAN, AND DECISION-MAKING THEORIES. (20 REF.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1967 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: & BEHAVIOR THERAPY, DESENSITIZATION

Title: PROBLEM OF SEX DIFFERENCES IN SPACE PERCEPTION AND ASPECTS OF INTELLECTUAL FUNCTIONING
Authors with affiliations: SHERMAN, J.A., 2917 MILITARY AVE., LOS ANGELES, CALIF
Abstract: KEY MEASURES OF ANALYTICAL COGNITIVE APPROACH ARE SUBSTANTIALLY RELATED TO SPACE PERCEPTION, AND THEREFORE ARE SEX BIASED. A CONCLUSION OF SEX DIFFERENCES IN ANALYTICAL ABILITY BASED ON THESE DATA APPEARS UNWARRANTED. THE CONSTRUCT OF ANALYTICAL COGNITIVE APPROACH APPEARS QUESTIONABLE. SPACE PERCEPTION APPEARS TO BE A RELEVANT VARIABLE TO CONTROL IN STUDIES OF SEX DIFFERENCES IN GEOMETRIC AND MATHEMATICAL PROBLEM SOLVING. A CAUSAL EXPLANATION OF THE DEVELOPMENT OF SEX DIFFERENCES IN SPATIAL PERCEPTION IS PRESENTED BASED PARTLY ON DIFFERENTIAL PRACTICE. OTHER CAUSAL EXPLANATIONS OF SEX DIFFERENCES IN ANALYTICAL APPROACH ARE DISCUSSED AND AN ATTEMPT IS MADE TO ACCOMMODATE THEM WITHIN THIS FRAMEWORK. (36 REF.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1967 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: SEX DIFFERENCES, ANALYTICAL COGNITION & SPACE PERCEPTION

Title: CRITICISM OF "TENSIONS IN PSYCHOLOGY BETWEEN THE METHODS OF BEHAVIORISM AND PHENOMENOLOGY"
Abstract: N. BRODY AND P. OPPENHEIM'S (SEE 40:9) UNDERSTANDING OF PHENOMENOLOGY IS FOUND TO BE MISLEADING AND OFTENTIMES FALSE. THEY MISTAKENLY IDENTIFY WHAT THE PHENOMENOLOGIST MEANS BY "EXPERIENCE" WITH "NONCONCEPTUALIZED EXPERIENCE," AND MAKE THE FURTHER MISTAKE OF IDENTIFYING THE LATTER WITH "BRUTE DATA." AFTER ANALYSIS OF THEIR INTERPRETATION, THE PHENOMENOLOGIST'S POSITION IS STATED AND THE POSSIBILITY OF INTERSUBJECTIVE VERIFIABILITY OF HIS FINDINGS EXAMINED. THE BEHAVIORIST'S APPEAL TO PUBLICLY OBSERVABLE DATA IS FOUND TO BE INCONSISTENT IN ITSELF. THE EPISTEMIC GROUNDS FOR THIS APPEAL ARE TO BE FOUND IN PHENOMENOLOGICAL ANALYSIS IN ITS PROPER SENSE. THEREFORE, BRODY AND OPPENHEIM'S CONTENTION THAT PHENOMENOLOGY IS IRRELEVANT TO PSYCHOLOGY IS FOUND TO BE INCORRECT AND THE QUESTION OF A POSSIBLE RAPPROCHEMENT REMAINS OPEN. (18 REF.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved).
Author Keywords: & PHENOMENOLOGY, CRITICISM
Index Keywords: article; behavior; behaviorism; human; psychology; Behavior; Behaviorism; Human; Psychology
Correspondence Address: ZANER, R.M.

Title: ANTECEDENTS TO BEHAVIOR FIXATIONS
Authors with affiliations: FELDMAN, R.S., U. MASSACHUSETTS; GREEN, K.F.
Abstract: A DOUBLE APPROACH-AVOIDANCE CONFLICT MODEL APPEARS ADEQUATE TO DESCRIBE THE RESULTS OF MAIER PARADIGM STUDIES ON RESPONSE FIXATIONS IN RATS. THE MODEL STATES THAT "GO-NO GO" CONFLICT MUST OCCUR IN THE PRESENCE OF RESPONSE ALTERNATIVES-SPATIAL (LEFT OR RIGHT) AND NONSPATIAL (BRIGHT OR DARK). EVIDENCE SHOWS THAT RANDOM 50% PUNISHMENT DOES NOT PRODUCE FIXATION. REINFORCEMENT BY ANXIETY REDUCTION AND RESISTANCE TO EXTINCTION DUE TO PARTIAL REINFORCEMENT WERE FOUND WANTING AS EXPLANATORY CONCEPTS. RATHER, ALTERING THE BALANCE OF THE "GO-NO GO" CONFLICT WITH PSYCHOACTIVE DRUGS OR ELIMINATING RESPONSE ALTERNATIVES DURING RANDOM PUNISHMENT REDUCES THE OCCURRENCE OF FIXATIONS. INTRODUCING NOVEL CUES RELATED TO REWARD AND PUNISHMENT BUT NOT ASSOCIATED WITH PREVIOUS CONFLICT AND TECHNIQUES WHICH GRADUALLY LEAD SS INTO THE CONFLICT SITUATION ALSO REDUCE FIXATION OCCURRENCE. (55 REF.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1967 American Psychological Association.

Title: QUASI-FORMAL MODELS OF INDUCTIVE BEHAVIOR AND THEIR RELATION TO PIAGET'S THEORY OF COGNITIVE STAGES
Authors with affiliations: GYR, J.W., U. MICHIGAN; BROWN, J.S.; CAFAGNA, A.C.
Abstract: 3 MODELS OF INDUCTIVE BEHAVIOR ARE FORMULATED AND THEIR PROPERTIES ARE EXPLORED WITH REFERENCE TO A SPECIFIC INDUCTIVE TASK. THEIR RELATION TO PIAGET'S COGNITIVE STAGES OF DEVELOPMENT IS TESTED EXPERIMENTALLY. THE GENERALITY OF THE MODELS FOR COGNITION GENERALLY IS EXPLORED BRIEFLY. (16 REF.) Title: PORTRAITS IN STRAW
Authors with affiliations: HENLE, M., NEW SCHOOL FOR SOCIAL RESEARCH; BALTIMORE, G.
Abstract: N. BRODY AND P. OPPENHEIM'S (SEE 40:9) REJECTION OF PHENOMENOLOGY FOR MOST PURPOSES OF PSYCHOLOGY IS DISCUSSED. THEY ARE SHOWN TO MISCONCEIVE THE NATURE OF PHENOMENAL AND OF NONCONCEPTUALIZED EXPERIENCE AS EMPLOYED BY THE PSYCHOLOGIST. METHODOLOGICAL BEHAVIORISM IS SHOWN TO REST ON THE USE OF THE INVESTIGATOR'S OWN EXPERIENCE. THE PROBLEM OF RECONCILIATION OF BEHAVIORISM AND PHENOMENOLOGICAL PSYCHOLOGY IS DISCUSSED BRIEFLY. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved).

Title: SELF-PERCEPTION: AN ALTERNATIVE INTERPRETATION OF COGNITIVE DISSONANCE PHENOMENA
Affiliations: CARNEGIE-MELLON U., PITTSBURGH, PA, United States
Authors with affiliations: BEM, D.J., CARNEGIE-MELLON U., PITTSBURGH, PA, United States
Abstract: A THEORY OF SELF-PERCEPTION IS PROPOSED TO PROVIDE AN ALTERNATIVE INTERPRETATION FOR SEVERAL OF THE MAJOR PHENOMENA EMBRACED BY FESTINGER'S THEORY OF COGNITIVE DISSONANCE AND TO EXPLICATE SOME OF THE SECONDARY PATTERNS OF DATA THAT HAVE APPEARED IN DISSONANCE EXPERIMENTS. IT IS SUGGESTED THAT THE ATTITUDE STATEMENTS WHICH COMPRISE THE MAJOR DEPENDENT VARIABLES IN DISSONANCE EXPERIMENTS MAY BE REGARDED AS INTERPERSONAL JUDGMENTS IN WHICH THE O AND THE OBSERVED HAPPEN TO BE THE SAME INDIVIDUAL AND THAT IT IS UNNECESSARY TO POSTULATE AN AVERSIVE MOTIVATIONAL DRIVE TOWARD CONSISTENCY TO ACCOUNT FOR THE ATTITUDE CHANGE PHENOMENA OBSERVED. SUPPORTING EXPERIMENTS ARE PRESENTED, AND METATHEORETICAL CONTRASTS BETWEEN THE "RADICAL" BEHAVIORAL APPROACH UTILIZED AND THE PHENOMENOLOGICAL APPROACH TYPIFIED BY DISSONANCE THEORY ARE DISCUSSED. (2 P. REF.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1967 American Psychological Association.

Index Keywords: behavior; human; perception; review; self concept; Behavior; Human; Perception; Self Concept

Title: TWO-PROCESS LEARNING THEORY: RELATIONSHIPS BETWEEN PAVLOVIAN CONDITIONING AND INSTRUMENTAL LEARNING
Authors with affiliations: RESCORLA, R.A., YALE U; SOLOMON, R.L.
Abstract: THE HISTORY OF 2-PROCESS LEARNING THEORY IS DESCRIBED, AND THE LOGICAL AND EMPIRICAL VALIDITY OF ITS MAJOR POSTULATES IS EXAMINED. THE ASSUMPTION OF 2 ACQUISITION PROCESSES REQUIRES THE DEMONSTRATION OF AN EMPIRICAL INTERACTION BETWEEN 2 TYPES OF REINFORCEMENT CONTINGENCIES AND (1) RESPONSE CLASSES, (2) REINFORCING STIMULUS CLASSES, OR (3) CHARACTERISTICS OF THE LEARNED BEHAVIOR ITSELF. THE MEDIATION POSTULATES OF 2-PROCESS THEORY WHICH ARGUE THAT CRS ARE INTIMATELY INVOLVED IN THE CONTROL OF INSTRUMENTAL RESPONDING ARE EMPHASIZED, AND 2 MAJOR LINES OF EVIDENCE THAT STEM UNIQUELY FROM THESE POSTULATES ARE EXAMINED: (1) THE CONCURRENT DEVELOPMENT AND MAINTENANCE OF INSTRUMENTAL RESPONSES AND CONDITIONED REFLEXES, AND (2) THE INTERACTION BETWEEN SEPARATELY CONDUCTED PAVLOVIAN CONDITIONING CONTINGENCIES AND INSTRUMENTAL TRAINING CONTINGENCIES IN THE CONTROL OF INSTRUMENTAL BEHAVIOR. THE EVIDENCE FROM CONCURRENT MEASUREMENT STUDIES PROVIDES, AT THE VERY BEST, ONLY WEAK SUPPORT FOR THE MEDIATIONAL HYPOTHESES OF 2-PROCESS THEORY. IN CONTRAST, THE EVIDENCE FROM INTERACTION STUDIES SHOWS THE STRONG MEDIATING CONTROL OF INSTRUMENTAL RESPONSES BY PAVLOVIAN CONDITIONING PROCEDURES, AND DEMONSTRATES THE SURPRISING POWER OF PAVLOVIAN CONCEPTS IN PREDICTING THE OUTCOMES OF MANY KINDS OF INTERACTION EXPERIMENTS. (4 P. REF.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1967 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: INSTRUMENTAL LEARNING & PAVLOVIAN CONDITIONING
Index Keywords: conditioned reflex; human; learning; review; Conditioning, Classical; Human; Learning

Title: RETENTION OF REINFORCER MAGNITUDE
Abstract: THE NET CONSEQUENCES OF 2 REINFORCER MAGNITUDES ASSOCIATED WITH A COMMON STIMULUS CONTEXT ARE CONSIDERED IN TERMS OF INTERFERENCE THEORY. THE EFFECT OF THE ORIGINAL REINFORCER MAGNITUDE UPON SUBSEQUENT BEHAVIOR IS DISCUSSED IN TERMS OF (1) SUCCESSIVE CONTRAST EFFECTS, (2) PROACTIVE INTERFERENCE IN THE RETENTION OF A SUBSEQUENT REINFORCER MAGNITUDE, AND (3) ITS INFLUENCE ON REACQUISITION OR EXTINCTION FOLLOWING A DIFFERENT REINFORCER MAGNITUDE. (2 P. REF.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1967 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: REINFORCER MAGNITUDE, INSTRUMENTAL INCENTIVE LEARNING
Index Keywords: behavior; human; reinforcement; review; Behavior; Human; Reinforcement (Psychology)

Title: CONTROL OF MEMORY BY SPREADING CORTICAL DEPRESSION: A CASE FOR STIMULUS CONTROL
Abstract: A STIMULUS-CONTROL HYPOTHESIS IS OFFERED TO ACCOUNT FOR RECENT FINDINGS WHICH HAVE BEEN TAKEN TO INDICATE THAT SPREADING DEPRESSION PREVENTS THE NEURAL STORAGE OF MEMORY TRACES. 3 GENERAL CONCLUSIONS DERIVED FROM THE SPREADING DEPRESSION RESULTS ARE REEVALUATED: (1) MEMORY CONFINEMENT TO 1 CEREBRAL HEMISPHERE PRODUCED BY TRAINING UNDER UNILATERAL DEPRESSION IS REINTERPRETED AS A GENERALIZATION-DECREMENT PHENOMENON, (2) MEMORY TRANSFER BETWEEN CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES PRODUCED BY A FEW REINFORCED RESPONSES WITH NEITHER HEMISPHERE DEPRESSED IS REINTERPRETED AS A STIMULUS-GENERALIZATION PHENOMENON, AND (3) MEMORY STORAGE PREVENTED BY SPREADING DEPRESSION IS REINTERPRETED AS MEMORY STORAGE DISPLACED BY SPREADING DEPRESSION FROM THE DEPRESSED AREAS IN THE CORTEX TO THE NONDEPRESSED AREAS IN THE SUBCORTEX. SEVERAL NEW EXPERIMENTS SUGGESTED BY THE STIMULUS-CONTROL HYPOTHESIS ARE DISCUSSED AND SEVERAL OLD RESULTS AT VARIANCE WITH THE MEMORY INTERPRETATIONS ARE REEXAMINED IN TERMS OF THE STIMULUS-CONTROL HYPOTHESIS. (21 REF.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1967 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: SPREADING CORTICAL DEPRESSIONR
Index Keywords: animal; male; memory; rat; review; spreading cortical depression; Animal; Male; Memory; Rats; Spreading Cortical Depression

Title: COMMENT ON "APPARENT REVERSAL (OSCILLATION) OF ROTARY MOTION IN DEPTH"
Abstract: R. H. DAY AND R. P. POWER (SEE 39:4) HAVE RECENTLY ADVANCED A THEORY OF APPARENT REVERSAL OF ROTARY MOTION IN DEPTH BASED UPON THE PREMISE THAT MOTION PERSPECTIVE IS IDENTICAL DURING CLOCKWISE AND COUNTERCLOCKWISE ROTATION. THIS IS NOT THE CASE: THE PREMISE APPLIES TO PARALLEL PROJECTIONS NOT TO POLAR PROJECTIONS SUCH AS THE RETINAL IMAGE. MOTION PERSPECTIVE CUES AFFORDED BY THE DIFFERENTIAL TRANSFORMATIONS OF THE RETINAL IMAGE UNDER THE 2 CONDITIONS OF ROTATION MAY MEDIATE VERIDICAL PERCEPTION EVEN WHERE SUCH TRANSFORMATIONS ARE LIMITED TO A 1-DIMENSIONAL STIMULUS DISPLAY. DAY AND POWER'S THEORY APPEARS TO APPLY ONLY WHEN SUCH CUES ARE SUBTHRESHOLD, FOR EXAMPLE, WHEN THE DISTANCE OF REGARD IS GREAT. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved).
Author Keywords: APPARENT REVERSAL OF ROTARY MOTION IN DEPTH, COMMENT

Title: DECISION THEORY, THE PIGEON, AND THE PSYCHOPHYSICAL FUNCTION
Affiliations: AMERICAN PSYCHOLOGICAL ASSOCIATION, WASHINGTON, D.C, United States
Authors with affiliations: BONEAU, C.A., AMERICAN PSYCHOLOGICAL ASSOCIATION, WASHINGTON, D.C, United States; COLE, J.L.
Abstract: A DECISION-THEORY MODEL FOR THE BEHAVIOR OF LOWER ORGANISMS IS DESCRIBED. THIS MODEL BASES PREDICTIONS OF BEHAVIOR UPON THE PRINCIPLE OF MAXIMIZATION OF PAYOFF UNDER CONDITIONS OF STIMULUS UNCERTAINTY. THE MODEL IS 1ST DEVELOPED FOR A SIMPLE, 2-STIMULUS COLOR DISCRIMINATION TASK FOR PIGEONS AND THEN GENERALIZED TO MULTIPLE-STIMULUS TASKS. FROM THIS GENERALIZED MODEL ARE DERIVED THE PSYCHOPHYSICAL FUNCTION AND ALTERATIONS IN THIS FUNCTION PRODUCED BY CHANGES IN MOTIVATION AND STIMULUS PROBABILITY. SOME RELEVANT DATA ARE DESCRIBED. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1967 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: THEORY MODEL, PSYCHOPHYSICS, PIGEON

Title: SOCIAL ATTITUDES AND THEIR CRITERIAL REFERENTS: A STRUCTURAL THEORY
Abstract: SOCIAL ATTITUDE REFERENTS-E.G., PRIVATE PROPERTY, RELIGION, CIVIL RIGHTS-ARE DIFFERENTIALLY CRITERIAL (RELEVANT) FOR DIFFERENT SETS OF INDIVIDUALS. THEIR STRUCTURE IS DUALISTIC: 2 BASIC ORTHOGONAL DIMENSIONS SPAN THE ATTITUDE DOMAIN DUE TO A PRESS TOWARD DICHOTOMIZING REFERENTS INTO CRITERIAL AND NONCRITERIAL AND TO THE CULTURE THAT OFFERS 2 MAIN IDEOLOGIES (LIBERALISM AND CONSERVATISM). BIPOLARITY APPEARS WHEN REFERENTS CRITERIAL FOR 1 SET OF INDIVIDUALS ARE USED NEGATIVELY BY ANOTHER SET OF INDIVIDUALS. FACTOR-ANALYTIC RESEARCH OF SOCIAL AND EDUCATIONAL ATTITUDES YIELDED SEVERAL 1ST-ORDER FACTORS, 2 ORTHOGONAL 2ND-ORDER FACTORS, AND LITTLE BIPOLARITY. 2 IMPLICATIONS FOR ATTITUDE RESEARCH ARE: (1) ITEMS SHOULD BE NATURAL EXPRESSIONS OF ATTITUDES AND NOT SYNTHETIC CONSTRUCTIONS (E.G., ITEM REVERSALS, BALANCED SCALES), AND (2) ATTITUDE REFERENTS THEMSELVES SHOULD BE STUDIED. (47 REF.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1967 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: ATTITUDE REFERENTS, THEORY
Index Keywords: attitude; human; review; social psychology; Attitude; Human; Psychology, Social
Correspondence Address: KERLINGER, F.N.

Title: A BIOLOGICAL THEORY OF REINFORCEMENT
Authors with affiliations: GLICKMAN, S.E., U. MICHIGAN; SCHIFF, B.B.
Abstract: A THEORY IS PRESENTED WHICH SUGGESTS THAT REINFORCEMENT EVOLVED AS A MECHANISM TO INSURE SPECIES-TYPICAL RESPONSES TO APPROPRIATE STIMULI. EVIDENCE IS REVIEWED WHICH SUGGESTS THAT SUCH RESPONSE SEQUENCES ARE ORGANIZED IN THE BRAIN STEM OF THE MAMMAL. THE SEQUENCES ARE CATEGORIZED AS CONSTITUTING APPROACH TO OR WITHDRAWAL FROM A STIMULUS-OBJECT, AND THE BRAIN STIMULATION LITERATURE IS REVIEWED TO DEMONSTRATE A RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN THESE CATEGORIES OF BEHAVIOR AND THE POSITIVE AND NEGATIVE REWARDING EFFECTS OF ELECTRICAL STIMULATION, RESPECTIVELY. REINFORCEMENT IS IDENTIFIED AS FACILITATION OF ACTIVITY IN THE NEURAL SYSTEMS WHICH MEDIATE THE SPECIES-SPECIFIC CONSUMMATORY ACTS, AND VARIOUS ANATOMICAL AND BEHAVIORAL IMPLICATIONS ARE DISCUSSED IN SOME DETAIL. (187 REF.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1967 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: BIOLOGICAL THEORY, SPECIES-TYPICAL RESPONSES TO NOVEL STIMULI
Index Keywords: animal; animal behavior; reinforcement; review; species difference; Animal; Behavior, Animal; Reinforcement (Psychology); Species Specificity
Correspondence Address: GLICKMAN, S.E.

Title: OPTIMAL POLICIES FOR THE PRISONER'S DILEMMA
Authors with affiliations: RAPOPORT, A., HEBREW U., JERUSALEM, Israel
Abstract: AN OPTIMAL MODEL FOR THE PRISONER'S DILEMMA GAME IS SUGGESTED. THE MODEL IS NORMATIVE IN THE SENSE THAT GIVEN FEW ASSUMPTIONS ABOUT THE WAY THE GAME IS PERCEIVED BY THE PLAYERS, AN OPTIMAL POLICY IS PRESCRIBED TO EACH PLAYER MAXIMIZING HIS LONG-RUN EXPECTED GAIN. THE DILEMMA IS RESOLVED BY RESTRUCTURING THE GAME AS A SUPERGAME COMPOSED OF SEVERAL COMPONENT GAMES SUCH THAT TRANSITIONS AMONG THEM ARE POSSIBLE. DYNAMIC PROGRAMING IS USED TO DERIVE THE OPTIMAL POLICY. (16 REF.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1967 American Psychological Association.

Title: ON FRUSTRATION AND THE PRE
Authors with affiliations: WILTON, R., U. EXETER, ENGLAND, United Kingdom
Abstract: ANIMALS TRAINED ON PARTIAL REINFORCEMENT TEND TO BE MORE RESISTANT TO EXTINCTION THAN ANIMALS TRAINED ON CONTINUOUS REINFORCEMENT. A MECHANISM WHICH CONTRIBUTES TO THIS EFFECT CAN BE DERIVED FROM FRUSTRATION THEORY. IT SUGGESTS THAT ANIMALS TRAINED ON CONTINUOUS REINFORCEMENT SUFFER AN INTRATRIAL STIMULUS GENERALIZATION DECREMENT IN EXTINCTION WHILE ANIMALS TRAINED ON PARTIAL REINFORCEMENT DO NOT. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1967 American Psychological Association.

Title: TRANSFER ANALYSIS OF FAMILIARIZATION EFFECTS
Affiliations: YORK U., TORONTO, ONTARIO, CANADA, Canada
Authors with affiliations: JUNG, J., YORK U., TORONTO, ONTARIO, CANADA, Canada
Abstract: FAMILIARIZATION PROCEDURES INVOLVE THE EXPERIMENTAL MANIPULATION OF THE FREQUENCY OF EXPOSURE OF ITEMS. THE EFFECT OF FREQUENCY IS THEN ASSESSED ON SUBSEQUENT LEARNING INVOLVING THESE ITEMS. THE PRESENT ANALYSIS ASSUMES THAT INCIDENTAL ASSOCIATIONS ARE FORMED DURING THE PRETRAINING PHASE. DEPENDING ON WHETHER PRETRAINING IS PROVIDED FOR STIMULI, RESPONSES, OR BOTH TERMS, IT IS SUGGESTED THAT DIFFERENT TRANSFER PARADIGMS EXIST BETWEEN THESE PRETRAINING ASSOCIATIONS AND THE TEST LIST ASSOCIATIONS. THE RESULTS FROM PREVIOUS FAMILIARIZATION STUDIES ARE SHOWN TO PARALLEL THOSE FOR THE TRANSFER PARADIGM ASSUMED TO EXIST IN EACH STUDY. (33 REF.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1967 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: FAMILIARIZATION, ASSOCIATION FORMATION DURING PRETRAINING, TRANSFER

Title: AN EXPECTANCY-VALUE MODEL OF INFORMATION-SEEKING BEHAVIOR
Affiliations: U. NEW ENGLAND, NEW SOUTH WALES, AUSTRALIA, Australia
Authors with affiliations: FEATHER, N.T., U. NEW ENGLAND, NEW SOUTH WALES, AUSTRALIA, Australia
Abstract: A MODEL OF INFORMATION-SEEKING BEHAVIOR IS PRESENTED WHICH CONSIDERS THIS BEHAVIOR AS DETERMINED BY THE RESULTANT OF APPROACH AND AVOIDANCE TENDENCIES. AN EXPERIMENT ILLUSTRATING THE APPLICATION OF THE MODEL IS DESCRIBED. THE MODEL IS SHOWN TO CLARIFY FESTINGER'S DISCUSSION OF THE EFFECTS OF CONFIDENCE AND USEFULNESS ON INFORMATION-SEEKING BEHAVIOR. DIFFERENT TYPES OF EXTRINSIC TENDENCY ARE DESCRIBED; FACTORS INFLUENCING MOTIVES, EXPECTANCIES, AND INCENTIVE VALUES ARE DISCUSSED; CONDITIONS FOR ELICITING THE TENDENCIES TO APPROACH CONSISTENCY AND TO AVOID INCONSISTENCY ARE CONSIDERED; AND OTHER TYPES OF ADJUSTMENT THAT MIGHT FOLLOW IMBALANCE IN A COGNITIVE STRUCTURE ARE SUMMARIZED. (30 REF.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1967 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: INFORMATION SEEKING BEHAVIOR, APPROACH & AVOIDANCE
Index Keywords: article; avoidance behavior; human; interpersonal communication; model; motivation; personality; Avoidance Learning; Communication; Human; Models, Psychological; Motivation; Personality
Correspondence Address: FEATHER, N.T.

Title: PAVLOVIAN CONDITIONING AND ITS PROPER CONTROL PROCEDURES
Abstract: THE TRADITIONAL CONTROL PROCEDURES FOR PAVLOVIAN CONDITIONING ARE EXAMINED AND EACH IS FOUND WANTING. SOME PROCEDURES INTRODUCE NONASSOCIATIVE FACTORS NOT PRESENT IN THE EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURE WHILE OTHERS TRANSFORM THE EXCITATORY, EXPERIMENTAL CS-UCS CONTINGENCY INTO AN INHIBITORY CONTINGENCY. AN ALTERNATIVE CONTROL PROCEDURE IS SUGGESTED IN WHICH THERE IS NO CONTINGENCY WHATSOEVER BETWEEN CS AND UCS. THIS "TRULY RANDOM" CONTROL PROCEDURE LEADS TO A NEW CONCEPTION OF PAVLOVIAN CONDITIONING POSTULATING THAT THE CONTINGENCY BETWEEN CS AND UCS, RATHER THAN THE PAIRING OF CS AND UCS, IS THE IMPORTANT EVENT IN CONDITIONING. THE FRUITFULNESS OF THIS NEW CONCEPTION OF PAVLOVIAN CONDITIONING IS ILLUSTRATED BY 2 EXPERIMENTAL RESULTS. (15 REF.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1967 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: CONTROL PROCEDURES
Index Keywords: conditioned reflex; conditioning; review; Conditioning (Psychology); Conditioning, Classical
Correspondence Address: RESCORLA, R.A.

Title: STIMULUS GENERALIZATION AND THE MATCHING PRINCIPLE
Abstract: A PREEXPERIMENTAL TENDENCY IS ASSUMED TO AFFECT GRADIENTS OF STIMULUS GENERALIZATION: A MATCHING OF RESPONSE AMPLITUDE TO STIMULUS MAGNITUDE. THIS IS SHOWN TO AFFECT GRADIENTS OF GENERALIZATION ALONG VERBAL DIMENSIONS OF AGGRESSION, MOOD, AND ANIMAL SIZE, AND ALONG THE PHYSICAL DIMENSION OF LENGTH OF LINES. IT APPLIES TO BOTH VOCAL AND NONVOCAL RESPONSES. BY EXTRAPOLATION, THE MATCHING PRINCIPLE APPLIES TO ALL STIMULUS DIMENSIONS AND ALL INSTRUMENTAL RESPONSES. THE MATCHING PRINCIPLE ALSO CORRECTLY PREDICTS THE PRESENCE OF RESPONSE GRADIENTS IN THE ABSENCE OF CONDITIONING. STIMULUS INTENSITY DYNAMISM AND ADAPTATION-LEVEL THEORY ARE DISCUSSED AND SHOWN TO BE DIFFERENT FROM THE MATCHING PRINCIPLE. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1967 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: STIMULUS-RESPONSE CONGRUENCIES AS MATCHING PRINCIPLE, RESPONSE DISPOSITION
Index Keywords: adult; human; learning; review; Adult; Generalization (Psychology); Generalization, Stimulus; Human
Correspondence Address: BUSS, A.H.

Title: WORD-FREQUENCY EFFECT AND RESPONSE BIAS
Affiliations: APPLIED PSYCHOLOGY RESEARCH UNIT, CAMBRIDGE, ENGLAND
Authors with affiliations: BROADBENT, D.E., APPLIED PSYCHOLOGY RESEARCH UNIT, CAMBRIDGE, ENGLAND
Abstract: MANY RECENT INVESTIGATORS HAVE STUDIED "RESPONSE BIAS" THEORIES OF THE PERCEPTION OF COMMON VS. UNCOMMON WORDS. 4 DIFFERENT CLASSES OF THEORY ARE DISTINGUISHED, AND IT IS DEMONSTRATED THAT 3 OF THEM ARE INCONSISTENT WITH PREVIOUSLY PUBLISHED AND WITH FRESH DATA. THE 4TH SENSE OF RESPONSE BIAS, HOWEVER, LEADS TO THE PREDICTION THAT BIAS ON CORRECT RESPONSES MAY BE GREATER THAN THAT ON ERRORS, AND IS VERY ACCURATELY CONSISTENT WITH THE DATA. THIS IS THE SENSE OF RESPONSE BIAS AS ANALOGOUS TO THE BIAS OF A CRITERION IN A STATISTICAL DECISION. (26 REF.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1967 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: WORD PERCEPTION & RESPONSE BIAS THEORIES
Index Keywords: adult; female; hearing; human; language; perception; review; Adult; Auditory Perception; Female; Hearing; Human; Language; Middle Age; Perception
Correspondence Address: BROADBENT, D.E.

Title: MOTIVATIONAL AND EMOTIONAL CONTROLS OF COGNITION
Authors with affiliations: SIMON, H.A., CARNEGIE INST. OF TECHNOLOGY
Abstract: THE CNS IS A SERIAL INFORMATION PROCESSOR THAT MUST SERVE AN ORGANISM ENDOWED WITH MULTIPLE NEEDS, AND LIVING IN AN ENVIRONMENT THAT PRESENTS UNPREDICTABLE THREATS AND OPPORTUNITIES. THESE REQUIREMENTS ARE MET BY 2 MECHANISMS: (1) GOAL-TERMINATING MECHANISMS, PERMITTING GOALS TO BE PROCESSED SERIALLY WITHOUT ANY 1 MONOPOLIZING THE PROCESSOR, AND (2) INTERRUPTION MECHANISM, HAVING THE PROPERTIES USUALLY ASCRIBED TO EMOTION, ALLOWING THE PROCESSOR TO RESPOND TO URGENT NEEDS IN REAL TIME. MECHANISMS OF THESE KINDS, TO CONTROL THE DIRECTION OF ATTENTION AND ACTIVITY, HAVE BEEN INCORPORATED IN SOME INFORMATION-PROCESSING THEORIES OF HUMAN COGNITION, AND THEIR FURTHER ELABORATION WILL PERMIT THESE THEORIES TO EXPLAIN WIDER RANGES OF BEHAVIOR. (16 REF.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1967 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: MOTIVATIONAL & EMOTIONAL CONTROLS, & INFORMATION-PROCESSING, THEORYS
Index Keywords: cognition; emotion; human; motivation; review; Cognition; Emotions; Human; Motivation
Correspondence Address: SIMON, H.A.

Title: PARALLEL FUNCTIONS OF SERIAL LEARNING AND TACHISTOSCOPIC PATTERN PERCEPTION
Authors with affiliations: HARCUM, E.R., COLL. OF WILLIAM + MARY
Abstract: THE SIMILARITY OF THE DISTRIBUTION OF ERRORS IN THE REPRODUCTION OF ELEMENTS WITHIN TACHISTOSCOPIC PATTERNS TO THE SERIAL-POSITION CURVE OF ERRORS IN ROTE LEARNING IS NOTED AND DISCUSSED. FROM THIS DATA A HYPOTHESIS IS DERIVED, THAT THIS SIMILARITY OCCURS BECAUSE THE "PERCEPTUAL" AND "LEARNING" TASKS INVOKE SIMILAR PSYCHOLOGICAL PROCESSES. THIS HYPOTHESIS IMPLIES THAT EACH OBSERVATION IN PERCEPTION IS A MINIATURE TASK OF SERIAL LEARNING. THE PRESENT ANALYSES OF PERCEPTION AND LEARNING TASKS SUPPORT THE HYPOTHESIS. CERTAIN COMMON PROCESSES, WHICH DETERMINE THE RELATIVE NUMBERS OF ERRORS FOR INDIVIDUAL STIMULUS-ELEMENTS IN BOTH TASKS, ARE INFERRED. THESE PROCESSES, GROUPED UNDER THE RUBRIC OF INFORMATION-TRANSLATION, INCLUDE ELEMENT DISCRIMINATION, SELECTIVE ANALYSIS OF PERSISTING TRACES, AND THE ORGANIZATION OF INFORMATION FOR STORAGE IN MEMORY. (59 REF.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1967 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: TACHISTOSCOPIC PATTERN PERCEPTION, SIMILARITY, INFORMATION-TRANSLATION THEORY
Index Keywords: human; learning; review; vision; Human; Serial Learning; Visual Perception
Correspondence Address: HARCUM, E.R.

Title: SYMPTOM EXPRESSION AS A FORM OF PRIMITIVE DECENTERING
Abstract: PIAGET'S DECENTERING CONCEPT IMPLIES THE FORMAL NOTION THAT A RECIPROCAL, MUTUALLY CORRECTIVE INFLUENCE IS EXERTED BY 1 SYSTEM OF FUNCTIONING UPON ANOTHER IF THERE IS CONTACT BETWEEN SYSTEMS. IT FURTHER IMPLIES THAT IF THESE SYSTEMS FUNCTION IN ISOLATION FROM EACH OTHER, THE DISTORTION INHERENT IN EACH SYSTEM WILL BE EXPRESSED AS AN EXAGGERATED AND FLUCTUATING FORM OF BEHAVIOR. THIS IMPLICATION OF THE DECENTERING CONCEPT TO AN INTERPRETATION OF IMPERSONAL AND INTERPERSONAL ASPECTS OF SYMPTOMATIC BEHAVIOR IS EXTENDED AND IT SUGGESTS THAT CENTRAL FEATURES OF SYMPTOM EXPRESSION CAN BE CHARACTERIZED IN TERMS OF EXAGGERATION AND FLUCTUATION; THESE FEATURES CAN BE DERIVED FROM THE FORMAL ATTRIBUTE OF DISJUNCTIVE ISOLATION BETWEEN SYSTEMS. THE IMPLICATIONS OF SUCH A FORMULATION ARE: (1) IT SUGGESTS AN ALTERNATIVE TO AN INAPPROPRIATE TELEOLOGY INHERENT IN A RADICAL ANXIETY-DEFENSE INTERPRETATION OF SYMPTOM EXPRESSION, AND (2) PROVIDES AN INITIAL FRAMEWORK WHEREBY PIAGET'S NOTIONS, WHICH HAVE BEEN PRIMARILY CONFINED TO IMPERSONAL COGNITIVE FUNCTIONING, CAN BE EXTENDED TO INTERPERSONAL DIMENSIONS OF EXPERIENCE. (25 REF.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1967 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: DECENTERING THEORY, IMPERSONAL & INTERPERSONAL COGNITIVE STRUCTURING, SYMPTOMATIC BEHAVIOR
Index Keywords: behavior; cognition; concept formation; human; review; Behavior; Cognition; Concept Formation; Human
Correspondence Address: FEFFER, M.

Title: LINEAR THEORY OF PERFORMANCE
Abstract: A THEORY LIKE TOLMAN'S THEORY OF PERFORMANCE IS GIVEN IN MATRIX ALGEBRA FORM. V = THE MATRIX OF VALENCES OF VARIOUS GOALS UNDER SEVERAL MAINTENANCE SCHEDULES. B = THE MATRIX OF EXPECTANCIES OF THE GOALS, GIVEN THAT VARIOUS MEANS ARE ADOPTED. THEN BV = THE MATRIX OF VALENCES INDUCED ON THE MEANS. (EXPECTANCIES OF EVENTS MAY INTERVENE IN THE CONSTRUCTION OF MATRIX B.) C = THE MATRIX OF PROBABILITIES THAT INDIVIDUAL BEHAVIORS, CLASSIFIED OBJECTIVELY BY E, CORRESPOND TO THE VARIOUS MEANS EMPLOYED BY S. THEN CBV = THE MATRIX OF VALENCES INDUCED ON OBJECTIVE ALTERNATIVES. ASSUME THAT THE ELEMENTS OF V CAN BE NORMALIZED AS POSITIVE AND ADDING TO UNITY. THEN P = CBV IS THE MATRIX OF PROBABILITIES OF THE RESPONSE ALTERNATIVES. THE MATRICES C, V, AND B CAN BE ESTIMATED; UNDER CERTAIN CONDITIONS, DERIVED. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1967 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: THEORY, ALGEBRAIC MODEL
Index Keywords: behavior; decision making; human; mathematics; review; Behavior; Decision Making; Human; Mathematics
Correspondence Address: RESTLE, F.

Title: Response disorganization and breadth of observation in schizophrenia
Affiliations: University of Massachusetts, Amherst, MA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Broen Jr., W.E., University of Massachusetts, Amherst, MA, United States
Abstract: Two variables: (a) degree of organization of competing responses; and (b) breadth of observation, are related to each other and used to discuss research tasks on which differences have been found between normals, acute schizophrenics, and chronic schizophrenics. Research results which have seemed contradictory can be clarified by the basic propositions that: (a) response disorganization characterizes both acute and chronic schizophrenics; and (b) chronics attempt to cope with response disorganization by observing fewer stimuli. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1966 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: acute schizophrenics; chronic schizophrenics; observation; response disorganization
Index Keywords: article; attention; human; interpersonal communication; psychology; thinking; Attention; Communication; Human; Schizophrenic Psychology; Thinking
Correspondence Address: Broen Jr., W.E.; University of Massachusetts, Amherst, MA, United States

Title: RAPID EYE MOVEMENT SLEEP AND CORTICAL HOMEOSTASIS
Authors with affiliations: EPHRON, H.S., NEW YORK MEDICAL COLL; CARRINGTON, P.
Abstract: FINDINGS INDICATE THAT UNDER MOST CONDITIONS NONRAPID EYE MOVEMENT (NREM) SLEEP REPRESENTS AN INDISPENSABLE CONDITION FOR THE ONSET OF REM SLEEP. THE IMPLICATIONS OF THIS SEQUENTIAL RELATIONSHIP ARE EXPLORED. IT IS CONCEPTUALIZED THAT DEEPENING NREM SLEEP INVOLVES A PROGRESSIVE LOSS OF CEREBRAL VIGILANCE WHICH, NEVERTHELESS, MUST SOMEHOW BE MAINTAINED WITHIN ADAPTIVELY APPROPRIATE LIMITS. A HOMEOSTATIC INTERPLAY BETWEEN SLEEP PHASES IS THEN POSTULATED. THIS INVOLVES 2 COMPLEMENTARY TENDENCIES; 1 TENDENCY TOWARD DEEPENING NREM SLEEP, AND ORGANISMIC REST, WHICH, WHEN IT REACHES A PRESET LEVEL, TRIGGERS THE RELEASE OF ANOTHER TENDENCY TOWARD REM SLEEP AND ORGANISMIC ACTIVATION. REM SLEEP IS SEEN AS ACTING TO INCREASE CORTICAL "TONUS" THROUGH A PROCESS OF "ENDOGENOUS AFFERENTATION." (5 P. REF.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1966 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: NONRAPID EYE MOVEMENT & REM SEQUENCE, CORTICAL HOMEOSTASIS

Title: ON THE INCOMPATIBILITY OF THE HOUSTON AND OSGOOD TRANSFER SURFACES
Abstract: A COMPARISON OF THE HOUSTON AND OSGOOD TRANSFER SURFACES DEMONSTRATES THAT THEY ARE INCOMPATIBLE. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1966 American Psychological Association.

Title: NEURAL MECHANISMS OF SLEEP: CHANGING VIEW OF RETICULAR FORMATION FUNCTION
Abstract: RECENT DATA ON SLEEP ARE REVIEWED PRIMARILY WITH THE GOAL OF UNDERSTANDING THE FUNCTIONAL ORGANIZATION OF MIDBRAIN, PONTINE, AND MEDULLARY NUCLEAR SYSTEMS RELATED TO THE SLEEP PROCESS. A SUMMARIZING SCHEMA IS PRESENTED IN WHICH IT IS ASSUMED THAT THERE ARE 2 EEG DESYNCHRONIZING SYSTEMS, 1 DESCRIBED PHYSIOLOGICALLY BY MORUZZI AND MAGOUN, AND THE OTHER, A LIMBIC-MIDBRAIN SYSTEM, DESCRIBED ANATOMICALLY BY NAUTA. AN ATTEMPT IS ALSO MADE TO SHOW HOW THESE DATA REQUIRE MODIFICATION OF PREVIOUSLY HELD VIEWS OF RETICULAR FORMATION FUNCTION. (4 P. REF.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1966 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: SLEEP, DESYNCHRONIZING SYSTEMS, RETICULAR FORMATION
Index Keywords: animal; brain stem; human; mesencephalon; physiology; reticular formation; review; sleep; Animal; Brain Stem; Human; Mesencephalon; Reticular Formation; Sleep
Correspondence Address: ROUTTENBERG, A.

Title: OPTICAL MOTIONS AND SPACE PERCEPTION: AN EXTENSION OF GIBSON'S ANALYSIS
Abstract: THERE IS A PERCEPTUAL TENDENCY TO SEE THE 2-DIMENSIONAL TRANSFORMATIONS OF SHADOWS AS RIGID MOVEMENTS IN 3 DIMENSIONS. THE SIGNIFICANCE OF THIS ILLUSION FOR VERIDICAL PERCEPTION IS INVESTIGATED BY A MATHEMATICAL ANALYSIS OF THE CORRESPONDENCE BETWEEN 3-DIMENSIONAL OBJECT DISPLACEMENTS AND THE OPTICAL MOTIONS THEY CAUSE AT THE EYE. THE RESULTS SHOW THAT OPTICALLY EQUIVALENT OBJECT DISPLACEMENTS SHARE SIGNIFICANT FEATURES, AND THAT THEREFORE THE OPTICAL MOTIONS THEY PRODUCE ARE POTENTIALLY INFORMATIVE ABOUT THOSE FEATURES. SOME OF THE OBJECTIVE FEATURES SPECIFIED BY OPTICAL MOTIONS ARE INITIAL ORIENTATION, ROTATION, AND THE RATIO BETWEEN INITIAL DISTANCE AND TRANSLATION DISTANCE. THE ANALYSIS IS BASED ON COPLANAR SETS OF OBJECT POINTS, AND THE FACT THAT THEIR DISPLACEMENTS PRODUCE 2-DIMENSIONAL PROJECTIVE TRANSFORMATIONS OF THE RETINAL IMAGE. (16 REF.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1966 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: SPACE, & OPTICAL MOTIONS, 2-DIMENSIONAL TRANSFORMATIONS OF SHADOWS
Index Keywords: article; depth perception; eye movement; human; illusion; mathematics; Eye Movements; Human; Illusions; Mathematics; Space Perception
Correspondence Address: HAY, J.C.

Title: SOCIAL REINFORCEMENT EFFECTS AS A FUNCTION OF SOCIAL REINFORCEMENT HISTORY
Abstract: IT WAS SUGGESTED THAT AN INDIVIDUAL'S PAST HISTORY OF SOCIAL REINFORCEMENT IMPORTANTLY INFLUENCES HIS PRESENT RECEPTIVITY TO SOCIAL REINFORCEMENT. AFFECTIVE AND BEHAVIORAL REACTIONS TO PRESENT LEVELS OF SOCIAL REINFORCEMENT ARE ASSUMED TO BE A COMPLEX FUNCTION OF BOTH THE DIRECTION AND MAGNITUDE OF ANY DISPARITY THAT MAY EXIST BETWEEN THE PRESENT RATE OF SOCIAL REINFORCEMENT AND THE INDIVIDUAL'S STANDARD OF SOCIAL REINFORCEMENT (SRS). DISPARITIES WHICH PRODUCE NEGATIVE AFFECT (I.E., RATES OF SOCIAL REINFORCEMENT WHICH ARE EITHER SUBSTANTIALLY ABOVE OR BELOW THE SRS) ARE ASSUMED, UNDER CERTAIN SPECIFIED CONDITIONS, TO RESULT IN THE INDIVIDUAL VARYING HIS SELF-PRESENTATION (E.G., HIS TASK PERFORMANCE) IN A DIRECTION WHICH IS LIKELY TO RESULT IN HIS BEING REINFORCED AT A RATE WHICH HE DEEMS APPROPRIATE, I.E., A RATE WHICH EITHER MATCHES OR MODERATELY EXCEEDS HIS SRS. IT IS THUS HYPOTHESIZED THAT THE DEGREE OF CONDITIONABILITY FOUND IN A VARIETY OF STUDIES CONCERNED WITH THE EFFECTS OF SOCIAL REINFORCEMENT ON SIMPLE MOTOR BEHAVIORS AND VERBAL OPERANTS CAN BE INTERPRETED AS INVOLVING ATTEMPTS AT MUTUAL SOCIAL CONTROL. (2 P. REF.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1966 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: REINFORCEMENT & SOCIAL REINFORCEMENT HISTORY
Index Keywords: behavior; human; reinforcement; review; social psychology; Behavior; Human; Psychology, Social; Reinforcement (Psychology)
Correspondence Address: BARON, R.M.

Authors: EKSTRAND B.R., WALLACE W.P., UNDERWOOD B.J.
Title: A FREQUENCY THEORY OF VERBAL-DISCRIMINATION LEARNING
Authors with affiliations: EKSTRAND, B.R., NORTHWESTERN U; WALLACE, W.P.; UNDERWOOD, B.J.
Abstract: THE FREQUENCY THEORY OF VERBAL-DISCRIMINATION (VD) LEARNING POSTULATES THAT THE CUE FOR DISCRIMINATION IS THE DIFFERENCE IN FREQUENCY OF OCCURRENCE BETWEEN THE CORRECT (C) AND INCORRECT (I) ALTERNATIVES OF A VD PAIR. IT IS POSTULATED THAT, AS VD LEARNING PROCEEDS, AT LEAST A 2:1 FREQUENCY DIFFERENCE IN FAVOR OF THE C ITEM IS BUILT UP, AND SS USE THIS DIFFERENCE AS THEIR CUE. BY ALWAYS SELECTING THE ITEM WITH THE GREATER PERCEIVED FREQUENCY OF OCCURRENCE, SS CAN PERFORM EFFICIENTLY. THE EXPERIMENT PRESENTED PRODUCED RESULTS IN SUPPORT OF THE FREQUENCY THEORY. THE DISCUSSION CENTERS ON ADDITIONAL PREDICTIONS OF THE THEORY AND THE EVIDENCE AVAILABLE IN SUPPORT OF THESE PREDICTIONS. (17 REF.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1966 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: VERBAL, CORRECT-INCORRECT FREQUENCY AS CUE
Index Keywords: article; association; discrimination learning; human; learning; Cues; Discrimination Learning; Human; Verbal Learning
Correspondence Address: EKSTRAND, B.R.

Title: AN ANALYSIS OF SOME SHORTCOMINGS IN THE INTERFERENCE THEORY OF FORGETTING
Authors with affiliations: UNDERWOOD, B.J., NORTHWESTERN U; EKSTRAND, B.R.
Abstract: TESTS OF INTERFERENCE THEORY OF FORGETTING AS APPLIED TO EXTRAEXPERIMENTAL SOURCES OF INTERFERENCE HAVE BEEN GENERALLY NEGATIVE. THE HYPOTHESIS WAS TESTED THAT THE NEGATIVE FINDINGS RESULT FROM THE FACT THAT LINGUISTIC ASSOCIATIONS, PRESUMED TO INTERFERE, DO NOT DO SO BECAUSE OF THEIR HIGH LEVEL OF LEARNING, THE DISTRIBUTION OF THEIR LEARNING OVER TIME, OR BOTH. THE A-B, A-C PARADIGM WAS EMPLOYED, WITH A-B BEING VARIED FROM 12-80 TRIALS, AND WAS LEARNED EITHER BY MASSED PRACTICE OR BY DISTRIBUTION OF PRACTICE OVER 4 DAYS. RECALL OF A-C AFTER 24 HR. SHOWED THAT DISTRIBUTION OF A-B RESULTED IN ONLY SMALL PROACTIVE INHIBITION (PI), WHILE MASSING RESULTED IN HEAVY PI. DEGREE OF A-B LEARNING INFLUENCED THE RECALL ONLY UNDER MASSED A-B LEARNING. SOME IMPLICATIONS FOR THE DEVELOPMENT OF FORGETTING THEORY WERE PRESENTED. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1966 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: FORGETTING THEORY, INTERFERENCE
Index Keywords: article; human; memory; paired associate learning; Human; Memory; Paired-Associate Learning

Title: Reinstatement
Authors with affiliations: Campbell, B.A., Princeton U.; Jaynes, J.
Abstract: Reinstatement is defined as periodic partial repetition of an experience such that it maintains the effects of that experience through time. This principle is demonstrated in a developmental study on the effects of early fear in rats, and is then discussed in relation to clinical and developmental theory. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1966 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: FEAR, EARLY, & REINSTATEMENT & CLINICAL & DEVELOPMENTAL THEORY, RAT; LEARNING; RAT/AVOIDANCE IN, REINSTATEMENT & EARLY FEAR & CLINICAL & DEVELOPMENTAL THEORY

Title: Cognitive and drive factors in the extinction of the conditioned eye blink in human subjects
Abstract: Extinction of the eyelid CR in humans has been shown to be a function of factors relating to Ss' capabilities to discriminate the change in stimulus conditions at the inception of extinction. Hypothesizing that the rapid extinction obtained with humans in the standard conditioning situation results from an inhibitory set not to respond based on this discrimination, subsequent experiments in a masking situation designed to control (eliminate) this cognitive factor revealed that extinction of the eyelid response in humans proceeds at a relatively slow rate, as in animals. The findings with the masking situation also suggest that the partial reinforcement effect is absent in humans as in the case of classical aversive extinction with animals. (31 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1966 American Psychological Association.

Title: Tests for spontaneous alternation
Abstract: Predictions about sequential properties of 2-choice learning data are derived from a simple assumption about the effects of rewarded and unrewarded choices. These predictions are used as tests for spontaneous alternation in T maze experiments. Given massed trials, rats show spontaneous alternation during position and reversal training as well as during training with both responses rewarded, but these rats are likely to show such alternation on a given trial if and only if they have alternated on the previous trial. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1966 American Psychological Association.

Correspondence Address: Holman, E.W.

Title: Attachment behavior of mammals
Abstract: Available data support the empirical generalization that animals tend to remain in the presence of objects to which they have been continuously exposed. From such observations, and certain assumptions of associative learning theory, it is proposed that mammalian attachment behavior is determined by: (1) the length of association with an object in a given context, and (2) the relative cue weight of the object. The model emphasizes the associative nature of the attachment process, the contextual and response relativity of attachment behavior, and the role of the immediate stimulus setting in the control of an animal's response subsystems. (3 p. ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1966 American Psychological Association.

Title: A Markov model for classical conditioning: Application to eye-blink conditioning in rabbits
Authors with affiliations: Theios, J., U. Texas; Brelsford Jr., J.W.
Abstract: A 3-state Markov model is postulated for classical conditioning, and specific implications of the model for eye-blink conditioning are discussed. The Markov model, a general response-independent model, and a single-operator linear model with individual differences were applied to eye-blink conditioning data of rabbits. Likelihood ratio analyses of individual response sequences indicate that the Markov model is far superior to the other models as a description of the conditioning process in rabbits. Speculations concerning theoretical identifications of the abstract states of the Markov process are made. Application of the Markov model to human eyelid conditioning is discussed. (19 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1966 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: MODEL, MARKOV, FOR EYE BLINK CLASSICAL CONDITIONING, RABBIT; MODELS & MATHEMATICAL MODELS; RABBIT, MARKOV MODEL FOR EYE BLINK CLASSICAL CONDITIONING

Title: Process of enumeration
Authors with affiliations: Beckwith, M., Indiana U.; Restle, F.
Abstract: Mathematically, the process of enumeration is fundamental to arithmetic. Psychologically, it is a sensorimotor chain controlled at every stage by a shifting perceptual organization. Enumeration requires a chant ("1, 2, 3 . . . "), a shifting indicator response (pointing), and a perceptual grouping of objects into those already counted and those still ahead. The arrangement of the objects has, theoretically, an important effect on the speed and accuracy of enumeration. Further analysis shows that the serial chain of behavior, required for counting a fairly large set of objects, must be divided into parts, and the objects grouped into corresponding subsets. 3 experiments show the relationship between arrangement of objects and counting. (23 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1966 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: MATHEMATICS, PSYCHOLOGICAL PROCESS OF ENUMERATION; PERCEPTION, ENUMERATION & PSYCHOLOGICAL PROCESS & SHIFTING, ORGANIZATION; THINKING

Title: Partial reinforcement: A hypothesis of sequential effects
Abstract: A hypothesis which attempts to account for extinction following partial reinforcement in terms of certain sequential aspects of nonreinforced and reinforced trials was considered. The central assumptions are that nonreinforced trials occasion a specific and distinctive internal stimulus and that this stimulus is progressively modified by successive nonreinforcements. Stimulus modification was indicated as exerting its effects on extinction through 3 sequential variables: N-length, number of different N-lengths, and number of occurrences of each N-length. The operation of these variables and the stimulus modification mechanism was elaborated by considering certain salient and representative partial reinforcement investigations. This detailed survey of critical experimental findings suggested that the better known nonsequential variables which form the basis of most current partial reinforcement hypotheses exercise little or no control over extinction and that a theory of extinction must be based on a sequential analysis. Experimental evidence was considered which suggests that: (1) the modification mechanism may be applicable to all partial reinforcement situations, whether classical or instrumental, appetitive or aversive; and (2) the present hypothesis may be able to deliver certain types of rate-of-extinction predictions. These particular rate predictions, while relatively primitive, do appear to be something of an improvement over the current greater-than type prediction. (2 p. ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1966 American Psychological Association.

Index Keywords: animal; reinforcement; review; Animal; Extinction (Psychology); Reinforcement (Psychology)
Correspondence Address: Capaldi, E.J.

Title: Criteria of expectancy
Abstract: Diagnoses expectancies of the form "aa'Eo" (i.e., "Act a rather than Act a' is expected to lead to Outcome o") by positive association between the relative frequencies of a pair of alternative acts, a and a', and a pair of opposed preference states, oPo' and o'Po. Controls to exclude artifactual association due to response biases are described, properties of such expectancies and experimental problems that arise in diagnosing them are discussed, and comparisons with earlier formalizations are made. (16 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1966 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: ATTENTION & EXPECTANCY & SET; EXPECTATION & EXPECTANCY, CRITERIA, & RESPONSE BIAS, EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN; EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN, EXPECTANCY CRITERIA & RESPONSE BIAS
Index Keywords: behavior; human; motivation; perceptive discrimination; review; Behavior; Discrimination (Psychology); Human; Motivation
Correspondence Address: Irwin, F.W.

Title: Cutaneous color sensitivity: Explanation and demonstration
Authors with affiliations: Makous, W.L., U. Washington, Seattle, United States
Abstract: Past reports that humans can, in complete darkness, sense with their fingers the colors of objects have been received with skepticism. A previously proposed hypothesis, based on differential rate of absorption of infrared radiation by different layers of the skin, is inconsistent thermodynamically. Quantitative analysis of the system consisting of a room-temperature surface juxtaposed to the higher temperature skin, however, leads to the conclusion that large differences in emissivity of different room-temperature surfaces almost certainly could be detected by the associated effects on skin temperature. Easily repeatable demonstrations confirm this, and a few simple temperature measurements confirm the theoretical identification of the mechanism. (34 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1966 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: COLOR PERCEPTION, CUTANEOUS SENSITIVITY, & TEMPERATURE; CUTANEOUS SENSITIVITY, COLOR, & TEMPERATURE; KINESTHESIS & SOMESTHESIS; TEMPERATURE, CUTANEOUS COLOR SENSITIVITY

Title: Electroconvulsive shock and inhibition: Some problems considered
Authors with affiliations: Lewis, D.J., Rutgers U.; Maher, B.A.
Abstract: Retrograde amnesia due to electro-convulsive shock (ECS) is a memory or response deficit for events that have occurred somewhat prior to the convulsion. While it is possible that the amnesia is due to the failure of an engram to consolidate, Lewis and Maher (see 39:4) pointed out that multiple ECS studies, which have so frequently been taken as supportive of the consolidation point of view, are not relevant. Here some criticisms of that study are answered, the weaknesses of many of the single ECS studies for this hypothesis are pointed out, and a conditioned-inhibition hypothesis for the amnesic effect of ECS is defended. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1966 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: BRAIN STIMULATION; INHIBITION, ELECTROCONVULSIVE SHOCK & RETROGRADE AMNESIA; NEUROLOGY, ELECTROCONVULSIVE SHOCK & RETROGRADE AMNESIA, CONSOLIDATION

Title: Mediation theory and the "single-stage" S-R model: Different?
Abstract: Argues that the widely held notion of a fundamental difference between so-called single-stage S-R models and 2-stage mediation theories is illusory, and the distinction cannot in fact be maintained in S-R theories of language. Skinner's and Osgood's accounts of verbal behavior and certain phenomena that relate to it are compared, and the basic similarity between them is pointed out. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1966 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: CONDITIONING/VERBAL, MEDIATION & SINGLE STAGE S-R MODEL; LEARNING; MEDIATION, VERBAL CONDITIONING, & SINGLE STAGE S-R MODEL; MODEL, VERBAL CONDITIONING, SINGLE STAGE S-R, & MEDIATION THEORY
Index Keywords: article; theoretical model; thinking; verbal behavior; Models, Theoretical; Thinking; Verbal Behavior

Title: Tensions in psychology between the methods of behaviorism and phenomenology
Affiliations: New School for Social Research, New York, N. Y.
Authors with affiliations: Brody, N., New School for Social Research, New York, N. Y.; Oppenheim, P.
Abstract: 3 loci of tension between behaviorism and phenomenology are discussed. Logical analysis indicates that the methods of phenomenology as defined are not relevant for the construction and test of psychological theory, although they may be valuable in other respects. 2 repprochements in which complementary roles are assigned to behaviorism and phenomenology, and the problem of terminological rapprochement are discussed. (43 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1966 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: BEHAVIORISM, & PHENOMENOLOGY; PHENOMENOLOGY, & BEHAVIORISM; PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT; PSYCHOLOGY, BEHAVIORISM & PHENOMENOLOGY
Index Keywords: article; behaviorism; philosophy; psychology; Behaviorism; Philosophy; Psychology
Correspondence Address: Brody, N.

Title: Habituation and stimulus novelty: A model based on classical conditioning
Affiliations: Wyeth Lab., Philadelphia, Pa, United States
Authors with affiliations: Stein, L., Wyeth Lab., Philadelphia, Pa, United States
Abstract: Describes a theory of habituation which assumes that: (1) the arousal reaction is controlled by antagonistic excitatory and inhibitory brain mechanisms; (2) a novel stimulus activates the excitatory mechanism which in turn activates the inhibitory mechanism; and (3) the inhibitory process is conditionable. The inhibitory mechanism becomes conditioned (by Pavlovian conditioning) to the onset of the stimulus itself after repeated presentations. Habituation of arousal occurs when the anticipatory, conditioned activation of the inhibitory mechanism overrides the direct activation of the excitatory mechanism. Reactivation of the arousal reaction when the habituated stimulus is changed is explained by a reduction in conditioned inhibitory activity due to stimulus-generalization decrement. (15 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1966 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: EXCITATION, AROUSAL HABITUATION & INHIBITORY MECHANISMS; HABITUATION, AROUSAL, INHIBITORY & EXCITATORY MECHANISMS; INHIBITION, AROUSAL HABITUATION, & EXCITATORY MECHANISMS; LEARNING

Title: Neural consolidation and electroconvulsive shock reexamined
Authors with affiliations: McGaugh, J.L., U. California, Irvine; Petrinovich, L.F.
Abstract: Lewis and Maher (see 39:4) concluded that the findings of electroconvulsive shock (ECS) studies provide little support for the consolidation hypothesis, and hypothesized that ECS effects on behavior are due to conditioned inhibition. Here it is shown that the evidence cited by Lewis and Maher, contrary to their conclusion, provides strong support for the consolidation hypothesis and that the conditioned-inhibition hypothesis proposed by them is inadequate on both logical and empirical grounds. (30 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1966 American Psychological Association.

Correspondence Address: McGaugh, J.L.; U. California, Irvine

Title: Comments on "A power comparison of the F and L tests: I"
Abstract: Boersma, DeJonge, and Stellwagen (see 39:3) fail to consider any situation except that where the specific ordered alternative of the L test is true. They thus fail to consider the general statistical inference consequences of using ordered-hypothesis tests vs. omnibus tests. The power comparison provides little useful information on the parametric vs. nonparametric choice of tests in either of the test situations. The conclusion of consistently superior power of the L test is somewhat dubious because they failed to demonstrate equal risks of Type 1 error in the 2 tests and used computer simulation of data that was inappropriate for either the randomized-blocks analysis of variance or the L test. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1966 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: MATHEMATICS & STATISTICS; STATISTICS, ORDER HYPOTHESIS L TEST VS OMNIBUS F TEST; STATISTICS/NONPARAMETRIC, ORDERED HYPOTHESIS L TEST VS OMNIBUS F TEST
Index Keywords: article; human; Human; Statistics
