Correspondence Address: Hunt, J.Mcv.; U. Illinois, Urbana, United States

Title: A field theory of extinction and spontaneous recovery
Abstract: "Both extinction and spontaneous recovery can be viewed as due to the changed direction of a psychological force toward the same goal. Measures such as latency, time required for the response, and errors can be shown not to have the same meaning in acquisition as they have in the process of extinction. One of the principal determinants of the resistance to extinction and of the tendency to spontaneous recovery is the 'relative' effortfulness of the response. Both extinction and spontaneous recovery can be viewed as problems of 'decision' in an overlapping choice situation. This requires solution of the problem of 'potency' of the situation." (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1956 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: RECOVERY, SPONTANEOUS, FIELD THEORY OF FIELD, THEORY, OF EXTINCTION, & RECOVERY EXTINCTION, FIELD THEORY OF LEARNING & MEMORY
Index Keywords: article; learning; LEARNING; Learning
Correspondence Address: Johdai, K.; Hiroshima U.Japan

Title: A new theory of color vision
Authors with affiliations: Shaw, W.A., U. Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, United States
Abstract: General dissatisfaction with existing accounts of color vision is expressed and a new theory proposed. Many color phenomena are discussed in elaborating the theory, but the bulk of the argument is set around four bits of empirical data on the behavioral level, which the author feels to be of greatest importance to color theory. A glossary of 16 terms is supplied. 36 references. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1956 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: COLOR VISION, THEORY VISION
Index Keywords: article; color vision; COLOR VISION; Color Perception
Correspondence Address: Shaw, W.A.; U. Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, United States

Title: On thought: the extrinsic theory
Authors with affiliations: Galanter, E., U. Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, United States; Gerstenhaber, M.
Abstract: "We have suggested that thought consists in modeling the environment and using the method to predict the future state of the world . . . By introducing the idea of a payoff function, we can control the motivational input to the organism, and so increase the likelihood of having its insights manifested in action. We then proposed an hypothesis relating S-R behavior and insightful behavior, and described some scraps of evidence in its support. Finally we pointed to the need for an independent measure of 'problem complexity' before we could get to the critical problem of the relation between the motivational structure of the person and the characteristics of the insight he reveals." (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1956 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: THOUGHT, EXTRINSIC FIELD THEORY OF THEORY, EXTRINSIC, OF THOUGHT THEORY & SYSTEMS
Index Keywords: article; thinking; THINKING; Thinking
Correspondence Address: Galanter, E.; U. Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, United States

Title: Mediation variables in scientific theory
Authors with affiliations: Rozeboom, W.W., U. Chicago, Ill, United States
Abstract: A discussion of mediation variables in general with particular reference to the status of intervening variables and hypothetical constructs. Particular attention is given to clarifying certain misconceptions concerning the nature of intervening variables and hypothetical constructs that arose after the publication of the 1948 paper on the subject by MacCorquodale and Meehl. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1956 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: THEORY, SCIENTIFIC, & MEDIATION VARIABLES MEDIATION, VARIABLES & SCIENTIFIC THEORY THEORY & SYSTEMS
Index Keywords: article; science; SCIENCE; Science
Correspondence Address: Rozeboom, W.W.; U. Chicago, Ill, United States

Title: The contribution of John B. Watson
Affiliations: State U. Iowa, Iowa City, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bergmann, G., State U. Iowa, Iowa City, United States
Abstract: An analysis of the professional contribution of John B. Watson, with particular attention paid to the philosophical underpinnings of his work. Though both are considered, the emphasis is more on the work of the man than the man himself. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1956 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: WATSON, J.B., WORKS, CRITIQUE BIOGRAPHY & CRITICISM, WATSON, J.B. HISTORY & BIOGRAPHY
Index Keywords: article; psychology; PSYCHOLOGY; Psychology
Correspondence Address: Bergmann, G.; State U. Iowa, Iowa City, United States

Title: Drive, incentive, and reinforcement
Affiliations: U. California, Los Angeles, United States
Authors with affiliations: Seward, J.P., U. California, Los Angeles, United States
Abstract: "This paper deals with two possible reinforcers: drive reduction and consumatory response. Experiments designed to separate their influence have yielded evidence in support of both. Drive reduction seems to be a sufficient condition for response selection. But rewards apparently do more than reduce drives; as incentives they appear to heighten excitement as well as activate instrumental responses. This poses a problem: How can drive reduction and incentive induction both produce the same result, i.e., strengthen a concurrent response? It is suggested that Guthrie's theory, with the aid of two motivational constructs, drive and goal, offers a solution." 46 references. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1956 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: REINFORCEMENT, DRIVE, & INCENTIVE INCENTIVE, DRIVE, & REINFORCEMENT DRIVE, INCENTIVE, & REINFORCEMENT LEARNING & MEMORY
Index Keywords: article; learning; LEARNING; Learning
Correspondence Address: Seward, J.P.; U. California, Los Angeles, United States

Title: Phenomenological personality theories and the data language of psychology
Abstract: "The aims of this paper are three-fold: to support the position that phenomenological theories of personality are compatible with the general scientific requirements of physicialism and predictiveness, to demonstrate that a fundamental methodological distinction between these theories and nonphenomenological theories is difficult to maintain, and, finally, to suggest that a crucial issue intrinsic to a discussion of the problems mentioned above-and one rarely raised in that connection-is the nature of the psychological data language traditionally favored by S-R and R-R theories." (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1956 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: PERSONALITY, THEORY OF, PHENOMENOLOGICAL PERSONALITY
Index Keywords: article; personality; psychology; PERSONALITY; PSYCHOLOGY; Personality; Psychology

Title: Information-receiving behavior of man
Abstract: "Communication theory as developed mainly for engineering purposes is incomplete as a theory of actual human communication. The required theory should pay proper attention to the following facts: (a) Human communication is a kind of game, sometimes cooperative and sometimes competitive. (b) The receiver's rules of decoding are usually not given; they should be developed by the receiver himself for each different information source. (c) The receiver may extract more than one information content from a signal. (d) The receiver is usually not given objective probabilities, but he estimates them. Accordingly, the amount of information and information content should be defined with respect to subjective probabilities. Particular attention should be paid to the problem of information synthesis." (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1956 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: INFORMATION, RECEIVING, COMMUNICATION COMMUNICATION, INFORMATION, RECEIVING LANGUAGE & COMMUNICATION
Index Keywords: article; psychology; PSYCHOLOGY; Psychology
Correspondence Address: Toda, M.; Hokkaido U.Japan

Authors: Guilford J.P., Kettner N.W., Christensen P.R.
Title: The nature of the general reasoning factor
Authors with affiliations: Guilford, J.P., U.S.C., Los Angeles, United States; Kettner, N.W.; Christensen, P.R.
Abstract: It has been much easier to decide what general reasoning is not than to say what it is. "By elimination and by consistent indications of a positive nature, the best we can say is that general reasoning has something to do with comprehending or structuring problems of certain kinds in preparation for solving them." (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1956 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: REASONING, GENERAL, NATURE OF CONCEPT, FORMATION, VARIABLES IN THINKING & IMAGINATION
Index Keywords: article; thinking; THINKING; Thinking
Correspondence Address: Guilford, J.P.; U.S.C., Los Angeles, United States

Title: Coin perception studies and the concept of schemata
Affiliations: U. North Carolina, Chapel Hill, United States
Authors with affiliations: McCurdy, H.G., U. North Carolina, Chapel Hill, United States
Abstract: "The following principal conclusions emerge from the present discussion: (a) The memory schema for coin sizes, while stretching out the total range and slightly exaggerating the differences between coins, preserves the correct order; (b) there is no evidence that this order is significantly disturbed by values and needs; (c) a memory schema, such as that for coin size, tends to resist correction by sensory contact with objects, contact serving as little more than a fleeting reminder, like a name; (d) departures from accurate size estimation which have been taken to favor the hypothesis that increase of value induces phenomenal magnification might better be interpreted as the result of the interference of expansive emotional states with meticulous adjustments." 18 references. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1956 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: PERCEPTION, COIN, MEMORY SCHEMATA MONEY, COIN PERCEPTION, MEMORY SCHEMATA MEMORY, SCHEMATA IN COIN PERCEPTION COMPLEX PROCESSES AND ORGANIZATIONS
Index Keywords: article; perception; PERCEPTION; Perception
Correspondence Address: McCurdy, H.G.; U. North Carolina, Chapel Hill, United States

Title: A formal theory of social power
Affiliations: U. Michigan, Ann Arbor, United States
Authors with affiliations: French Jr., J.R.P., U. Michigan, Ann Arbor, United States
Abstract: "This theory illustrates a way by which many complex phenomena about groups can be deduced from a few simple postulates about interpersonal relations. By the application of digraph theory we are able to treat in detail the patterns of relations whose importance has long been noted by the field theorists." Three major postulates are presented as well as a variety of theorems dealing with the effects of the power structure of the group, the effects of communication patterns, the effects of patterns of opinion, and leadership. 32 references. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1956 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: SOCIAL, POWER, THEORY OF SOCIAL PSYCHOLOGY
Index Keywords: article; behavior; leadership; sociology; BEHAVIOR; LEADERSHIP; SOCIOLOGY; Behavior; Leadership; Sociology
Correspondence Address: French Jr., J.R.P.; U. Michigan, Ann Arbor, United States

Authors: Garner W.R., Hake H.W., Eriksen C.W.
Title: Operationism and the concept of perception
Affiliations: Johns Hopkins U., Baltimore, Md, United States
Authors with affiliations: Garner, W.R., Johns Hopkins U., Baltimore, Md, United States; Hake, H.W.; Eriksen, C.W.
Abstract: "Perception is conceived as a process intervening between stimuli and responses. As such it can be viewed as a concept whose properties may be delimited by converging operations. Converging operations are any set of experimental operations which eliminate alternative hypotheses and which can lead to a concept which is not uniquely identified with any of the original operations, but is defined by the results of all operations performed . . . Illustrations from current experimental problems in perception indicate how some response characteristics may be isolated from perceptual properties, and vice versa." (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1956 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: PERCEPTION, & OPERATIONISM OPERATIONISM, & PERCEPTION RECEPTIVE AND PERCEPTUAL PROCESSES
Index Keywords: article; perception; psychology; PERCEPTION; PSYCHOLOGY; Perception; Psychology
Correspondence Address: Garner, W.R.; Johns Hopkins U., Baltimore, Md, United States

Title: Reinforcement and expectancy: two theories in search of a controversy
Abstract: "This paper is an attempt to appraise the present status of reinforcement and expectancy theories as exemplified by Hull's latest revision and MacCorquodale and Meehl's recent 'formalization' of Tolman's view. Specifically, the 2 systems are compared in their approaches to the derivation of inferential behavior. Hull's redefinition of habit strength changes the meaning of 'reinforcement,' while his use of rG in deriving the effect of delayed reward makes goal anticipation the major determinant of reaction potential. As a result of these changes, inference can be derived without the restrictions met by Hull's earlier attempts, in a manner closely analogous to that of expectancy theory." (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1956 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: REINFORCEMENT, & EXPECTANCY EXPECTANCY, & REINFORCEMENT LEARNING & MEMORY
Index Keywords: article; learning; LEARNING; Learning

Title: Application of the statistical theory to form perception
Abstract: "The arguments presented here are tentative, and in many respects speculative, yet they offer a consistent theory of form perception as an alternative to the diffusion hypothesis, which lacks neurophysiological foundation. The theory from which these arguments have been derived, although itself speculative to a certain degree, is based firmly upon neurophysiological and anatomical facts. It also has the less important but nevertheless relevant commendation that it has proved fruitful in dealing with other aspects of visual form perception. For the purposes of clear and detailed exposition, this paper has been confined largely to the treatment of form perception at low levels of illumination, with increasing contrast between figure and ground." 27 references. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1956 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: PERCEPTION, FORM, & STATISTICAL THEORY FORM, PERCEPTION, & STATISTICAL THEORY VISION
Index Keywords: article; depth perception; statistics; SPACE PERCEPTION; STATISTICS; Space Perception; Statistics
Correspondence Address: Day, R.H.; U. SydneyAustralia

Title: Rational choice and the structure of the environment
Affiliations: Carnegie Inst. Tech., Pittsburgh, Pa, United States
Authors with affiliations: Simon, H.A., Carnegie Inst. Tech., Pittsburgh, Pa, United States
Abstract: "In this paper I have attempted to identify some of the structural characteristics that are typical of the 'psychological' environments of organisms. We have seen that an organism in an environment with these characteristics requires only very simple perceptual and choice mechanisms to satisfy its several needs and to assure a high probability of its survival over extended periods of time. In particular, no 'utility function' needs to be postulated for the organism, nor does it require any elaborate procedure for calculating marginal rates of substitution among different wants." (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1956 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: ENVIRONMENT, & CHOICE CHOICE, & ENVIRONMENT THEORY & SYSTEMS
Index Keywords: article; psychology; thinking; PSYCHOLOGY; THINKING; Psychology; Thinking
Correspondence Address: Simon, H.A.; Carnegie Inst. Tech., Pittsburgh, Pa, United States

Title: Confirmation of theories in psychology
Abstract: "The main difficulty with inference by confirmation is that a given theory does not uniquely imply a certain consequence; that consequence may also be implied by alternative theories of psychology. To make a valid inference (inference by indirect evidence), other probabilities must be taken into account, all of which are included in the rule of Bayes. In using Bayes's rule one must establish reference classes composed of homogeneous theories, and interpret the probabilities it contains. A concrete method of applying Bayes's rule is presented in the present paper, though a number of problems are unsolved. It is expected that eventually a complete methodology will evolve that will make a technique available to the experimentalist and to the theory maker, with which valid inferences can be made." (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1956 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: PSYCHOLOGY, THEORY OF, CONFIRMATION OF THEORY & SYSTEMS
Index Keywords: article; psychology; PSYCHOLOGY; Psychology

Title: The magical number seven, plus or minus two: some limits on our capacity for processing information
Affiliations: Harvard U., Cambridge, Mass, United States
Authors with affiliations: Miller, G.A., Harvard U., Cambridge, Mass, United States
Abstract: A variety of researches are examined from the standpoint of information theory. It is shown that the unaided observer is severely limited in terms of the amount of information he can receive, process, and remember. However, it is shown that by the use of various techniques, e.g., use of several stimulus dimensions, recoding, and various mnemonic devices, this informational bottleneck can be broken. 20 references. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1956 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: INFORMATION THEORY, HUMAN LIMITS LANGUAGE & COMMUNICATION
Index Keywords: article; psychometry; statistics; PSYCHOMETRICS; STATISTICS; Psychometrics; Statistics
Correspondence Address: Miller, G.A.; Harvard U., Cambridge, Mass, United States

Title: Two-factor learning theory reconsidered, with special reference to secondary reinforcement and the concept of habit
Authors with affiliations: Mowrer, O.H., U. Illinois, Urbana, United States
Abstract: Two-factor learning theory is re-examined in the light of research on secondary reinforcement and the proprioceptive control of behavior. The result is a modification of the position which makes it more compatible with field-type theories than before. The concept of habit is given a new meaning which makes it more like positive feedback than a motive-behavior bond. The article concludes with some criticisms of the position and possible resolutions of them. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1956 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: LEARNING, THEORY, TWO-FACTOR, CRITIQUE LEARNING & MEMORY
Index Keywords: article; learning; LEARNING; Learning
Correspondence Address: Mowrer, O.H.; U. Illinois, Urbana, United States

Title: "Functionalism" in perception
Abstract: Logical, experimental, methodological, and theoretical problems in the way of straightforward studies of the phenomena of perception are discussed, with special emphasis on the issues posed by the functionalist views of Bruner and Postman. 32 references. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1956 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: PERCEPTION, FUNCTIONALISM IN RECEPTIVE AND PERCEPTUAL PROCESSES
Index Keywords: article; perception; PERCEPTION; Perception

Title: Affects and perceptual learning
Abstract: Of the many hypothesized effects of affect on the perceptual processes, the author selects the one relating to its influences on perceptual learning. The only aspect of affectivity considered here is the pleasantness-unpleasantness dimension. The discussion is set in the context of a variety of researches and theories. 32 references. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1956 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: PERCEPTION, LEARNING, & AFFECT LEARNING, PERCEPTUAL, & AFFECT LEARNING & MEMORY
Index Keywords: article; emotion; learning; perception; EMOTIONS; LEARNING; PERCEPTION; Emotions; Learning; Perception

Title: Issues distinguishing idiographic from nomothetic approaches to personality theory
Authors with affiliations: Falk, J.L., U. Illinois, Urbana, United States
Abstract: A logical and methodological discussion of the position and relationship between idiographic and nomothetic approaches to personality theory. Despite the fact that the two approaches differ in intent, it is held that they are in some ways dependent and inter-related. "Methodologically speaking, the nomothetic is potentially capable of usurping the realm of the idiographic. The chief value of idiography is seen as its function in the delineation of new variables and working hypotheses." (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1956 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: PERSONALITY, THEORY OF, IDIOGRAPHIC, & NOMOTHETIC PERSONALITY
Index Keywords: article; personality; PERSONALITY; Personality
Correspondence Address: Falk, J.L.; U. Illinois, Urbana, United States

Title: Extinction re-examined and re-analyzed: a new theory
Authors with affiliations: Razran, G., Queens Coll., NY, United States
Abstract: The article begins with a critical up-to-date summary of the facts of extinction in classical conditioning. On the basis of these data, the three main current theories of extinction are held to be inadequate. A new theory holding extinction to be effected in two stages, i.e., automatic deconditioning and counter conditioning, is presented. It is shown that the new theory fits the existing data well. 56 references. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1956 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: EXTINCTION, 2-STAGE THEORY LEARNING & MEMORY
Index Keywords: article; learning; LEARNING; Learning
Correspondence Address: Razran, G.; Queens Coll., NY, United States

Title: A micromolar approach to behavior theory
Affiliations: Yale U., New Haven, Conn, United States
Authors with affiliations: Logan, F.A., Yale U., New Haven, Conn, United States
Abstract: An examination of Hull's macromolar approach to learned behavior indicates that it is inadequate to certain bodies of data. A micromolar approach is described, in which quantitatively different behaviors are viewed as different responses, rather than as different strengths of the same response. The model is applied to a simple instrumental response with rats, and it is concluded that the micromolar approach is a potentially useful one, and deserves consideration alongside other theories of learned behavior. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1956 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: MICROMOLAR, BEHAVIOR, APPROACH TO BEHAVIOR, THEORY, MICROMOLAR THEORY & SYSTEMS
Index Keywords: article; behavior; BEHAVIOR; Behavior
Correspondence Address: Logan, F.A.; Yale U., New Haven, Conn, United States

Title: Subception: fact or artifact?
Affiliations: Harvard U., Cambridge, Mass, United States
Authors with affiliations: Eriksen, C.W., Harvard U., Cambridge, Mass, United States
Abstract: "The present paper has shown that the subseption effect reported by Lazarus and McCleary, (see 25: 7840), can be formulated as a partial correlation between the GSR and the stimulus with the verbal response held constant. The general case where such a partial correlation would be obtained is where both the GSR and verbal response are independently correlated with the stimulus, but not perfectly, and the error terms in these two response systems are not perfectly correlated with each other. Several sources of noncorrelated error between the GSR and the verbal response systems were considered." (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1956 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: STIMULUS, & GSR, SUBCEPTION LEARNING & MEMORY
Index Keywords: article; perception; PERCEPTION; Perception
Correspondence Address: Eriksen, C.W.; Harvard U., Cambridge, Mass, United States

Title: An axiomatic and experimental study of sensory order and measure
Authors with affiliations: Galanter, E.H., U. Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, United States
Abstract: Existing methods for the construction of sensory orders are criticized. Criteria for a satisfactory technique are suggested and a new method described. Illustrative examples of the use of the procedure are presented, along with some color vision data analyzed by the technique. Two possible disadvantages of the procedure that are mentioned are that no direct ordering of nonmatching elements is given and that a relative rather than an absolute order is obtained. 17 references. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1956 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: SENSORY, ORDER, & MEASURE RECEPTIVE AND PERCEPTUAL PROCESSES
Index Keywords: article; color vision; COLOR VISION/physiology; physiology; sensation; COLOR VISION/physiology; SENSATION; Color Perception; Sensation
Correspondence Address: Galanter, E.H.; U. Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, United States

Title: The study of alternative responses by means of the correlation coefficient
Affiliations: Rutgers U., New Brunswick, N. J.
Authors with affiliations: Wittenborn, J.R., Rutgers U., New Brunswick, N. J.
Abstract: A procedure is developed for determining the presence of functional equivalence among a series of alternative responses. The procedure involves the reasoning that if a suitable correlation coefficient can be derived, functional similarity may be satisfactorily inferred from the fact that alternative responses occur in similar total contexts. An illustration of the procedure is presented. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1955 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: RESPONSE, ALTERNATIVE, CORRELATION CORRELATION, COEFFICIENT, IN ALTERNATIVE RESPONSES STATISTICS
Index Keywords: article; psychometry; PSYCHOMETRICS; Psychometrics
Correspondence Address: Wittenborn, J.R.

Title: Some effects of motivational processes on cognition
Abstract: "The attempt has been made to describe the ways in which motivational processes alter cognitive ones in accordance with the nature of the material on which they act. It was suggested that needs and attitudes may act by pointing or sensitizing, organizing and reorganizing, selecting, supplying context, arousing relevant memory traces, arousing expectations, discouraging the desire to understand, obscuring differences, disturbing the recognition process, altering the physiognomic properties of experience, and animating or enlivening aspects of experience. In addition, strength of motivation may influence performance on perceptual or other cognitive tasks without producing actual cognitive change." 55 references. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1955 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: MOTIVATION, & COGNITION COGNITION, MOTIVATIONAL EFFECTS THINKING & IMAGINATION
Index Keywords: article; behavior; perception; thinking; BEHAVIOR; PERCEPTION; THINKING; Behavior; Perception; Thinking

Title: Anxiety, stimulus generalization, and differential conditioning: a comparison of two theories
Abstract: An analysis is made of some recent experimental material relating differential conditioning to anxiety within the frameworks of Hull-Spence and Bush-Mosteller models. By means of indices of relative differentiation, anxious and non-anxious subjects are shown to be equivalent from the standpoint of either theory. With the support of some additional assumptions, both theories can predict this outcome. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1955 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: GENERALIZATION, DIFFERENTIAL CONDITIONING, & ANXIETY CONDITIONING, DIFFERENTIAL, ANXIETY, & GENERALIZATION ANXIETY, & DIFFERENTIAL CONDITIONING, THEORY LEARNING & MEMORY
Index Keywords: anxiety; ANXIETY/psychology; article; learning; psychological aspect; ANXIETY/psychology; LEARNING; Anxiety; Learning

Title: What is learned in perceptual learning? A reply to Professor Postman
Authors with affiliations: Gibson, J.J., Cornell U., Ithaca, N. Y.; Gibson, E.J.
Abstract: This is a reply to Professor Postman's critique (see 30: 5713) of the Gibsons' theory. The main point of disagreement concerns the authors' belief that Postman does not avoid the problems inherent in the associationistic position by ridding it of phenomenal experience and relating it to S-R connections. It is held that Postman's position leaves him with the problem of whether perceptual learning is a change in the attachment of responses to stimuli or an increase in the specificity of responses to stimuli. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1955 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: PERCEPTION, LEARNING, THEORY LEARNING, PERCEPTUAL, THEORY LEARNING & MEMORY
Index Keywords: article; learning; perception; LEARNING; PERCEPTION; Learning; Perception
Correspondence Address: Gibson, J.J.

Title: Association theory and perceptual learning
Authors with affiliations: Postman, L., U. California, Berkeley, United States
Abstract: "We have examined two contrasting approaches to the problem of perceptual learning--traditional associationism and the specificity hypothesis of Gibson and Gibson, which ascribes all perceptual learning to the increasing effectiveness of stimulus variables. The case for the associationistic position has been reaffirmed, and the adequacy of the specificity formulation has been questioned." (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1955 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: PERCEPTION, LEARNING, & ASSOCIATION THEORY LEARNING, PERCEPTUAL, & ASSOCIATION THEORY ASSOCIATION, THEORY, & PERCEPTUAL LEARNING LEARNING & MEMORY
Index Keywords: article; learning; perception; LEARNING; PERCEPTION; Learning; Perception
Correspondence Address: Postman, L.; U. California, Berkeley, United States

Title: The descent of instinct
Affiliations: Yale U., New Haven, Conn, United States
Authors with affiliations: Beach, F.A., Yale U., New Haven, Conn, United States
Abstract: The concept of instinct is given a brief historical discussion with the goal of determining why it has shown so much vitality without an objective test for at least two millennia. The last part of the paper is devoted to an evaluation of the concept as it relates to a science of behavior. Topics discussed are: origins in philosophy and theology, early scientific uses, the anti-instinct revolt, current thought in psychology, genes and behavior, the meaning of genetical determination, and the ontogeny of behavior. The author concludes that when the methods of analysis that he proposes are applied to the various types of behavior called instinctive, the concept will disappear, to be replaced by scientifically valid and useful explanations. 30 references. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1955 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: INSTINCT, CONCEPT, HISTORY & CRITIQUE RESPONSE PROCESSES
Index Keywords: article; drive; INSTINCT; Instinct
Correspondence Address: Beach, F.A.; Yale U., New Haven, Conn, United States

Title: Conceptual and methodological problems in interpersonal perception
Authors with affiliations: Gage, N.L., U. Illinois, Urbana, United States; Cronbach, L.
Abstract: Ambiguity in the interpretation of much current research on interpersonal perception is held to be the result of certain methodological confusions. Several of these conceptual problems are described and suggestions for dealing with them presented. 23 references. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1955 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: SOCIAL, PERCEPTION, METHODOLOGICAL PROBLEMS PERCEPTION, INTERPERSONAL, METHODOLOGICAL PROBLEMS METHODS & MEASUREMENTS
Index Keywords: article; behavior; perception; BEHAVIOR; PERCEPTION; Behavior; Perception
Correspondence Address: Gage, N.L.; U. Illinois, Urbana, United States

Title: Relationships between shame and guilt in the socializing process
Authors with affiliations: Ausubel, D.P., U. Illinois, Urbana, United States
Abstract: An analysis of the basis of guilt and shame and the relationships between them indicates that guilt should develop in all cultures, given the minimally favorable social conditions. Cultural relativism in this area is seen to arise from the ethnocentric tendency to define a given trait in terms of its specific attributes in one's own culture. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1955 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: SOCIALIZATION, SHAME & GUILT IN SHAME, & GUILT, IN SOCIALIZATION GUILT, & SHAME, IN SOCIALIZATION SOCIAL PSYCHOLOGY
Index Keywords: article; emotion; personality; EMOTIONS; PERSONALITY; Emotions; Personality
Correspondence Address: Ausubel, D.P.; U. Illinois, Urbana, United States

Title: A note on second-order conditioning--and secondary reinforcement
Authors with affiliations: Razran, G., Queens Coll., Flushing, N. Y.
Abstract: It is held that the literature on both second-order conditioning and secondary reinforcement indicates that both are delicate, impermanent processes. It is even possible that second-order conditioning is a pseudo-phenomenon. In any event, the necessity for some sort of cognitive control in the complete explanation of existing data on these effects is emphasized. 34 references. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1955 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: REINFORCEMENT, SECONDARY, & SECOND-ORDER CONDITIONING CONDITIONING, SECOND-ORDER, & SECONDARY REINFORCEMENT LEARNING & MEMORY
Index Keywords: article; learning; LEARNING; Learning
Correspondence Address: Razran, G.

Title: Consciousness, behavior, and personality
Abstract: Consciousness, behavior, and personality are held to be inextricable in theory and study. It is shown that acceptance of the concept of consciousness does not necessarily carry with it an acceptance of introspectionism or the study of states of consciousness. Consciousness implies exposure to the real behavioral world and not confinement to an internal world of representation. It is pointed out, however, that the introduction of the notion of consciousness solves no concrete problem regarding behavior, but is necessary in order to come to grips with the problems of behavior and personality in a realistic fashion. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1955 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: PERSONALITY, CONSCIOUSNESS, & BEHAVIOR CONSCIOUSNESS, BEHAVIOR, & PERSONALITY BEHAVIOR, CONSCIOUSNESS, & PERSONALITY PERSONALITY
Index Keywords: article; behavior; consciousness; personality; BEHAVIOR; CONSCIOUSNESS; PERSONALITY; Behavior; Consciousness; Personality
Correspondence Address: Nuttin, J.; U. LouvainBelgium

Title: Statistical theory of distributional phenomena in learning
Authors with affiliations: Estes, W.K., Indiana U., Bloomington, United States
Abstract: An analysis of the distributional problem in learning reveals that the variables of stimulus fluctuation and interpolated learning are most ubiquitous in influence. A mathematical model developed around the concept of stimulus fluctuation allows for an account of a wide variety of experimental findings without resort to any sort of neo-Pavlovian conceptions of inhibitory potential. 25 references. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1955 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: LEARNING, DISTRIBUTIONAL PHENOMENA, STATISTICAL THEORY LEARNING & MEMORY
Index Keywords: article; learning; LEARNING; Learning
Correspondence Address: Estes, W.K.; Indiana U., Bloomington, United States

Title: The difference between Q and R
Authors with affiliations: Block, J., U. California, Berkeley, United States
Abstract: "It is the purpose of this note to specify the conditions where the equivalence between Q and R will exist and the conditions where this equivalence will not occur. The controversy which has arisen devolves from differing initial assumptions about the nature of personality rather than being an issue in the realm of matrix algebra." (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1955 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: PERSONALITY, Q & R, DIFFERENCES PERSONALITY THEORY & SYSTEMS
Index Keywords: article; psychometry; statistics; PSYCHOMETRICS; STATISTICS; Psychometrics; Statistics
Correspondence Address: Block, J.; U. California, Berkeley, United States

Title: Psychology from a biologist's point of view
Abstract: In an attempt to spell out the domain of psychological inquiry, a number of the realms of scientific and theoretical investigations are discussed. The current status of physical science, the materialism-spiritualism duality, parapsychology, and the scientific status of the concept of the spiritual life are related to the question. The basic problem of psychology is seen as, "... the exact nature if the relationship between our knowledge of the objective world and the subjective experience of knowing and all other conscious acts." The biological nature of this problem is pointed out. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1955 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: PSYCHOLOGY, FROM BIOLOGICAL VIEWPOINT BIOLOGY, & PSYCHOLOGY PROFESSIONAL PROBLEMS OF PSYCHOLOGY
Index Keywords: article; biology; psychology; BIOLOGY; PSYCHOLOGY; Biology; Psychology

Title: The stimulus conditions which follow learned responses
Authors with affiliations: Perkins Jr., C.C., Kent State U., O.
Abstract: An analysis of the stimulus conditions which immediately follow occurrences of the response acquired or extinguished is presented. It is assumed that any stimulus-response connections which become stronger are followed by a more reinforcing stimulus situation than alternate responses which tend to drop out. The analysis leads to a different treatment of conditioning than that found in reinforcement, contiguity, or two-factor approaches. The analysis leads to a clarification of the differences between trial and error learning and conditioning and at the same time implies common principles underlying both. The article concludes with an analysis of the development of observing responses and suggestions for experimental test of the theory. 20 references. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1955 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: LEARNING, LEARNED RESPONSES, STIMULUS CONDITIONS LEARNING & MEMORY
Index Keywords: article; learning; LEARNING; Learning
Correspondence Address: Perkins Jr., C.C.

Title: Notes toward a motor theory of visual egocentric localization
Authors with affiliations: Bruell, J.H., Western Reserve U., Cleveland, O.; Albee, G.W.
Abstract: The relationships between visual egocentric localization and involuntary and voluntary oculomotor innervation are described more precisely than previously. Two hypotheses are derived to account for the perception of direction and for some phenomena of egocentric apparent movement. Predictions from the hypotheses are compared with empirical data and found tenable for a variety of perceptual experiences. 23 references. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1955 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: VISION, EGOCENTRIC LOCALIZATION, MOTOR THEORY PERCEPTION, VISUAL, EGOCENTRIC LOCALIZATION, MOTOR THEORY VISION
Index Keywords: article; depth perception; vision; SPACE PERCEPTION; VISION; Space Perception; Vision
Correspondence Address: Bruell, J.H.

Title: Some problems in the theory of vigilance
Affiliations: Johns Hopkins U., Baltimore, Md, United States
Authors with affiliations: Deese, J., Johns Hopkins U., Baltimore, Md, United States
Abstract: The extrinsic stimulus factors which govern and control vigilance behavior are discussed. Two alternative theories, reinforcement and expectancy, are examined in the light of existing data. A final section is devoted to showing that a specific inhibitory construct is not required for an explanation of the maintenance of vigilance. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1955 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: VIGILANCE, BEHAVIOR, THEORY COMPLEX PROCESSES AND ORGANIZATIONS
Index Keywords: article; learning; LEARNING; Learning
Correspondence Address: Deese, J.; Johns Hopkins U., Baltimore, Md, United States

Title: Principles of performance
Authors with affiliations: Tolman, E.C., U. California, Berkeley, United States
Abstract: The author extends with modifications his earlier cognitive learning position so as to more clearly delineate the performance principles of the system. He begins by setting forth his basic assumptions concerning independent and intervening variables, and then relating them to what is called performances in the behavior space. The analysis is applied to bar-pressing, escape behavior, response combining, and vicarious trial and error. 25 references. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1955 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: PERFORMANCE, COGNITIVE LEARNING THEORY LEARNING, COGNITIVE THEORY, PERFORMANCE PRINCIPLES THEORY & SYSTEMS
Index Keywords: article; learning; LEARNING; Learning
Correspondence Address: Tolman, E.C.; U. California, Berkeley, United States

Title: Feedback theory and the reflex are concept
Authors with affiliations: Slack, C.W., Princeton U., N. J.
Abstract: The 1896 paper on the reflex are theory by John Dewey is re-examined in the light of current feedback or servo theory. It is shown that in a simple example of the reflex are, a rather complete understanding of the entire stimulus-response transaction is necessary before any definition of either the stimulus or the response is possible. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1955 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: REFLEX, ARC CONCEPT, & FEEDBACK THEORY THEORY & SYSTEMS
Index Keywords: article; learning; LEARNING; Learning
Correspondence Address: Slack, C.W.

Title: Visual figure discrimination and the mediation of equivalence responses
Authors with affiliations: Towe, A.L., U. Washington, Seattle, United States
Abstract: In an attempt to account for the inter- and intra-subject variability in a discrimination learning situation, a variant on the continuity theory of discrimination learning is developed. The proposition lays emphasis on changes in the aspect of the to be discriminated figures perceived from trial to trial. Four predictions from the formulation are developed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1955 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: LEARNING, DISCRIMINATION, EQUIVALENCE RESPONSES LEARNING & MEMORY
Index Keywords: article; learning; LEARNING; Learning
Correspondence Address: Towe, A.L.; U. Washington, Seattle, United States

Title: On making predictions from Hull's theory
Affiliations: Northwestern U., Evanston, Ill, United States
Authors with affiliations: Cotton, J.W., Northwestern U., Evanston, Ill, United States
Abstract: Without clarification and simplification of the Hullian theory, the author believes that most predictions rigorously deduced from the theory will contradict or at least differ in form the theory's empirical equations. Three levels of specificity in prediction from Hull's theory are discussed and it is held that some of the prediction failures have resulted from the false belief that the deductive procedure is necessarily simplified by making predictions at a low level of specificity. Finally, the problem of differing parameter values for different organisms is considered, and two different solutions outlined. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1955 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: HULLIAN THEORY, PREDICTIONS FROM THEORY & SYSTEMS
Index Keywords: article; behavior; BEHAVIOR; Behavior
Correspondence Address: Cotton, J.W.; Northwestern U., Evanston, Ill, United States

Title: Elicitation theory: I. An analysis of two typical learning situations
Authors with affiliations: Denny, M.R., Mich. State Coll., E. Lansing; Adelman, H.M.
Abstract: A theory of acquisition is presented and then developed in the context of two well known learning situations: the T maze, including place and response learning, and barpressing in the Skinner Box. Experimental evidence for the interpretations is cited. 23 references. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1955 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: LEARNING, ELICITATION THEORY LEARNING & MEMORY
Index Keywords: article; learning; LEARNING; Learning
Correspondence Address: Denny, M.R.; Mich. State Coll., E. Lansing

Title: Interpersonal behavior as influenced by accuracy of social perception
Authors with affiliations: Steiner, I.D., U. Illinois, Urbana, United States
Abstract: The assumptions of some branches of applied psychology that increased interpersonal competence and group efficiency result from increased accuracy of social perception have had doubt cast upon them by some recent empirical research. The concept of collective action upon which they are based is examined in an attempt to determine the limiting conditions under which the propositions are likely to be valid. 21 references. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1955 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: SOCIAL, PERCEPTION, & INTERPERSONAL BEHAVIOR PERCEPTION, OF SOCIAL, & INTERPERSONAL BEHAVIOR INTERPERSONAL, BEHAVIOR, & SOCIAL PERCEPTION BEHAVIOR, INTERPERSONAL, & SOCIAL PERCEPTION SOCIAL PSYCHOLOGY
Index Keywords: article; behavior; perception; BEHAVIOR; PERCEPTION; Behavior; Perception
Correspondence Address: Steiner, I.D.; U. Illinois, Urbana, United States

Title: The psychology of mental content reconsidered
Affiliations: Wesleyan U., Middletown, Conn, United States
Authors with affiliations: McClelland, D.C., Wesleyan U., Middletown, Conn, United States
Abstract: Titchener's structural psychology failed for two main reasons: first, the content categories that he chose did not turn out to be theoretically fruitful or operational, and second, his students categorized their own data. It is contended that the study of the "what" as well as the "how" of mental processes is still of importance, and that the projective testing movement kept this interest in content alive, but within the framework of a methodology both more scientifically sophisticated and theoretically fruitful. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1955 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: PROJECTIVE TECHNIQUES, & MENTAL CONTENT MENTAL, CONTENT, THEORY, & PROJECTIVE TESTS THINKING & IMAGINATION
Index Keywords: article; psychology; PSYCHOLOGY; Psychology
Correspondence Address: McClelland, D.C.; Wesleyan U., Middletown, Conn, United States

Title: Thinking: from a behavioristic point of view
Affiliations: U.C.L.A., Los Angeles, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Maltzman, I., U.C.L.A., Los Angeles, CA, United States
Abstract: "A theory of human problem solving has been outlined, based upon the concept of a compound temporal habit family hierarchy, which is assumed to function, at least in part, according to the principles of conditioning and trial and error learning. Some of the characteristics of the compound hierarchy were noted, and its role in different kinds of problem-solving situations was indicated." "The systematic status of thinking from a behavioristic point of view was described as a disposition or hypothetical state of the organism. Within the present theory it is equivalent to a new combination of habit strengths produced, primarily, by mediated generalization." 25 references. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1955 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: THINKING, BEHAVIORISTIC THEORY THINKING & IMAGINATION
Index Keywords: article; thinking; THINKING; Thinking
Correspondence Address: Maltzman, I.; U.C.L.A., Los Angeles, CA, United States

Title: Probabilistic functioning and the clinical method
Authors with affiliations: Hammond, K.R., U. Colorado, Boulder, United States
Abstract: "The attempt has been made here to scrutinize the clinical method from a systematic, methodological point of view. Lenzen's remarks concerning the partition between the subject and object were introduced in order to suggest that the clinician not be considered a reader of instruments, but an instrument to be understood in terms of a probability model. It was suggested that of two criteria for a reduction base, high reliability and communicability, the latter is difficult to achieve, not because of mere technical difficulties but because of a fundamental fact of behavior described as vicarious functioning. Brunswik's 'representative design' is asserted to be the research procedure which is congruent with vicarious functioning; its applicability is demonstrated by Todd, who also demonstrated the feasibility of applying a probability model to the clinical situation." (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1955 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: CLINICAL PSYCHOLOGY, METHOD, & PROBABILISTIC FUNCTION CLINICAL PSYCHOLOGY, GUIDANCE, COUNSELING THEORY & SYSTEMS
Index Keywords: article; psychology; PSYCHOLOGY; Psychology
Correspondence Address: Hammond, K.R.; U. Colorado, Boulder, United States

Title: The probability approach and nomothetic theory
Authors with affiliations: Postman, L., U. California, Berkeley, United States
Abstract: This paper is written in reply to a paper by Egon Brunswik (see 30: 35) in a symposium on the probability approach in psychology. The author attempts to present the strengths and weaknesses of both the nomethetic and probability points of view, with the aim of showing that though many of Brunswik's arguments are cogent, they can be met from within the framework of a nomothetic position. However, it is concluded that there is room for peaceful coexistence of the two approaches. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1955 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: BEHAVIOR, THEORY, PROBABILISTIC THEORY & SYSTEMS
Index Keywords: article; psychology; PSYCHOLOGY; Psychology
Correspondence Address: Postman, L.; U. California, Berkeley, United States

Title: Discussion of probabilistic functionalism
Affiliations: Stanford U., Palo Alto, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hilgard, E.R., Stanford U., Palo Alto, CA, United States
Abstract: This paper is written in reply to a paper by Egon Brunswik (see 30: 35) in a symposium on probability approaches in psychology. The writer presents counter arguments to many of Brunswik's criticisms of the nomethetic approach, and additionally presents difficulties which arise from a purely probabilistic-representative stand-point such as that espoused by Brunswik. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1955 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: BEHAVIOR, THEORY, PROBABILISTIC THEORY & SYSTEMS
Index Keywords: article; psychology; PSYCHOLOGY; Psychology
Correspondence Address: Hilgard, E.R.; Stanford U., Palo Alto, CA, United States

Title: Functionalism, psychological theory, and the uniting sciences: some discussion remarks
Abstract: This paper is written in reply to a paper by Egon Brunswik (see 30: 35) in a symposium on probability approaches in psychology. It also contains a discussion of other papers in the symposium. Considerable attention is given to the arbitrary character of the limits and methods of one scientific discipline in comparison to others. 25 references. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1955 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: BEHAVIOR, THEORY, PROBABILISTIC THEORY & SYSTEMS
Index Keywords: article; psychology; PSYCHOLOGY; Psychology

Title: Discussion: theory and reductionism
Authors with affiliations: Krech, D., U. California, Berkeley, United States
Abstract: This paper is written in reply to a paper by Egon Brunswik (see 30: 35) in a symposium on probability approaches in psychology. The writer aligns himself with the counterarguments of Postman in the latter's reply to the Brunswik paper, in the main. He goes on to criticize Brunswik by saying that he has taken a methodological criticism and made of it a cosmology. In reply to both Postman and Brunswik, the author presents the preferences, faiths, and intuitions that underlie his stand. One of the major of these faiths is that if theory is our aim, we should consciously espouse the microscopic approach in psychology. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved).
Author Keywords: BEHAVIOR, THEORY, PROBABILISTIC THEORY & SYSTEMS
Index Keywords: article; psychology; PSYCHOLOGY; Psychology
Correspondence Address: Krech, D.; U. California, Berkeley, United States

Title: SYMPOSIUM on the probability approach in psychology.
Abstract: [No abstract available]
Index Keywords: article; psychology; PSYCHOLOGY; Psychology

Title: In defense of probabilistic functionalism: a reply
Authors with affiliations: Brunswik, E., U. California, Berkeley, United States
Abstract: This paper is in reply to four other critical discussion papers by Postman, Hilgard, Krech, and Feigl. The latter four papers are written in criticism of another paper by Brunswik in the same symposium on the probability approach in psychology. Brunswik divides probabilistic functionalism into representative design and functional theory and attempts to meet the other authors' criticisms within these divisions. 29 references. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1955 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: CHICKEN, DEPTH PERCEPTION BEHAVIOR, THEORY, PROBABILISTIC THEORY & SYSTEMS

Title: Pleasure-seeking behavior and the drive-reduction hypothesis
Affiliations: State U. Iowa, Iowa City, United States
Authors with affiliations: Brown, J.S., State U. Iowa, Iowa City, United States
Abstract: By coordinating such factors as amount and kind of previous experience with a stimulus, level of sensory adaptation, and degree and kind of simultaneous stimulation, it is shown that drive cannot be equated with the sheer physical intensity of the stimulus. "When this is done, many of the supposed exceptions to the drive-reduction hypothesis are eliminated, since they can no longer be correctly described as involving increases in drive." 29 references. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1955 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: BEHAVIOR, THEORY, DRIVE REDUCTION HYPOTHESIS THEORY & SYSTEMS
Index Keywords: article; behavior; BEHAVIOR; Behavior
Correspondence Address: Brown, J.S.; State U. Iowa, Iowa City, United States

Title: The constancy of the I - V: a critique of intervening variables
Affiliations: U. C. L. A., Los Angeles, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Seward, J.P., U. C. L. A., Los Angeles, CA, United States
Abstract: "I have tried to evaluate the usefulness of intervening variables in the explanation, or prediction, of behavior. I argued that the usefulness of an I-V depends on the constancy of its relations to S-V's and R-V's as specified in three propositions. I then examined available evidence in order to test the constancy of one I-V, Hull's sEr, in the only system sufficiently quantitative for such tests to be applied." 36 references. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1955 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: INTERVIEWING, VARIABLE, CONSTANCY, CRITIQUE THEORY & SYSTEMS
Index Keywords: article; behavior; BEHAVIOR; Behavior
Correspondence Address: Seward, J.P.; U. C. L. A., Los Angeles, CA, United States

Title: The functions of schemata in perceiving
Abstract: The author objects to what he sees as the excessive emphasis recently upon the influence of transient individual needs and interests upon perception. He feels that greater attention should be directed toward the influence of the more enduring forms of cognitive organization. Specifically, he points out the usefulness of Bartlett's concept of the "schema," and attempts to relate it to a good deal of perceptual data. 47 references. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1955 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: PERCEPTION, THEORIES OF, COGNITIVE ORGANIZATION RECEPTIVE AND PERCEPTUAL PROCESSES
Index Keywords: article; perception; PERCEPTION; Perception
Correspondence Address: Vernon, M.D.

Title: Statistical theory of spontaneous recovery and regression
Authors with affiliations: Estes, W.K., Indiana U., Bloomington, United States
Abstract: "In this paper we have investigated the possibility that certain apparently spontaneous behavior changes, e.g., recovery from extinction, may be accounted for in terms of random fluctuations in stimulus conditions. Taken in isolation, the concept of random stimulus fluctuation has proved untestable, but when incorporated into a model it has led to quantitative descriptions of a variety of already established empirical relationships concerning spontaneous recovery and regression and to the determination of some new ones." 22 references. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1955 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: EXTINCTION, RESISTANCE TO, SPONTANEOUS RECOVERY, STATISTICAL THEORY LEARNING & MEMORY
Index Keywords: article; behavior; BEHAVIOR; Behavior
Correspondence Address: Estes, W.K.; Indiana U., Bloomington, United States

Title: Representative design and probabilistic theory in a functional psychology
Authors with affiliations: Brunswik, E., U. California, Berkeley, United States
Abstract: This is the core or basic paper in a symposium on the probability approach in psychology. The paper expands on earlier contentions of this author that the environment to which an organism must adjust is semierratic and that therefore all functional psychology is inherently probabilistic, demanding a representative research design of its own, and leading to a special type of high-complexity, descriptive theory. "The expansions beyond the earlier publications... concern mainly the use of a behavioral example...; the brief consideration of such semirepresentative policies as 'canvassing'; certain comparisons with factorial design and the analysis of variance, as well as with non-functionalistic uses of probability in psychology; and a discussion of actual and potential applications to the clinical-social area and to related domains." 53 references. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1955 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: PSYCHOLOGY, THEORY OF, PROBABILISTIC THEORY BEHAVIOR, THEORY, PROBABILISTIC THEORY & SYSTEMS
Index Keywords: article; psychology; PSYCHOLOGY; Psychology
Correspondence Address: Brunswik, E.; U. California, Berkeley, United States

Title: HARVEY A. CARR: 1873-1954
Authors with affiliations: Koch, H.L., U. Chicago, Ill, United States
Abstract: A brief biographical account of the professional life of the late Harvey A. Carr. Portrait, frontispiece. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1955 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: PORTRAITS, CARR, H. A. OBITUARIES, CARR, H. A. CARR, H. A., OBITUARY, & PORTRAIT HISTORY & BIOGRAPHY
